title: Percent, fraction, decimal conversions
description: Percents can be written in decimal form. ​Per-cent means per-100. So, we divide the percent by 100 to get an equivalent decimal. Then, we remove the percent sign (%). For example, 65% can be converted to decimal form by solving 65÷100. So, 65%=0.65. Another way to think of dividing by 100 is moving the decimal two places to the left.

title: Percent problems

title: Simplifying square roots
description: Roots are nice, but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So, for example, instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer, like √20? Still, we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5, which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Simplifying square roots
description: Roots are nice, but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So, for example, instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer, like √20? Still, we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5, which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Long division of polynomials
description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding how to rewrite quotients like that is *polynomial long division*.

title: Polynomial Remainder Theorem
description: The Polynomial Remainder Theorem allows us to determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a polynomial expression easily. Check it out!

title: Advanced polynomial factorization methods
description: Sal factors p(x)=2x^5+x^4-2x-1 as (2x+1)(x^4-1) using grouping. Then he further factors (x^4-1) as (x^2+1)(x+1)(x-1) using the special product form of difference of squares.

title: Coordinate plane: quadrant 1
description: Sal graphs ordered pairs, such as (8, 10) in quadrant 1 on a coordinate plane.

title: Quadrants on the coordinate plane
description: Learn about the 4 quadrants that make up a coordinate plane.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Coordinate plane: 4 quadrants
description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points, lines, and more.

title: Introduction to linear equations in 2 variables
description: Learn about a class of equations in two variables that's called "linear equations." They are called that way because their graph is a line. These are the most basic and probably most useful equations you will ever know!

title: Graph of a Linear Equation in Two Variables
description: Sal creates a graph of the linear equation 5x + 2y = 20.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Linear models word problems
description: Sal solves a word problem about a person reading a book, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

title: Introduction to Euclidean geometry
description: Euclid was a great mathematician and often called the father of geometry.  Learn more about Euclid and how some of our math concepts came about and how influential they have become.

title: Geometric definitions
description: Watch Sal solve a problem where he matches three students definition of parallel lines to a teacher's comments.

title: Angle types
description: Acute angles measure less than 90 degrees.  Right angles measure 90 degrees.  Obtuse angles measure more than 90 degrees.  Learn about angles types and see examples of each.

title: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles
description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles, as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

title: Angles between intersecting lines
description: Learn about parallel lines, transversals, and the angles they form.

title: Triangle angles
description: Learn about the angles in a triangle and a little about exterior angles being the sum of the remote interior angles.

title: Congruence of triangles and the criteria for congruence
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

title: Proofs of general theorems that use triangle congruence
description: Sal proves that a point is the midpoint of a segment using triangle congruence.

title: Theorems concerning triangle properties
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Inequalities in a Triangle
description: Intuition behind the triangle inequality theorem

title: Quadrilaterals
description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid, parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, and square.

title: Quadrilateral proof and angles
description: Learn how to find the sum of the interior angles of any polygon.

title: Area of Parallelogram
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a parallelogram is base times height, just like the formula for the area of a rectangle.

title: Area of a triangle
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Circle basics
description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs

title: Chord and Circles
description: Sal proves that if a radius in a circle is drawn so it bisects a chord, then the radius is also perpendicular to that chord. The proof uses SSS congruence.

title: Points and Circles
description: Thinking about the distance between a point and a line. Proof that a point on an angle bisector is equidistant to the sides of the angle and a point equidistant to the sides is on an angle bisector.

title: Basic constructions
description: Sal constructs a line that bisects a given angle using compass and straightedge.

title: Finding the area of a triangle using Heron's formula
description: Using Heron's Formula to determine the area of a triangle while only knowing the lengths of the sides

title: Surface area
description: Admittedly, "nets of polyhedra" sounds like the title of a bad sci-fi movie about man-eating, multi-headed fish. But in reality, nets of polyhedra are just 2D objects that wrap around 3D objects, like wrapping paper around presents.

title: Volume of cubes and cuboids
description: Sal introduces volume and compares it to length and area.  He also introduces cube units.

title: Volume of cones, cylinders, and spheres
description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h, and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

title: Presentation of Data
description: Here are a few of the many ways to look at data. Which is your favorite?

title: Graphical Representation of Data using bar graphs
description: Sal creates a bar chart using data from a survey.

title: Graphical representation  of data using histograms
description: A histogram is a graphical display of data using bars of different heights. In a histogram, each bar groups numbers into ranges. Taller bars show that more data falls in that range. A histogram displays the shape and spread of continuous sample data.

title: Measures of Central Tendency
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Probability basics
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Euclid’s division  algorithm
description: Let's get introduced to Euclid's division algorithm to find the HCF (Highest common factor) of two numbers. Let's learn how to apply it over here and learn why it works in a separate video.

title: The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
description: Independent realization from an ancestor's perspective

title: HCF and LCM
description: Find the biggest number that will divide into the given 2 numbers. This is called the GCF or greatest common factor.No worries, we'll show you how to do it.

title: Relationship between HCF and LCM
description: Finding the HCF from prime factors can sometimes be hard to imagine. Let's look at an interesting way to visualise finding the HCF of two numbers using prime factorisation. Created by

title: Proofs related to irrational numbers
description: Sal proves that the square root of 2 is an irrational number, i.e. it cannot be given as the ratio of two integers.

title: Converting fractions to repeating decimals
description: Learn how to rewrite 19/27 as a repeating decimal. What's a repeating decimal? THAT is a great question. This video explains.

title: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs
description: Sal uses the zeros of y=x^3+3x^2+x+3 to determine its corresponding graph.

title: Long division of polynomials
description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding how to rewrite quotients like that is *polynomial long division*.

title: Modelling real-world scenarios with linear equations
description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a truck's fuel consumption, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

title: Linear models word problems
description: Sal solves a word problem about a person reading a book, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

title: Slope
description: Sal shows how to find the slope of a line.

title: Solving equations using the elimination method
description: Sal uses simple elimination to figure out how many cupcakes are eaten by children and adults.

title: Solving systems of equations with substitution
description:
To solve a system of equations using substitution...
1. Isolate one of the variables in one of the equations, e.g. rewrite 2x+y=3 as y=3-2x.
2. You can now express the isolated variable using the other one. *Substitute* that expression into the second equation, e.g. rewrite x+2y=5 as x+2(3-2x)=5.
3. Now you have an equation with one variable! Solve it, and use what you got to find the other variable.

title: Number of solutions to systems of equations
description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

title: Systems of equations word problems
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+3=75 by isolating x^2 and taking the square root of both sides.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Solving quadratics by factoring
description: Sal solves the equation s^2-2s-35=0 by factoring the expression on the left as (s+5)(s-7) and finding the s-values that make each factor equal to zero.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Solving quadratics by completing the square
description: Some quadratic expressions can be factored as perfect squares. For example, x²+6x+9=(x+3)². However, even if an expression isn't a perfect square, we can turn it into one by adding a constant number. For example, x²+6x+5 isn't a perfect square, but if we add 4 we get (x+3)². This, in essence, is the method of *completing the square*

title: Solving quadratics using the quadratic formula
description: With the quadratic formula, we can solve any quadratic equation! Learn how to use it with an example.

title: Intro to arithmetic progressions
description: Let's get introduced to arithmetic progressions. Let's also look at a few examples of arithmetic progressions.

title: Basic sigma notation
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Applications of arithmetic progressions
description: Let's learn how to find the number of 3-digit numbers that are divisible by 7. Let's use this example to understand how to solve similar problems involving the application of arithmetic progressions to divisibility.

title: Definitions of similarity
description: Sal is given pairs of polygons, and then he determines whether they are similar by trying to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations.

title: Introduction to triangle similarity
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar, and how this follows from the definition of similarity.

title: Solving similar triangles
description: Sal solves two problems where a missing side length is found by proving that triangles are similar and using this to find the measure.

title: Solving problems with similar and congruent triangles
description: Sal uses the similarity of triangles and the congruence of others in this multi-step problem to find the area of a polygon.

title: Solving modeling problems with similar and congruent triangles
description: Triangle similarity, the Golden ratio, and art, all converge in this inspiring video!

title: Pythagoras Theorem
description: Proof of the Pythagorean Theorem using similarity

title: Dividing Line segments: section formula
description: Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio. A graph is given to make it easier to visualize the problem.

title: Ratio in which a point divides a line segment
description: Let's learn how to find the ratio in which a point divides a line segment. Let's learn how to do this intuitively without having to rely on a formula to do it.

title: Midpoint formula
description: Learn how to use the midpoint formula to find the midpoint of a line segment on the coordinate plane, or find the endpoint of a line segment given one point and the midpoint.

title: Area of a triangle using coordinates
description: Let's find the area of a triangle when the coordinates of the vertices are given to us. Let's do this without having to rely on the formula directly.

title: Introduction to Trigonometric ratios
description: Sal introduces sine, cosine, and tangent, and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.

title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: The reciprocal trigonometric ratios
description: Sal finds all six trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent, secant, cosecant, and cotangent) of an angle in a given right triangle.

title: Trigonometric ratios and similarity
description: Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Sine and cosine of complementary angles
description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Trigonometric ratios of special triangles
description: Introduction to 45-45-90 Triangles

title: Trigonometric Identities
description: Let's get introduced to trigonometric identities by learning the Pythagorean identities. This is our first step towards using trigonometric identities to move from one ratio to another.

title: Heights and distances
description: Let's get introduced to heights and distances. Let's learn the meaning of the terms - 'line of sight', 'angle of elevation', and 'angle of depression'.

title: Construction of Tangents to a Circle
description: Sal constructs a line tangent to a circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Circle basics
description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs

title: Arc length (degrees)
description: Finding the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: Arc length (radians)
description: Sal finds the fraction of an arc length out of the entire circumference using the radian measure of the central angle subtended by the arc.

title: Area of combination of figures
description: A worked example of finding the area of an equilateral triangle inscribed within a circle who's area is known. This video uses Heron's formula and some trigonometry.

title: Surface area of combination of solids
description: Let's learn how to find the surface area of combination of solids by breaking them down into cuboids, cylinders, cones, and hemispheres with the help of an example.

title: Volume of combination of solids
description: Let's learn how to find the volume of a complicated solid by breaking it down into cylinders, cones, hemispheres, and cuboids.

title: Volume and surface area word problems
description: See if you can find the incremental volume of a ring in cubic inches. You'll need to put to use your knowledge of how to measure volume.

title: Volume and surface area of a frustum of a cone
description: Let's learn how to find the volume of a frustum by looking at an example problem. Let's use an intuitive approach to find the volume rather than directly applying the formula.

title: Probability basics
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Multiplication rule for independent events
description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Multiplication rule for dependent events
description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.

title: Addition rule for probability
description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.

title: Intersection and union of sets
description: Sal shows examples of intersection and union of sets and introduces some set notation.

title: Types of sets
description: Sal explains the difference between a subset, a strict subset, and a superset. He also explains the notation behind these ideas.

title: Operations on sets
description: Sal shows an example finding the relative complement or difference of two sets A and B.

title: Evaluating functions
description: Functions assign a single output for each of their inputs. In this video, we see examples of various kinds of functions.

title: Inputs and outputs of a function
description: Sal finds the input value for which f(t)=13, given that f(t)=-2t+5.

title: Interpreting function notation
description: Learn how to interpret expressions that contain a function within a real-world context. In this video, the function we interpret models an account balance over time.

title: Functions and equations
description: Equations and functions are not the same thing, but they can be related in several ways. Watch Jesse Roe and Sal talk about the difference between equations and functions

title: Introduction to the domain and range of a function
description: Introducing intervals, which are bounded sets of numbers and are very useful when describing domain and range.

title: Determining the domain of a function
description: Finding the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Recognizing functions
description: Checking whether a given set of points can represent a function. For the set to represent a function, each domain element must have one corresponding range element at most.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Maximum and minimum points
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing
description: Function values can be positive or negative, and they can increase or decrease as the input increases. Here we introduce these basic properties of functions.

title: Interpreting features of graphs
description: When a function models a real-world context, we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video, we consider a graph that models temperature over time.

title: Combining functions
description: Given that f(x)=9-x^2 and g(x)=5x^2+2x+1, Sal finds (f+g)(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Piecewise functions
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. Some functions have simple rules, like "for every x, return x²." However, there can be other rules that are more elaborate. For example, "If x<0, return 2x, and if x≥0, return 3x." These are called *piecewise functions*, because their rules aren't uniform, but consist of multiple pieces

title: Determining the domain of advanced functions
description: Sal covers many different kinds of functions and shows how to determine their domain.

title: Determining the range of advanced functions
description: Sal finds the domain and the range of f(x)=3x^2+6x-2.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Introduction to logarithms
description: Sal explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.

title: The constant e and the natural logarithm
description: Sal introduces a very special number in the world of math (and beyond!), the constant 𝑒.

title: Properties of logarithms
description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for addition and subtraction of logarithms.

title: Change of base formula for logarithms
description: Sal approximates log₅(100) by rewriting it as log(100)/log(5) using the change of base rule, then evaluates with a calculator.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Exponential equations: logarithms
description: Sal solves the equation 10^(2t-3)=7.

title: Logarithmic scale (optional)
description: Vi Hart and Sal talk about how we humans perceive things nonlinearly

title: Stretching functions
description: Sal walks through several examples of how to write g(x) implicitly in terms of f(x) when g(x) is a shift or a reflection of f(x).

title: Symmetry of functions
description: Sal explains what it means for a function to be even, odd, or neither, both algebraically and graphically.

title: Graphs of radical functions
description: Sal shows various examples of functions and their graphs that are a result of shifting and/or flipping y=√x.

title: Graphs of logarithmic functions
description: Sal graphs y=2^x and y=log_2(x) on the same coordinate plane, showing how they relate as graphs of inverse functions.

title: Graphs of polynomials using their zeroes
description: Sal uses the zeros of y=x^3+3x^2+x+3 to determine its corresponding graph.

title: End behavior of polynomial functions
description: Sal explains what "end behavior" is and what affects the end behavior of polynomial functions.

title: Intro to radians
description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: Trigonometric values of special angles
description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.

title: Trigonometric functions
description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine, cosine, and tangent for all real numbers.

title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Trigonometric identities
description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.

title: Trigonometric equations
description: Sal finds the expressions that together represent all possible solutions to the equation sin(x)=1/3.

title: Deductive and inductive reasoning
description: Sal discusses the difference between inductive and deductive reasoning by considering a word problem.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Principle of mathematical induction
description: Proving an expression for the sum of all positive integers up to and including n by induction

title: What are the imaginary numbers?
description: Sal introduces the imaginary unit i, which is defined by the equation i^2=-1. He then gets to know this special number better by thinking about its powers.

title: What are the complex numbers?
description: Sal explains how we obtain complex numbers by adding real numbers and imaginary numbers.

title: The complex plane
description: Sal shows how to plot various numbers on the complex plane.

title: Adding & subtracting complex numbers
description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multiplying complex numbers
description: Sal multiplies (1-3i) by (2+5i).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Complex conjugates & dividing complex numbers
description: Sal explains what is the conjugate of a complex number, and shows how the product of a complex number and its conjugate is always a real number.

title: Absolute value & angle of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the absolute value of (3-4i).

title: Distance & midpoint of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the distance between (2+3i) and (-5-i) and then he finds their midpoint on the complex plane.

title: Polar form of complex numbers
description: Sal rewrites the complex number -3+2i (which is given in rectangular form) in its polar form.

title: Multiplying & dividing complex numbers in polar form
description: Sal shows how complex division affects the modulus and the argument of the divisor and the dividend.

title: Introduction to inequalities with variables
description: A solution to an inequality makes that inequality true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an inequality true.

title: One-step inequalities
description: Our discussion of linear inequalities begins with multiplying and dividing by negative numbers. Listen closely for the word "swap." Super important!

title: Two-step inequalities
description: Two-step inequalities are slightly more complicated than one-step inequalities (duh!). This is a worked example of solving ⅔>-4y-8⅓.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multi-step inequalities
description: Sal solves the inequality -3p-7<p+9, draws the solution on a number line and checks a few values to verify the solution.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Compound inequalities
description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5z+7<27 OR -3z≤18.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Checking solutions of two-variable inequalities
description: Sal checks if the ordered pairs (3,5) and (1,-7) are solutions of the inequality 5x-3y≥25.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphing two-variable inequalities
description: Learn how to graph two-variable linear inequalities like y≤4x+3.

title: Fundamental Principle of Counting
description: Tree diagrams display all the possible outcomes of an event. Each branch in a tree diagram represents a possible outcome. Tree diagrams can be used to find the number of possible outcomes and calculate the probability of possible outcomes.

title: Permutations
description: Sal explains a tricky factorial problem about counting seat arrangements.

title: Combinations
description: Sal introduces the basic idea of combinations.

title: Binomial Theorem for Positive Integral Indices
description: Sal explains what's the binomial theorem, why it's useful, and how to use it.

title: Sequences
description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms"), like 2,5,8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example, 2,5,8 follows the pattern "add 3," and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example, 2,5,8,... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Basic sigma notation
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Finite geometric series
description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn more about it here.

title: Finite geometric series applications
description: Watch Sal solve an example of using a geometric series to answer a fun word problem.

title: Sum to n terms of special series
description: What is the sum of the first n squares, 1 + 4 + 9 + 16 + ... + n²? In this video we begin the journey towards finding a formula for this sum.

title: x-intercepts and y-intercepts
description: Learn what x- and y-intercepts are.  The equations used in this video are y = 0.5x - 3 and 5x + 6y = 30.

title: Slope
description: Sal shows how to find the slope of a line.

title: Horizontal & vertical lines
description: When two points have the same y-value, it means they lie on a horizontal line. The slope of such a line is 0, and you will also find this by using the slope formula.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Intro to slope-intercept form
description: Slope-intercept form, y=mx+b, of linear equations, emphasizes the slope and the y-intercept of the line. Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Graphing slope-intercept equations
description: To graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form, we can use the information given by that form. For example, y=2x+3 tells us that the slope of the line is 2 and the y-intercept is at (0,3). This gives us one point the line goes through, and the direction we should continue from that point to draw the entire line.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Parallel and perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane
description: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Writing slope-intercept equations
description: Learn to write equations in slope-intercept form for three different lines.

title: Point-slope form
description: Point-slope is the general form y-y₁=m(x-x₁) for linear equations. It emphasizes the slope of the line and a point on the line (that is not the y-intercept). Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Standard form
description: The standard form for linear equations in two variables is Ax+By=C. For example, 2x+3y=5 is a linear equation in standard form. When an equation is given in this form, it's pretty easy to find both intercepts (x and y). This form is also very useful when solving systems of two linear equations.

title: Distance between a point and a line
description: The distance from a point to a line is the shortest distance between the point and any point on the line. This can be done with a variety of tools like slope-intercept form and the Pythagorean Theorem.

title: Introduction to conic sections
description: Sal introduces the four conic sections and shows how they are derived by intersecting planes with cones in certain ways.

title: Standard equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Expanded equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.

title: Features of an ellipse
description: Sal introduces ellipses and shows how their standard equation relates to their center and radii (ellipses have two radii: major and minor).

title: Foci of an ellipse
description: Sal explains how the radii and the foci of an ellipse relate to each other, and how we can use this relationship in order to find the foci from the equation of an ellipse.

title: Features of a parabola
description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.

title: Features of a hyperbola
description: Sal introduces the standard equation for hyperbolas, and how it can be used in order to determine the direction of the hyperbola and its vertices.

title: Foci of a hyperbola
description: Sal discusses the foci of hyperbolas and shows how they relate to hyperbola equations.

title: Identifying conic sections from their expanded equations
description: Sal manipulates the equation x^2+y^2-3x+4y=4 in order to find that it represents a circle, and the equation 2x^2+y+12x+16=0 in order to find it represents a parabola.

title: Limits introduction
description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Limits from tables
description: Sal finds the limit of 3sin(5x)/sin(2x) at x=0 using a table of values.

title: Limits from graphs
description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function isn't defined at the limiting value but that doesn't mean the limit doesn't exist!

title: One-sided limits
description: A one-sided limit is the value the function approaches as the x-values approach the limit from *one side only*. For example, f(x)=|x|/x returns -1 for negative numbers, 1 for positive numbers, and isn't defined for 0. The one-sided *right* limit of f at x=0 is 1, and the one-sided *left* limit at x=0 is -1.

title: One-sided vs. Two-sided limits
description: Sal explains the relationship between the 1-sided limits and the 2-sided limit of a function at a point, using a graphical example where the 1-sided limits exist but the 2-sided limit doesn't.

title: Formal definition of limits (optional)
description: A quick reminder of what limits are, to set up for the formal definition of a limit.

title: Limits from equations (factoring & rationalizing)
description: Sal finds the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) at x=2 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Squeeze theorem
description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers, and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k), then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0, by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

title: Introduction to differential calculus
description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Derivative as instantaneous rate of change
description: Sal finds the average rate of change of a curve over several intervals, and uses one of them to approximate the slope of a line tangent to the curve.

title: Secant lines
description: What is the slope of a line between two points on a curve?  This is called a "secant" line.

title: Derivative as a limit
description: The derivative of function f at x=c is the limit of the slope of the secant line from x=c to x=c+h as h approaches 0. Symbolically, this is the limit of [f(c)-f(c+h)]/h as h→0.

title: Formal definition of derivative
description: Sal introduces two ways of writing the limit expression for the derivative of a function at a point.

title: Using the formal definition of derivative
description: Sal finds the limit expression for the derivative of f(x)=x² at the point x=3 and evaluates it.

title: Derivative as a function
description: Given the graph of a function, Sal sketches the graph of its derivative.

title: Power rule
description: Sal introduces the power rule, which tells us how to find the derivative of xⁿ.

title: Polynomial functions differentiation
description: Once you know how to take the derivative of x^n, it turns out you can take the derivative of any polynomial.  Let's see why...

title: Sine & cosine, eˣ and ln(x) derivatives
description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Product rule
description: Introduction to the product rule, which tells us how to take the derivative of a product of functions.

title: Measures of dispersion
description: Sal discusses the three most common measures of spread!

title: Range
description: The range is the difference between the largest and smallest numbers. The midrange is the average of the largest and smallest number. Practice with this problem.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Mean absolute deviation (grouped data)
description: Mean absolute deviation (MAD) of a data set is the average distance between each data value and the mean. Mean absolute deviation is a way to describe variation in a data set. Mean absolute deviation helps us get a sense of how "spread out" the values in a data set are.

title: Variance and standard deviation (ungrouped data):
description: Sal discusses the three most common measures of spread!

title: Comparing distributions
description: Sal examines two distributions in dot plots to draw conclusions about the times of Olympic swimmers.

title: Basic probability
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Addition rule for probability
description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.

title: Compound probability of independent events using diagrams
description: We're thinking about the probability of rolling doubles on a pair of dice. Let's create a grid of all possible outcomes.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Compound probability of independent events using the multiplication rule
description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Probability using combinatorics
description: Probability of getting exactly 3 heads in 8 flips of a fair coin.

title: Introduction to inverses of functions
description: Sal explains what inverse functions are. Then he explains how to algebraically find the inverse of a function and looks at the graphical relationship between inverse functions.

title: Finding inverse functions
description: Sal finds the inverses of f(x)=-x+4 and g(x)=-2x-1.

title: Formal definition of inverse functions (optional)
description: Introduction to the inverse of a function

title: Binary operations
description: Sal solves a few problems where a new operator is defined and Sal evaluates some expression with it.

title: Basic concepts of inverse trigonometry
description: Sal introduces arcsine, which is the inverse function of sine, and discusses its principal range.

title: Domain and range of inverse trigonometric functions
description: Sal finds the formula for the inverse function of g(x)=tan(x-3π/2)+6, and then determines the domain of that inverse function.

title: Introduction to matrices
description: Take the red pill and enter the Matrix!

title: Adding & subtracting matrices
description: Sal defines what it means to add or subtract matrices. He shows a few examples and discusses some important properties of matrix addition and subtraction.

title: Multiplying matrices by scalars
description: Sal defines what it means to multiply a matrix by a scalar (in the world of matrices, a scalar is simply a regular number).

title: Multiplying matrices by matrices
description: Sal explains what it means to multiply two matrices, and gives an example.

title: Properties of matrix multiplication
description: Sal discusses the conditions of matrix dimensions for which addition or multiplication are defined.

title: Transpose of a matrix
description: Transpose of a matrix

title: Invertible matrices
description: Sal introduces the concept of an inverse matrix.

title: Inverse of a matrix by elementary operations
description: Sal explains how we can find the inverse of a 3x3 matrix using Gaussian elimination.

title: Determinants
description: Sal shows how to find the determinant of a 2x2 matrix.

title: Properties of determinants
description: The determinant when a row is multiplied by a scalar

title: Adjoint and inverse of a matrix using minors and cofactors
description: Sal shows how to find the inverse of a 3x3 matrix using its determinant. In Part 1 we learn how to find the matrix of minors of a 3x3 matrix and its cofactor matrix.

title: Solving equations with inverse matrices
description: Sal shows how a system of two linear equations can be represented with the equation A*x=b where A is the coefficient matrix, x is the variable vector, and b is the constant vector.

title: Determinants in more depth (Optional)
description: Determining a method for constructing inverse transformation matrices

title: Continuity at a point
description: Sal introduces a formal definition of continuity at a point using limits.

title: Review: Limits of combined & composite functions
description: What is the limit of the sum of two functions?  What about the product?

title: Continuous functions
description: Sal is asked which of the following two functions is continuous on all real numbers: eˣ and/or √x. In general, the common functions are continuous on all the numbers in their domain.

title: Review: Intermediate value theorem
description: Introduction to the Intermediate value theorem. If f is a continuous function over [a,b], then it takes on every value between f(a) and f(b) over that interval.

title: Product rule
description: Introduction to the product rule, which tells us how to take the derivative of a product of functions.

title: Quotient rule
description: Sal shows how you can derive the quotient rule using the product rule and the chain rule (one less rule to memorize!)

title: Chain rule
description: The chain rule states that the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). In other words, it helps us differentiate *composite functions*. For example, sin(x²) is a composite function because it can be constructed as f(g(x)) for f(x)=sin(x) and g(x)=x². Using the chain rule and the derivatives of sin(x) and x², we can then find the derivative of sin(x²).

title: Exponential functions differentiation
description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Derivatives capstone
description: Sal differentiates eᶜᵒˢˣ⋅cos(eˣ) by applying both the product rule and the chain rule.

title: Implicit differentiation introduction
description: Some relationships cannot be represented by an explicit function. For example, x²+y²=1. Implicit differentiation helps us find ​dy/dx even for relationships like that. This is done using the chain ​rule, and viewing y as an implicit function of x. For example, according to the chain rule, the derivative of y² would be 2y⋅(dy/dx).

title: Implicit differentiation (advanced examples)
description: Implicit differentiation of y = cos(5x - 3y)

title: Inverse trig functions differentiation
description: Derivative of inverse sine

title: Proofs for the derivatives of eˣ and ln(x)
description: Taking the derivative of ln x

title: Logarithmic differentiation
description: Sal finds the derivatives of xˣ and x^(xˣ). They are surprisingly fun to do!

title: Mean value theorem
description: The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b] and differentiable on the open interval (a,b), then there exists a point c in the interval (a,b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a,b]. In other words, the graph has a tangent somewhere in (a,b) that is parallel to the secant line over [a,b].

title: Critical points
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Relative minima & maxima
description: Once you find a critical point, how can you tell if it is a minimum, maximum or neither?

title: Absolute minima & maxima
description: The Extreme value theorem states that if a function is continuous on a closed interval [a,b], then the function must have a maximum and a minimum on the interval. This makes sense: when a function is continuous you can draw its graph without lifting the pencil, so you must hit a high point and a low point on that interval.

title: Concavity
description: Sal introduces the concept of concavity, what it means for a graph to be "concave up" or "concave down," and how this relates to the second derivative of a function.

title: Points of inflection
description: Inflection points are points where the function changes concavity, i.e. from being "concave up" to being "concave down" or vice versa. They can be found by considering where the second derivative changes signs. In similar to critical points in the first derivative, inflection points will occur when the second derivative is either zero or undefined.

title: Sketching graphs using calculus
description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=3x⁴-4x³+2 including extremum and inflection points.

title: Approximations
description: Sal introduces the idea of approximating curves using their tangent line equations. This is also called "local linearization."

title: Rectilinear motion (optional)
description: The position of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by s(t)=t³-6t²+9t. Sal analyzes it to find the times when the particle is "speeding up."

title: Related rates
description: What's the relationship between how fast a circle's radius changes, and how fast its area changes?

title: Tangents & Normals
description: Sal finds the equation of the line tangent to the curve y=eˣ/(2+x³) at the point (1,e/3).

title: Optimization
description: What is the minimum possible value of x^2+y^2 given that their product has to be fixed at xy = -16

title: Applied rates of change
description: Let's face it, sometimes it feels like we forget much of what we learn.  In this example we model that forgetful phenomenon.

title: L'Hôpital's rule
description: When you are solving a limit, and get 0/0 or ∞/∞, L'Hôpital's rule is the tool you need.

title: Antiderivatives
description: What's the opposite of a derivative?  It's something called the "indefinite integral".

title: Indefinite integrals intro
description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Indefinite integrals of common functions
description: ∫sin(x)dx=-cos(x)+C, ∫cos(x)dx=sin(x)+C, and ∫eˣdx=eˣ+C. Learn why this is so and see worked examples.

title: Integration by parts
description: By looking at the product rule for derivatives in reverse, we get a powerful integration tool.

title: u-substitution
description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

title: Reverse chain rule
description: What is the "reverse chain rule", and why it does the same thing as u-substitution.

title: Partial fraction expansion
description: When you are integrating a function in the form of a fraction, it helps to find a way to break apart the expression.

title: Integration using trigonometric identities
description: A specialized form of u-substitution involves taking advantage of trigonometric identities.

title: Trigonometric substitution
description: Introduction to trigonometric substitution

title: Functions defined by integrals
description: Finding a definite integral by breaking it down to smaller intervals that are adjacent to each other.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how, in some sense, integration is the opposite of differentiation.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus: chain rule
description: See what the fundamental theorem of calculus looks like in action.

title: Definite integral as area
description: If you already know the area under a curve, you can use it to compute an integral.

title: Definite integral properties
description: Sal uses a graph to explain why we can take a constant out of a definite integral.

title: Definite integral evaluation
description: There are really two versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus, and we go through the connection here.

title: Challenging definite integrals
description: A rather difficult integration by parts problem.

title: Improper integrals
description: Improper integrals are definite integrals where one or both of the ​boundaries is at infinity, or where the integrand has a vertical asymptote in the interval of integration. As crazy as it may sound, we can actually calculate some improper integrals using some clever methods that involve limits.

title: Riemann sums
description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: Riemann sums with sigma notation
description: Here we express the approximation of the area under a curve in sigma notation.

title: Trapezoidal rule
description: Estimating the area under a curve with trapazoids instead of rectangles can give a closer approximation.

title: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum
description: Definite integrals represent the exact area under a given curve, and Riemann sums are used to approximate those areas. However, if we take Riemann sums with infinite rectangles of infinitely small width (using limits), we get the exact area, i.e. the definite integral!

title: Area under simple curves
description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Area between two curves
description: By integrating the difference of two functions, you can find the area between them.

title: Area defined by polar graphs
description: Develop intuition for the area enclosed by polar graph formula

title: Arc length (optional)
description: We can use definite integrals to find the length of a curve. See how it's done and get some intuition into why the formula works.

title: Intro to differential equations
description: Differential equations are equations that relate a function with one or more of its derivatives. This means their solution is a function! Learn more in this video.

title: Slope fields (optional)
description: Slope fields allow us to analyze differential equations graphically. Learn how to draw them and use them to find particular solutions.

title: Separable equations
description: "Separation of variables" allows us to rewrite differential equations so we obtain an equality between two integrals we can evaluate. Separable equations are the class of differential equations that can be solved using this method.

title: Homogeneous equations
description: Introduction to first order homogenous equations.

title: Exact equations and integrating factors
description: Chain rule using partial derivatives (not a proof; more intuition).

title: Vector basics
description: The difference between vectors and scalars. ​Introduction to distance, displacement, speed, and velocity.

title: Unit vectors
description: Learn what a unit vector is and how to find a unit vector in the direction of a given vector.

title: Adding vectors in magnitude & direction form
description: Watch Sal add two vectors given in magnitude and direction form by breaking them down into components first.

title: Dot product:  Scalar product of two vectors
description: Definitions of the vector dot product and vector length

title: Cross product: Vector product of two vectors
description: Introduction to the cross product

title: Review: Multiplication rule for independent events
description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Review: Combinatorics and probability
description: Probability of getting exactly 3 heads in 8 flips of a fair coin.

title: Multiplication rule for dependent events
description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.

title: Conditional probability and independence
description: Sal solves a conditional probability example where he thinks about probabilities like P(A | B) where the events are about lunch and breakfast!

title: Baye's Theorem
description: Conditional probability visualized using trees.

title: Discrete and continuous random variables and probability models
description: Basic idea and definitions of random variables

title: Expected value
description: Understanding an insurance company's sense of my chances of dying.

title: Variance of random variables
description: Sal derives the variance of the difference of random variables

title: Binomial random variables
description: Sal introduces the binomial distribution with an example.

title: Poisson distribution (optional)
description: Introduction to Poisson Processes and the Poisson Distribution.

title: Integer arithmetic properties (Hindi)
description: Anmol uses pictures and practice problems to see commutativity and associativity in multiplication.

title: Multiplying & dividing negative numbers (Hindi)
description: Learn some rules of thumb for multiplying positive and negative numbers.

title: Multiplying unit fractions and whole numbers (Hindi)
description: Anmol multiplies 1/2 x 5 using repeated addition and fraction models.

title: Multiplying whole numbers and fractions (Hindi)
description: Anmol gives a visual explanation of multiplying a fraction and a whole number.

title: Multiplication as scaling (Hindi)
description: Anmol compares the following expressions by thinking about multiplication as scaling: 2/3x7/8, 8/7x2/3, and (5x2)/(3x5).

title: Multiplying fractions (Hindi)
description: Anmol introduces multiplying 2 fractions.

title: Multiplying mixed numbers (Hindi)
description: Anmol introduces multiplying mixed numbers.

title: Multiplying fractions word problems (Hindi)
description: Anmol solves a word problem by multiplying 2 fractions.

title: Fractions as division (Hindi)
description: Anmol shows how a/b and a÷b are equivalent. That is, the fraction bar and the division symbol mean the same thing.

title: Dividing fractions by fractions (Hindi)
description: Using a number line, we'll explain why multiplying by the inverse is the same as dividing.

title: Dividing fractions word problems (Hindi)
description: Dividing a whole number by a fraction? Turn the tables and multiply by the reciprocal of the fraction. Boom!

title: Multiplying decimals (Hindi)
description: Anmol introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.

title: Multiplying decimals: standard algorithm (Hindi)
description: Sometimes multiplying really small decimals (with all those zeros!) can be a little intimidating. Watch as we show you a handy trick to simplify these problems and solve them.

title: Dividing decimals (Hindi)
description: Anmol divides 63÷35.

title: Dividing decimals: standard algorithm (Hindi)
description: Decimal divisors in the hundredths place can be a little confusing. In this video we'll show you how to move the decimal and make it a whole number. Pretty nifty! Watch.

title: Algebraic equations basics (Hindi)
description: Learn what variables, expressions, and equations are.

title: One-step equations intuition (Hindi)
description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.

title: One-step addition & subtraction equations (Hindi)
description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.

title: One-step multiplication and division equations (Hindi)
description: Let's ease into this, shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!

title: One-step equation word problems (Hindi)
description: Using information from the Super swimming word problem, explore all the possible combinations and create equations which express the possibilities. Let's figure out which plan is best!

title: Two-steps equations intro (Hindi)
description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

title: Two-step equation word problems (Hindi)
description: Learn how to construct and solve a basic linear equation to solve a word problem.

title: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles (Hindi)
description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles, as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

title: Angles between intersecting lines (Hindi)
description: Learn about parallel lines, transversals, and the angles they form.

title: Triangle angles (Hindi)
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Equilateral and isosceles triangles (Hindi)
description: Angles opposite to equal sides of an isosceles triangle are equal to each other.

title: Triangle inequality theorem (Hindi)
description: Intuition behind the triangle inequality theorem.

title: Pythagoras theorem (Hindi)
description: Introduction to the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Triangle congruence (Hindi)
description: Anmol explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

title: Area and perimeter (Hindi)
description: Anmol figures out the width of Lucky's farm, for which the total perimeter and length are given.

title: Area of parallelograms (Hindi)
description: Learn how to find the area of a parallelogram.

title: Area of triangles (Hindi)
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Area of shapes on grids (Hindi)
description: Learn how to calculate the area of a triangle on a grid.

title: Area and circumference of circles (Hindi)
description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle in HIndi

title: Area of composite figures (Hindi)
description: Learn to break up irregular shapes into smaller geometric shapes to determine area.

title: Area unit conversions (Hindi)
description: Let's learn how to convert between area units like square centimetres, square metres and square kilometres.

title: The constituents of an expression (Hindi)
description: This video explains what the words term, factor, and coefficient mean. Think of an expression as a sentence. A sentence has parts, and so does an algebraic expression.

title: Combining like terms- part 1/2 (Hindi)
description: In simple addition we learned to add all the numbers together to get a sum. In algebra, numbers are sometimes attached to variables and we need to make sure that the variables are alike before we add the numbers.

title: Combining like terms- part 2/2 (Hindi)
description: We've learned about order of operations and combining like terms. Let's layer the distributive property on top of this.

title: Adding & subtracting algebraic expressions (Hindi)
description: Sal simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x)

title: Adding and subtracting algebraic expressions : two variables (Hindi)
description: Anmol simplifies (4x²y - 3x² - 2y) + (8xy - 3x² + 2x²y + 4).

title: Finding the value of an expression (Hindi)
description: We're going to put our order of operations knowledge to work as we evaluate this expression. Exponents, specifically, are our focus here.

title: Number patterns (Hindi)
description: Anmol uses factors and multiples to figure out days of the week.

title: Exponents (Hindi)
description: introduction to exponents and exponential growth

title: Exponent properties- part 1/2 (Hindi)
description: When multiplying numbers with common base, add exponents

title: Exponent properties- part 2/2 (Hindi)
description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video, we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Two-steps equations intro (Hindi)
description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

title: Algebraic equation types (Hindi)
description: Equations of the form AX=B

title: Linear equations with variables on both sides (Hindi)
description: We will use a scale to try to achieve balance and help explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation, even when the variable appears on both sides.

title: Linear equations with parentheses (Hindi)
description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.

title: Analyzing the number of solutions to linear equations (Hindi)
description: See how some equations have one solution, others have no solutions, and still others have infinite solutions.

title: Linear equations word problems (Hindi)
description: Anmol solves the following age word problem: The sum of 4 consecutive odd integers is 136. What are the 4 integers?

title: Two-step equation word problems (Hindi)
description: Learn how to construct and solve a basic linear equation to solve a word problem.

title: Angles with polygons (Hindi)
description: Learn how to find the sum of the interior angles of any polygon.

title: Quadrilateral types (Hindi)
description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid, parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, and square.

title: Quadrilateral proofs and angles (Hindi)
description: Anmol proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: Square roots (Hindi)
description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Approximating square roots (Hindi)
description: Learn how to approximate the decimal value of √45 without using a calculator.

title: Simplifying square roots (Hindi)
description: Roots are nice, but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So, for example, instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer, like √20? Still, we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5, which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Cube roots (Hindi)
description: Learn the meaning of cube roots and how to find them. Also learn how to find the cube root of a negative number.

title: Adding & subtracting polynomials (Part1/2) (Hindi)
description: Anmol simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x).

title: Adding and subtracting polynomials (Part2/2) (Hindi)
description: Anmol simplifies (x³ + 3x - 6) + (-2x² + x - 2) - (3x - 4).

title: Multiplying monomials (Hindi)
description: Learn how to multiply monomials like 5x² * 4x⁶ or 4p³ * p.

title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials (Hindi)
description: Sal expresses the product (10a-3)(5a² + 7a - 1) as 50a³+55a²-31a+3.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Polynomials word problems (Hindi)
description: Anmol finds the volume of a tank whose base has an area of 3x² + 30x + 5 square feet and whose height is 8x - 5 feet.

title: Area of trapezoids & composite figures (Hindi)
description: Area of a trapezoid is found with the formula, A=(a+b)/2 x h.  Learn how to use the formula to find area of trapezoids.

title: Surface area (Hindi)
description: Surface area is the sum of the areas of all faces (or surfaces) on a 3D shape. A cuboid has 6 rectangular faces. To find the surface area of a cuboid, add the areas of all 6 faces. We can also label the length (l), width (w), and height (h) of the prism and use the formula, SA=2lw+2lh+2hw, to find the surface area.

title: Volume of rectangular prisms (Hindi)
description: Anmol introduces volume and compares it to length and area. He also introduces cube units.

title: Volume and surface area of cylinder (Hindi)
description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h, and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

title: Negative exponents (Hindi)
description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with negative exponents as fractions with positive exponents.

title: Direct and inverse proportion (Hindi)
description: Anmol explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.

title: Introduction to factorization (Hindi)
description: Anmol explains what it means for a polynomial to be a factor of another polynomial, and what it means for a polynomial to be divisible by another polynomial.

title: Factoring monomials (Hindi)
description: Anmol analyzes two different factorizations of 24x^5 and determines whether they are correct.

title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors (Hindi)
description: Anmol shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).

title: Evaluating expressions with unknown variables (Hindi)
description: Anmol solved a few examples where we need to evaluate an expression, but we don't know the individual variable values.

title: Factoring quadratics intro (Hindi)
description: Anmol factors x²-3x-10 as (x+2)(x-5) using the sum-product form: (x+a)(x+b)=x²+(a+b)x+a*b.

title: Factoring quadratics by grouping (Hindi)
description: Anmol introduces the method of grouping, which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.

title: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms (Hindi)
description: Anmol factors 35k^2+100k-15 as 5(k+3)(7k-1).

title: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares (Hindi)
description: When an expression can be viewed as the difference of two perfect squares, i.e. a²-b², then we can factor it as (a+b)(a-b). For example, x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This method is based on the pattern (a+b)(a-b)=a²-b², which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a-b).

title: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares (Hindi)
description: When an expression has the general form a²+2ab+b², then we can factor it as (a+b)². For example, x²+10x+25 can be factored as (x+5)². This method is based on the pattern (a+b)²=a²+2ab+b², which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a+b).

title: Strategy in factoring quadratics (Hindi)
description: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. After learning all of them in separate, let's think strategically about which method is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

title: Factoring polynomials with special product forms (Hindi)
description: Anmol factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.

title: Practice dividing polynomials with remainders (Hindi)
description: Anmol divides (18x^4-3x^2+6x-4) by 6x.

title: Intro to the coordinate plane (Hindi)
description: Introduction to the coordinate plane and plotting points on the coordinate plane.

title: Coordinate plane word problems (Hindi)
description: Anmol plots the corners of a rectangle on the first quadrant of a coordinate plane.

title: Irrational numbers (Hindi)
description: Learn what rational and irrational numbers are and how to tell them apart.

title: Rational numbers and repeating decimals (Hindi)
description: Learn how to rewrite 19/27 as a repeating decimal. What's a repeating decimal? THAT is a great question. This video explains.

title: Sums and products of rational and irrational numbers (Hindi)
description: Anmol proves that the sum, or the product, of any two rational numbers will always be a rational number.

title: Exponent properties review (Hindi)
description: For any base a and for any exponents n and m, aⁿ⋅aᵐ=aⁿ⁺ᵐ and aⁿ/aᵐ=aⁿ⁻ᵐ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

title: Radicals (Hindi)
description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Rational exponents intro (Hindi)
description: What does it mean to take a number by a power which is a unit fraction? For example, what is the result of 3 raised to ½?

title: Properties of exponents (rational exponents) (Hindi)
description: Anmol simplifies the expression m^(7/9) / m^(1/3) as a single exponential term m^(4/9).

title: Advanced: exponent & radical evaluation (Hindi)
description: Anmol shows how to evaluate 64^(2/3) and (8/27)^(-2/3).

title: Simplifying square roots (Hindi)
description: Roots are nice, but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So, for example, instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer, like √20? Still, we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5, which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Simplifying radicals (higher-index roots) (Hindi)
description: Multiple examples of simplifications of higher-index radicals. For example, simplifying ⁵√96 as 2⁵√3.

title: Radicals (miscellaneous videos) (Hindi)
description: Anmol simplifies sums and products of square roots. For example, he simplifies -√40+√90 as √10.

title: Introduction to polynomials (Hindi)
description: Polynomials are sums of terms of the form k⋅xⁿ, where k is any number and n is a positive integer. For example, 3x+2x-5 is a polynomial. Introduction to polynomials. This video covers common terminology like terms, degree, standard form, monomial, binomial and trinomial.

title: Zeroes of a polynomial (Hindi)
description: Evaluating 3x²-8x+7 when x=-2.

title: Long division of polynomials (Hindi)
description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding how to rewrite quotients like that is *polynomial long division*.

title: Polynomial Remainder Theorem (Hindi)
description: The Polynomial Remainder Theorem allows us to determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a polynomial expression easily. Check it out!

title: Advanced polynomial factorization methods (Hindi)
description: Anmol factors p(x)=2x^5+x^4-2x-1 as (2x+1)(x^4-1) using grouping. Then he further factors (x^4-1) as (x^2+1)(x+1)(x-1) using the special product form of difference of squares.

title: Intro to the coordinate plane (Hindi)
description: Introduction to the coordinate plane and plotting points on the coordinate plane.

title: Coordinate plane: quadrant 1 (Hindi)
description: Anmol graphs ordered pairs, such as (8, 10) in quadrant 1 on a coordinate plane.

title: Quadrants on the coordinate plane (Hindi)
description: Learn about the 4 quadrants that make up a coordinate plane.

title: Coordinate plane: 4 quadrants (Hindi)
description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points, lines, and more.

title: Coordinate plane word problems (Hindi)
description: Anmol plots the corners of a rectangle on the first quadrant of a coordinate plane.

title: Introduction to linear equations in 2 variables (Hindi)
description: Learn about a class of equations in two variables that's called "linear equations." They are called that way because their graph is a line. These are the most basic and probably most useful equations you will ever know!

title: Graph of a Linear Equation in Two Variables (Hindi)
description: Anmol creates a graph of the linear equation 5x + 2y = 20.

title: Linear models word problems (Hindi)
description: Anmol solves a word problem about a person reading a book, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

title: Angle types (Hindi)
description: Acute angles measure less than 90 degrees.  Right angles measure 90 degrees.  Obtuse angles measure more than 90 degrees.  Learn about angles types and see examples of each.

title: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles (Hindi)
description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles, as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

title: Angles between intersecting lines (Hindi)
description: Learn about parallel lines, transversals, and the angles they form.

title: Triangle angles (Hindi)
description: Learn about the angles in a triangle and a little about exterior angles being the sum of the remote interior angles.

title: Congruence of triangles and the criteria for congruence (Hindi)
description: Anmol explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

title: Proofs of general theorems that use triangle congruence (Hindi)
description: Anmol proves that a point is the midpoint of a segment using triangle congruence.

title: Theorems concerning triangle properties (Hindi)
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Inequalities in a Triangle (Hindi)
description: Intuition behind the triangle inequality theorem.

title: Quadrilaterals (Hindi)
description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid, parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, and square.

title: Quadrilateral proofs and angles (Hindi)
description: Anmol proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: Area of Parallelogram (Hindi)
description: Learn how to find the area of a parallelogram.

title: Area of a triangle (Hindi)
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Circle basics (Hindi)
description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs.

title: Chord and Circles (Hindi)
description: Anmol proves that if a radius in a circle is drawn so it bisects a chord, then the radius is also perpendicular to that chord. The proof uses SSS congruence.

title: Points and Circles (Hindi)
description: Thinking about the distance between a point and a line. Proof that a point on an angle bisector is equidistant to the sides of the angle and a point equidistant to the sides is on an angle bisector.

title: Inscribed angles (Hindi)
description: Anmol finds a missing inscribed angle using the inscribed angle theorem.

title: Inscribed shapes problem solving (Hindi)
description: Proof showing that a triangle inscribed in a circle having a diameter as one side is a right triangle.

title: Finding the area of a triangle using Heron's formula (Hindi)
description: Using Heron's Formula to determine the area of a triangle while only knowing the lengths of the sides.

title: Surface area (Hindi)
description: Surface area is the sum of the areas of all faces (or surfaces) on a 3D shape. A cuboid has 6 rectangular faces. To find the surface area of a cuboid, add the areas of all 6 faces. We can also label the length (l), width (w), and height (h) of the prism and use the formula, SA=2lw+2lh+2hw, to find the surface area.

title: Volume of cubes and cuboids (Hindi)
description: Anmol introduces volume and compares it to length and area.  He also introduces cube units.

title: Volume of cones, cylinders, and spheres (Hindi)
description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h, and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

title: Measures of Central Tendency (Hindi)
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Probability basics (Hindi)
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a coin and rolling a die.

title: The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic (Hindi)
description: Independent realization from an ancestor's perspective

title: HCF and LCM (Hindi)
description: Find the biggest number that will divide into the given 2 numbers. This is called the GCF or greatest common factor.No worries, we'll show you how to do it.

title: Proofs related to irrational numbers (Hindi)
description: Anmol proves that the square root of 2 is an irrational number, i.e. it cannot be given as the ratio of two integers.

title: Converting fractions to repeating decimals (Hindi)
description: Learn how to rewrite 19/27 as a repeating decimal. What's a repeating decimal? THAT is a great question. This video explains.

title: Intro to polynomials (Hindi)
description: Polynomials are sums of terms of the form k⋅xⁿ, where k is any number and n is a positive integer. For example, 3x+2x-5 is a polynomial. Introduction to polynomials. This video covers common terminology like terms, degree, standard form, monomial, binomial and trinomial.

title: Finding zeros of polynomials (Hindi)
description: Anmol finds all the zeros (which is the same as the roots) of p(x)=x⁵+9x³-2x³-18x=0.

title: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs (Hindi)
description: Anmol uses the zeros of y=x^3+3x^2+x+3 to determine its corresponding graph.

title: Long division of polynomials (Hindi)
description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding how to rewrite quotients like that is *polynomial long division*.

title: Modelling real-world scenarios with linear equations (Hindi)
description: Anmol is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a truck's fuel consumption, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

title: Linear models word problems (Hindi)
description: Anmol solves a word problem about a person reading a book, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.
