title: Slope (Hindi)
description: Anmol shows how to find the slope of a line.

title: Solving equations using the elimination method (Hindi)
description: Anmol uses simple elimination to figure out how many samosas are eaten by men and women.

title: Solving systems of equations with substitution (Hindi)
description: To solve a system of equations using substitution... 1. Isolate one of the variables in one of the equations, e.g. rewrite 2x+y=3 as y=3-2x. 2. You can now express the isolated variable using the other one. *Substitute* that expression into the second equation, e.g. rewrite x+2y=5 as x+2(3-2x)=5. 3. Now you have an equation with one variable! Solve it, and use what you got to find the other variable.

title: Number of solutions to systems of equations (Hindi)
description: Anmol gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

title: Systems of equations word problems (Hindi)
description: Anmol solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

title: Solving quadratics in factored form (Hindi)
description: The zero product property states that if a⋅b=0 then either a or b equal zero. This basic property helps us solve equations like (x+2)(x-5)=0.

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots (Hindi)
description: Anmol solves the equation 2x^2+3=75 by isolating x^2 and taking the square root of both sides.

title: Solving quadratics by factoring (Hindi)
description: Sal solves the equation s^2-2s-35=0 by factoring the expression on the left as (s+5)(s-7) and finding the s-values that make each factor equal to zero.

title: Solving quadratics by completing the square (Hindi)
description: Some quadratic expressions can be factored as perfect squares. For example, x²+6x+9=(x+3)². However, even if an expression isn't a perfect square, we can turn it into one by adding a constant number. For example, x²+6x+5 isn't a perfect square, but if we add 4 we get (x+3)². This, in essence, is the method of *completing the square*.

title: Solving quadratics using the quadratic formula (Hindi)
description: With the quadratic formula, we can solve any quadratic equation! Learn how to use it with an example.

title: Intro to arithmetic progressions (Hindi)
description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms"), like 2,5,8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example, 2,5,8 follows the pattern "add 3," and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example, 2,5,8,... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Constructing arithmetic progressions (Hindi)
description: Anmol finds explicit formulas of arithmetic sequences given the first few terms of those sequences. He also explores equivalent forms of such formulas.

title: Basic sigma notation (Hindi)
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Sum to n terms of an arithmetic progression (Hindi)
description: Anmol explains the formula for the sum of a finite arithmetic series.

title: Definitions of similarity (Hindi)
description: Anmol is given pairs of polygons, and then he determines whether they are similar by trying to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations.

title: Introduction to triangle similarity (Hindi)
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar, and how this follows from the definition of similarity.

title: Solving similar triangles (Hindi)
description: Anmol solves two problems where a missing side length is found by proving that triangles are similar and using this to find the measure.

title: Solving problems with similar and congruent triangles (Hindi)
description: Anmol uses the similarity of triangles and the congruence of others in this multi-step problem to find the area of a polygon.

title: Solving modeling problems with similar and congruent triangles (Hindi)
description: Triangle similarity, the Golden ratio, and art, all converge in this inspiring video!

title: Distance formula (Hindi)
description: Anmol finds the distance between two points with the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Dividing Line segments: section formula (Hindi)
description: Watch Anmol figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio. A graph is given to make it easier to visualize the problem.

title: Midpoint formula (Hindi)
description: Learn how to use the midpoint formula to find the midpoint of a line segment on the coordinate plane, or find the endpoint of a line segment given one point and the midpoint.

title: Problem solving with distance on the coordinate plane (Hindi)
description: Anmol finds the area of a trapezoid using the distance formula and the trapezoid area formula.

title: Introduction to Trigonometric ratios (Hindi)
description: Anmol introduces sine, cosine, and tangent (abbreviated as sin, cos and tan) and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle. He also shows how change in sides lead to change in the values of trigonometric ratios.

title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios (Hindi)
description: Anmol is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.

title: The reciprocal trigonometric ratios (Hindi)
description: Anmol finds all six trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent, secant, cosecant, and cotangent) of an angle in a given right triangle.

title: Trigonometric ratios and similarity (Hindi)
description: Anmol explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Trigonometric ratios of complementary angles (Hindi)
description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Trigonometric ratios of special triangles (Hindi)
description: Learn how to get a right-angled triangle with 45 degrees in it and the find the trigonometric ratios of 45 degrees.

title: Trigonometric Identities (Hindi)
description: Anmol introduces and proves the identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1, which arises from the Pythagorean theorem!

title: Heights and distances (Hindi)
description: A typical problem involving the application of trigonometry (Heights and DIstances) is solved here using basic trigonometric ratios.

title: Tangent to a Circle (Hindi)
description: Anmol proves that the radius that connects the intersection point of a tangent line with the circle is perpendicular to the tangent line.

title: Circle basics (Hindi)
description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs.

title: Arc measure (Hindi)
description: Anmol introduces arc measure including that they must sum to 360, conventions of minor and major arcs, and a comparison to arc length.

title: Arc length (degrees) (Hindi)
description: Finding the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.

title: Introduction to radians (Hindi)
description: Anmol explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: Arc length (radians) (Hindi)
description: Anmol finds the fraction of an arc length out of the entire circumference using the radian measure of the central angle subtended by the arc.

title: Sectors (Hindi)
description: Anmol finds the area of a semicircle and the arc length of a partial circle.

title: Area of combination of figures (Hindi)
description: Learn how to find the circumference, the distance around a circle, when given the area.

title: Probability basics (Hindi)
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a coin and rolling a die.

title: Intersection and union of sets (Hindi)
description: This video shows examples of intersection and union of sets and introduces some set notation.

title: Types of sets (Hindi)
description: This video explains the difference between a subset, a strict subset, and a superset. He also explains the notation behind these ideas.

title: Operations on sets (Hindi)
description: This video shows an example finding the relative complement or difference of two sets A and B.

title: Evaluating functions (Hindi)
description: Functions assign a single unique output for each of their inputs. In this video, we see examples of various kinds of functions.

title: Inputs and outputs of a function (Hindi)
description: Find the input value for which g(t)=-7 given the equation for g.

title: Interpreting function notation (Hindi)
description: Learn how to interpret expressions that contain a function within a real-world context. In this video, the function we interpret models the number of people living on a particular floor of a tower.

title: Functions and equations (Hindi)
description: Equations and functions are not the same thing, but they can be related in several ways. This video explains the difference between equations and functions.

title: Introduction to the domain and range of a function (Hindi)
description: Introducing intervals, which are bounded sets of numbers and are very useful when describing domain and range.

title: Determining the domain of a function (Hindi)
description: Finding the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).

title: Recognizing functions (Hindi)
description: Checking whether a given set of points can represent a function. For the set to represent a function, each domain element must have one corresponding range element at most.

title: Maximum and minimum points (Hindi)
description: This video explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing (Hindi)
description: Function values can be positive or negative, and they can increase or decrease as the input increases. Here we introduce these basic properties of functions.

title: Interpreting features of graphs (Hindi)
description: When a function models a real-world context, we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video, we consider a graph that models temperature over time.

title: Combining functions (Hindi)
description: Given that f(x)=9-x^2 and g(x)=5x^2+2x+1, Sal finds (f+g)(x).

title: Piecewise functions (Hindi)
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. Some functions have simple rules. However, there can be other rules that are more elaborate. These are called piecewise functions, because their rules aren't uniform, but consist of multiple pieces.

title: Determining the domain of advanced functions (Hindi)
description: This video covers many different kinds of functions and shows how to determine their domain.

title: Introduction to logarithms (Hindi)
description: This video explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.

title: The constant e and the natural logarithm (Hindi)
description: We introduce a very special number in the world of math (and beyond!), the constant 𝑒.

title: Properties of logarithms (Hindi)
description: This video introduces the logarithm identities for addition and subtraction of logarithms.

title: Change of base formula for logarithms (Hindi)
description: We approximate log₅(100) by rewriting it as log(100)/log(5) using the change of base rule, then evaluate with a calculator.

title: Exponential equations: logarithms (Hindi)
description: We solve the equation 10^(2t-3)=7.

title: Solving exponential models (Hindi)
description: We solve an exponential equation in order to answer a question about an exponential model.

title: Intro to radians (Hindi)
description: This video explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: Trigonometric values of special angles (Hindi)
description: Lets find the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.

title: Trigonometric functions (Hindi)
description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine, cosine, and tangent for all real numbers.

title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent (Hindi)
description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).

title: Trigonometric identities (Hindi)
description: In this video, we'll find several trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.

title: Trigonometric equations (Hindi)
description: Lets solve the equations cos(θ)=1 and cos(θ)=-1 using the graph of y=cos(θ).

title: What are the imaginary numbers? (Hindi)
description: Let's get to know the imaginary unit i, which is defined by the equation i^2=-1. We believe that we can get to know this special number better by thinking about its powers.

title: What are the complex numbers? (Hindi)
description: We explain how we obtain complex numbers by adding real numbers and imaginary numbers.

title: The complex plane (Hindi)
description: This video shows how to plot various numbers on the complex plane.

title: Adding & subtracting complex numbers (Hindi)
description: Let's add (5+2i) and (3-7i).

title: Multiplying complex numbers (Hindi)
description: Let's multiply(1-3i) by (2+5i).

title: Complex conjugates & dividing complex numbers (Hindi)
description: This video explains what is the conjugate of a complex number, and shows how the product of a complex number and its conjugate is always a real number.

title: Absolute value & angle of complex numbers (Hindi)
description: Let's find the absolute value of (3-4i).

title: Distance & midpoint of complex numbers (Hindi)
description: We find the distance between (2+3i) and (-5-i) and then he finds their midpoint on the complex plane.

title: Polar form of complex numbers (Hindi)
description: We rewrite the complex number -3+2i (which is given in rectangular form) in its polar form.

title: Multiplying & dividing complex numbers in polar form (Hindi)
description: This video shows how complex division affects the modulus and the argument of the divisor and the dividend.

title: Introduction to inequalities with variables (Hindi)
description: To plot an inequality, such as x is greater than 3, on a number line, first draw a circle over the number e.g., 3. Then if the sign includes equal to, fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to leave the circle unfilled in. Finally, draw a line going from the circle in the direction of the numbers that make the inequality true.

title: One-step inequalities (Hindi)
description: In addition to solving the inequality, we'll graph the solution. Remember to swap if you multiply both sides of the inequality by a negative number.

title: Two-step inequalities (Hindi)
description: Two-step inequalities are slightly more complicated than one-step inequalities duh!. This is a worked example.

title: Multi-step inequalities (Hindi)
description: We solve the inequality, draws the solution on a number line and check a few values to verify the solution.

title: Compound inequalities (Hindi)
description: We'll solve a compound inequality that involves OR

title: Checking solutions of two-variable inequalities (Hindi)
description: We check if the ordered pairs (3,5) and (1,-7) are solutions of the given inequality.

title: Constraining solutions of two-variable inequalities (Hindi)
description: We determine which x-values make the ordered pair (x,-7) a solution of an inequality, both algebraically and graphically.

title: Graphing two-variable inequalities (Hindi)
description: Learn how to graph two-variable linear inequalities.

title: x-intercepts and y-intercepts (Hindi)
description: Learn what x- and y-intercepts are. The equations used in this video are y = 0.5x - 3 and 5x + 6y = 30.

title: Slope (Hindi)
description: Before we dive into the world of derivatives, let's explore one of the most important concept that would be used here - Slope.

title: Horizontal & vertical lines (Hindi)
description: When two points have the same y-value, it means they lie on a horizontal line. The slope of such a line is 0, and you will also find this by using the slope formula.

title: Intro to slope-intercept form (Hindi)
description: Slope-intercept form, y=mx+b, of linear equations, emphasizes the slope and the y-intercept of the line. Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Graphing slope-intercept equations (Hindi)
description: To graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form, we can use the information given by that form. For example, y=2x+3 tells us that the slope of the line is 2 and the y-intercept is at (0,3). This gives us one point the line goes through, and the direction we should continue from that point to draw the entire line.

title: Parallel and perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane (Hindi)
description: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Equations of parallel and perpendicular lines (Hindi)
description: The slopes of parallel lines are equal, and the slopes of perpendicular lines are opposite reciprocals. This is a worked example of determining whether given lines are parallel or perpendicular.

title: Writing slope-intercept equations (Hindi)
description: Learn to write equations in slope-intercept form for three different lines.

title: Limits introduction (Hindi)
description: A limit tells us the value that a function approaches as that function’s inputs get closer and closer to some number. The idea of a limit is the basis of all calculus.

title: Limits from tables (Hindi)
description: We'll find the limit of 3sin(5x)/sin(2x) at x=0 using a table of values.

title: Limits from graphs (Hindi)
description: We'll find the limit of a function given its graph. The function isn't defined at the limiting value but that doesn't mean the limit doesn't exist!

title: One-sided limits (Hindi)
description: A one-sided limit is the value the function approaches as the x-values approach the limit from *one side only*. For example, f(x)=|x|/x returns -1 for negative numbers, 1 for positive numbers, and isn't defined for 0. The one-sided *right* limit of f at x=0 is 1, and the one-sided *left* limit at x=0 is -1.

title: One-sided vs. Two-sided limits (Hindi)
description: This video explains the relationship between the 1-sided limits and the 2-sided limit of a function at a point, using a graphical example where the 1-sided limits exist but the 2-sided limit doesn't.

title: Limits from equations (direct substitution) (Hindi)
description: This video explains how you can easily find limits of functions at points where the functions are continuous: simply plug in the x-value into the function! Later we will learn how to find limits even when the function isn't continuous.

title: Limits from equations (factoring & rationalizing) (Hindi)
description: We'll find the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) at x=2 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Squeeze theorem (Hindi)
description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers, and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k), then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0, by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

title: Limits of trigonometric functions (Hindi)
description: We'll find the limit at θ=0 of (1-cosθ)/(2sin²θ) by rewriting the expression using the Pythagorean identity.

title: Limits of piecewise functions (Hindi)
description: What is the limit of the sum of two functions?  What about the product?

title: Limits at infinity (Hindi)
description: We find the limits at positive and negative infinity of (4x⁵-3x²+3)/(6x⁵-100x²-10).

title: Formal definition of limits (optional) (Hindi)
description: A quick reminder of what limits are, to set up for the formal definition of a limit.

title: Review: Limits from equations (Hindi)
description: There are many techniques for finding limits that apply in various conditions. It's important to know all these techniques, but it's also important to know when to apply which technique.

title: Introduction to differential calculus (Hindi)
description: Before we dive into the world of derivatives, let's explore one of the most important concept that would be used here - Slope.

title: Derivative as slope of tangent line (Hindi)
description: The derivative of a function gives us the slope of the line tangent to the function at any point on the graph. This can be used to find the equation of that tangent line.

title: Derivative as instantaneous rate of change (Hindi)
description: We'll find the average rate of change of a curve over several intervals, and use one of them to approximate the slope of a line tangent to the curve.

title: Secant lines (Hindi)
description: What is the slope of a line between two points on a curve?  This is called a "secant" line.

title: Derivative as a limit (Hindi)
description: The derivative of function f at x=c is the limit of the slope of the secant line from x=c to x=c+h as h approaches 0. Symbolically, this is the limit of [f(c)-f(c+h)]/h as h→0.

title: Formal definition of derivative (Hindi)
description: This video introduces two ways of writing the limit expression for the derivative of a function at a point.

title: Using the formal definition of derivative (Hindi)
description: We'll find the limit expression for the derivative of f(x)=x² at the point x=3 and evaluate it.

title: Derivative as a function (Hindi)
description: Given the graph of a function, we'll sketch the graph of its derivative.

title: Basic differentiation rules (Hindi)
description: We introduce the Constant rule, which says that the derivative of f(x)=k (for any constant k) is f'(x)=0. We also justify this rule algebraically.

title: Power rule (Hindi)
description: We introduce the power rule, which tells us how to find the derivative of xⁿ.

title: Polynomial functions differentiation (Hindi)
description: Once you know how to take the derivative of x^n, it turns out you can take the derivative of any polynomial.  Let's see why...

title: Rational functions differentiation (intro) (Hindi)
description: We'll differentiate g(x)=2/(x³)-1/(x²), and evaluate the derivative at x=2. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Radical functions differentiation (intro) (Hindi)
description: We'll differentiate h(x)=5x^¼+7, and evaluates the derivative at x=16. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Sine & cosine, eˣ and ln(x) derivatives (Hindi)
description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Product rule (Hindi)
description: Introduction to the product rule, which tells us how to take the derivative of a product of functions.

description: A line plot is a graph that displays data using a number line. To create a line plot, ​first create a number line that includes all the values in the data set. Next, place an X (or dot) above each data value on the number line. If a value occurs more than once in a data set, place ​an Xs​ over that number for each time it occurs.

description: Percent means per-hundred.  Use that knowledge to solve problems like what percent of 16 is 4?

description: It's nice to practice conversion problems, but how about applying our new knowledge of percentages to a real life problem like recycling? Hint: don't forget your long division!

title: Adding decimals
description: Sal solves 9.087+15.31 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Subtracting decimals
description: Just like when add, be sure you align decimals before subtracting.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems
description: Here's a simple word problem asking us to put our adding decimals skill to work.

title: Multiplying decimals
description: Sal introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.

title: Dividing whole numbers
description: Learn to divide 9815÷65.  The answer does not have a remainder.

title: Dividing decimals
description: Sal divides 63÷35.

title: Dividing fractions by fractions
description: Using a number line, we'll explain why multiplying by the inverse is the same as dividing.

title: Exponents
description: Sal shows how exponents are repeated multiplication

title: Order of operations
description: This example shows the steps and clarifies the purpose of order of operations: to have ONE way to interpret a mathematical statement.

title: Intro to negative numbers
description: Mysterious negative numbers! What ARE they? They are numbers less than zero. If you understand the nature of below zero temperatures, you can understand negative numbers. We'll help.

title: Negative decimals & fractions on the number line
description: These example exercises require us to interpret a number line in order to locate where our positive and negative decimals should be placed.

title: Number opposites
description: Learn about number opposites like 3 and -3 or -4 and 4 using a number line.

title: Comparing negative numbers
description: Sal puts -25, -30, -7, -10, and -40 in order from least to greatest.

title: Negative symbol as opposite
description: Sal explains more challenging opposites like -(-3).

title: Absolute value
description: Learn how to find the absolute value of 5, -10, and 12.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Coordinate plane
description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points, lines, and more.

title: Least common multiple
description: Sal finds the LCM (least common multiple) of 12 and 36, and of 12 and 18. He shows how to do that using the prime factorization method, which is a just great!

title: Greatest common factor
description: Find the biggest number that will divide into the given 2 numbers. This is called the GCF or greatest common factor.No worries, we'll show you how to do it.

title: Parts of algebraic expressions
description: Our focus here is understanding that a variable is just a symbol that can represent different values in an expression. We got this. Just watch.

title: Substitution & evaluating expressions
description: Learn how to evaluate an expression with variables using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Expression value intuition
description: Explore how the values of algebraic expressions like 100-x, 5/x + 5, and (3y)/(2y) change as the values of the variables change.

title: Evaluating expressions word problems
description: In this example we have a formula for converting Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit. Let's substitute the variable with a value (Celsius temp) to get the degrees in Fahrenheit. Great problem to practice with us!
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Writing algebraic expressions introduction
description: Sal writes an expression to represent 11 more than a.

title: Writing basic algebraic expressions word problems
description: Learn how to write basic expressions with variables to describe situations described in word problems.

title: Distributive property with variables
description: Learn how to apply the distributive law of multiplication over addition and why it works. This is sometimes just called the distributive law or the distributive property.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Combining like terms
description: In simple addition we learned to add all the numbers together to get a sum. In algebra, numbers are sometimes attached to variables and we need to make sure that the variables are alike before we add the numbers.

title: Equivalent expressions
description: Sal finds equivalent expressions by combining like terms and using the distributive property.

title: Algebraic equations basics
description: Learn what variables, expressions, and equations are.

title: One-step equations intuition
description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.

title: One-step addition & subtraction equations
description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.

title: One-step multiplication and division equations
description: Let's ease into this, shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!

title: Finding mistakes in one-step equations
description: Learn how to spot mistakes in someone else's work as they attempt to solve one-step equations.

title: One-step equation word problems
description: Learn how to write basic equations to model real-world situations.

title: Intro to inequalities with variables
description: A solution to an inequality makes that inequality true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an inequality true.

title: Dependent and independent variables
description: Identifying the dependent and the independent variables in a word problem.

title: Areas of parallelograms
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a parallelogram is base times height, just like the formula for the area of a rectangle.

title: Areas of triangles
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Area of composite figures
description: Sometimes it helps to rearrange the parts of geometric figures to find the area. That's what we're going to do here.

title: Volume with fractions
description: Another way of finding the volume of a rectangular prism involves dividing it into fractional cubes, finding the volume of one, and then multiplying that volume by the number of cubes that fit into our rectangular prism.

title: Surface area
description: Admittedly, "nets of polyhedra" sounds like the title of a bad sci-fi movie about man-eating, multi-headed fish. But in reality, nets of polyhedra are just 2D objects that wrap around 3D objects, like wrapping paper around presents.

title: Polygons on the coordinate plane
description: Sal draws a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane using the coordinates of its vertices.

title: Dot plots & frequency tables
description: Here are a few of the many ways to look at data. Which is your favorite?

title: Statistical questions
description: What makes a question a "statistical question"?

title: Histograms
description: A histogram is a graphical display of data using bars of different heights. In a histogram, each bar groups numbers into ranges. Taller bars show that more data falls in that range. A histogram displays the shape and spread of continuous sample data.

title: Mean and median
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Mean and median challenge problems
description: Learn how to find the value of a missing piece of data if you know the mean of the data set.

title: Interquartile range (IQR)
description: The IQR describes the middle 50% of values when ordered from lowest to highest. To find the interquartile range (IQR), ​first find the median (middle value) of the lower and upper half of the data. These values are quartile 1 (Q1) and quartile 3 (Q3). The IQR is the difference between Q3 and Q1.

title: Box plots
description: Is this some kind of cute cat video? No! Box and whisker plots seek to explain data by showing a spread of all the data points in a sample. The "whiskers" are the two opposite ends of the data. This video is more fun than a handful of catnip.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Mean absolute deviation (MAD)
description: Mean absolute deviation (MAD) of a data set is the average distance between each data value and the mean. Mean absolute deviation is a way to describe variation in a data set. Mean absolute deviation helps us get a sense of how "spread out" the values in a data set are.

title: Comparing data displays
description: Sal solves practice problems where he thinks about which data displays would be helpful in which situations.

title: Shape of data distributions
description: Some distributions are symmetrical, with data evenly distributed about the mean. Other distributions are "skewed," with data tending to the left or right of the mean. We sometimes say that skewed distributions have "tails."

title: Intro to adding negative numbers
description: Use a number line to add -15 + (-46) + (-29)
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Intro to subtracting negative numbers
description: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers. The problems solved in this video are 2 - 3 = -1 and -2 - 3 = -5 and -2 + 3 = 1 and 2 - (-3) = 5 and -2 - (-3).

title: Adding & subtracting with negatives on the number line
description: Sal shows how to model 6 + (-2) using vertical number lines.

title: Adding & subtracting integers
description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding & subtracting negative fractions
description: Use a number line to add fractions with different signs.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Addition & subtraction word problems with negatives
description: The examples in this video use negative numbers to represent real world situations. What are these negative numbers really telling us?

title: Absolute value
description: In this video, we think about what |a-b| really means, and we verify that |a-b| = |b-a| by looking at an example.

title: Properties of addition & subtraction
description: Equivalent expressions with negative numbers

title: Adding & subtracting negative numbers: variables
description: Practice substituting positive and negative values for variables.

title: Multiply & divide negative numbers
description: Learn some rules of thumb for multiplying positive and negative numbers.

title: Multiplication & division word problems with negatives
description: Let's think about the meaning of negative numbers in different situations.

title: Understanding multiplying and dividing fractions
description: Sal finds equivalent expressions to -g/h.

title: Multiply & divide negative fractions
description: See examples of multiplying and dividing fractions with negative numbers.

title: Order of operations
description: This example shows the steps and clarifies the purpose of order of operations: to have ONE way to interpret a mathematical statement.

title: Properties of multiplication & division
description: In this video, we figure out whether or not some expressions are equivalent. To do this, we think about properties of multiplication and division.

title: Converting fractions to decimals
description: Here's an example of how we convert a decimal to a simplified fraction. Over time this will become second nature to you.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding & subtracting rational numbers
description: Comparing Rational Numbers

title: Percent word problems
description: We'll use algebra to solve this percent problem.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Rational number word problems
description: First visualize this word problem then use subtraction and multiplication of decimals and fractions to get at the answer.

title: Rate problems with fractions
description: Sal solves an example problem with rates with fractions.

title: Constant of proportionality
description: Sal identifies the constant of proportionality from a line graphed on a coordinate plane.

title: Identifying proportional relationships
description: Sal introduces the idea of a proportional relationship by looking at tables of values.

title: Graphs of proportional relationships
description: Learn how to tell proportional relationships by drawing graphs. Key idea: the graph of a proportional relationship is a straight line through the origin.

title: Writing & solving proportions
description: Learn the reasoning behind solving proportions. We'll put some algebra to work to get our answers, too.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Equations of proportional relationships
description: Learn how to write a proportional equation y=kx where k is the so-called "constant of proportionality".

title: Combining like terms
description: In simple addition we learned to add all the numbers together to get a sum. In algebra, numbers are sometimes attached to variables and we need to make sure that the variables are alike before we add the numbers.

title: The distributive property & equivalent expressions
description: Learn how to apply the distributive property to factor out the greatest common factor from an algebraic expression like 2+4x.

title: Interpreting linear expressions
description: We match the expressions to their meaning in this example. We're reinforcing our knowledge of linear expressions.

title: Two-step equations intro
description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.

title: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions
description: Learn how to solve equations that involve decimals and fractions. The equations shown in this video are called "two-step" equations because they each take two steps to solve.

title: Two-step equation word problems
description: Using information from the Super Yoga word problem, explore all the possible combinations and create equations which express the possibilities. Let's figure out which plan is best!

title: One-step inequalities
description: To plot an inequality, such as x>3, on a number line, first draw a circle over the number (e.g., 3). Then if the sign includes equal to (≥ or ≤), fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to (> or <), leave the circle unfilled in. Finally, draw a line going from the circle in the direction of the numbers that make the inequality true.

title: Two-step inequalities
description: Two-step inequalities are slightly more complicated than one-step inequalities (duh!). This is a worked example of solving ⅔>-4y-8⅓.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Area and circumference of circles
description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

title: Area and circumference challenge problems
description: Learn how to find the circumference, the distance around a circle, when given the area.

title: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles
description: Two rays that share the same endpoint form an angle. Learn about angles and the parts of an angle, like the vertex.

title: Missing angle problems
description: Given two intersecting lines and the measure of vertical angles, watch as we solve to find the measure of the remaining angles.

title: Constructing triangles
description: Can you build a triangle that is both a right triangle and an isosceles triangle?

title: Slicing geometric shapes
description: What happens when you slice vertically into a rectangular pyramid? What kind of geometric shape results?

title: Scale drawings
description: Sal uses virtual manipulatives to identify figures that scale proportionally.

title: Volume and surface area word problems
description: See if you can find the incremental volume of a ring in cubic inches. You'll need to put to use your knowledge of how to measure volume.

title: Basic probability
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Probability models
description: Compare expected probabilities to what really happens when we run experiments.

title: Compound events and sample spaces
description: Explore the notion of a "sample space". See a sample space represented as a tree diagram, table, and list.

title: Comparing and sampling populations
description: To make a valid conclusion, you'll need a representaive, not skewed, sample.

title: Repeating decimals
description: Learn how to rewrite 19/27 as a repeating decimal. What's a repeating decimal? THAT is a great question. This video explains.

title: Square roots & cube roots
description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Irrational numbers
description: Learn what rational and irrational numbers are and how to tell them apart.

title: Approximating irrational numbers
description: Learn how to find the approximate values of square roots. The examples used in this video are √32, √55, and √123. The technique used is to compare the squares of whole numbers to the number we're taking the square root of.

title: Exponents with negative bases
description: Learn to what we know about negative numbers to determine how negative bases with exponents are affected and what patterns develop. Also learn how order of operations affect the pattern.

title: Exponent properties intro
description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video, we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Negative exponents
description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with negative exponents as fractions with positive exponents.

title: Working with powers of 10
description: Learn how to multiply (9 * 10^9) (-2 * 10^-3).

title: Scientific notation intro
description: Can you imagine if you had to do calculations with very, very small numbers? How would you handle all those zeros to the right of the decimal? Thank goodness for scientific notation!
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Arithmetic with numbers in scientific notation
description: Learn how to simplify a multiplication and division expression using scientific notation. The expression in this problem is (7 * 10^5) / ((2 * 10^-2)(2.5 * 10^9)).

title: Scientific notation word problems
description: Vampires and math students want to know: How many red blood cells are in the a human body? We can find the answer using scientific notation.

title: Equations with variables on both sides
description: Worked example: Learn to solve the equation 2x + 3 = 5x - 2.

title: Equations with parentheses
description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Number of solutions to equations
description: See how some equations have one solution, others have no solutions, and still others have infinite solutions.

title: Equations word problems
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: The sum of 4 consecutive odd integers is 136. What are the 4 integers?

title: Graphing proportional relationships
description: Sal compares a rate given in an equation to a rate shown on a graph.

title: Solutions to linear equations
description: Bridging algebra and geometry. What makes linear equations so linear.

title: Intercepts
description: Learn what x- and y-intercepts are.  The equations used in this video are y = 0.5x - 3 and 5x + 6y = 30.

title: Slope
description: Sal shows how to find the slope of a line.

title: Intro to slope-intercept form
description: Slope-intercept form, y=mx+b, of linear equations, emphasizes the slope and the y-intercept of the line. Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Graphing slope-intercept form
description: To graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form, we can use the information given by that form. For example, y=2x+3 tells us that the slope of the line is 2 and the y-intercept is at (0,3). This gives us one point the line goes through, and the direction we should continue from that point to draw the entire line.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Writing slope-intercept equations
description: Learn to write equations in slope-intercept form for three different lines.

title: Functions
description: Functions assign a single output for each of their inputs. In this video, we see examples of various kinds of functions.

title: Linear models
description: Sal discusses how we would go about making sense of the direction of a linear graph that represents a relationship between two real-world quantities.

title: Comparing linear functions
description: Sal is given the formula of a linear function and the graph of another, and is asked to determine which function increases faster.

title: Constructing linear models for real-world relationships
description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a truck's fuel consumption, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

title: Recognizing functions
description: Learn to determine if points on a graph represent a function.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Linear and nonlinear functions
description: Learn to recognize if a function is linear.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Intro to systems of equations
description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Systems of equations with graphing
description: Sal shows how to solve a system of linear equations by graphing and looking for the point of intersection.

title: Solving systems with substitution
description: Learn to use substitution to solve the system of equations 2y = x + 7 and x = y - 4.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Number of solutions to systems of equations
description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

title: Systems of equations word problems
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

title: Angles between intersecting lines
description: Learn about parallel lines, transversals, and the angles they form.

title: Triangle angles
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Pythagorean theorem and distance between points
description: Learn how to find the distance between two points by using the distance formula, which is an application of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Pythagorean theorem proofs
description: James Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean Theorem.

title: Volume
description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h, and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

title: Transformations intro
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Congruence and similarity
description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are congruent by mapping one onto the other using rigid transformations.

title: Introduction to scatter plots
description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

title: Interpreting scatter plots
description: Sal answers a question about scatter plots that show the relationship between study time, shoe size, and test score.

title: Estimating lines of best fit
description: Sal solves a problem where he has to estimate the line of best fit for a scatter plot.

title: Two-way tables
description: Sal uses a Venn diagram to introduce two-way frequency tables.

title: Basic addition and subtraction
description: Introduction to addition. Learn multiple visual ways to represent addition.

title: Addition and subtraction within 20
description: Sal adds 8 + 7 by making a group of ten.

title: Strategies for adding and subtracting within 100
description: Sal adds 53+17 by breaking apart the numbers and making a group of 10.

title: Addition within 100
description: Sal adds 23 + 45 thinking about place value.

title: Subtraction within 100
description: Sal subtracts 23 from 65 by thinking about tens and ones.

title: Word problems within 100
description: Sal solves a 2-step subtraction word problem with numbers less than 100.

title: Multi-digit addition with regrouping
description: Learn to use regrouping to add 536+398.

title: Multi-digit subtraction with regrouping
description: Learn to use regrouping (borrowing) and place value to subtract 971-659.

title: Multiplication intro
description: Sal uses arrays and repeated addition to visualize multiplication.

title: Multiplication: place value and area models
description: Sal uses place value, the distributive property, associative property, and an area model to show more ways to multiply.

title: Multi-digit multiplication
description: Learn to multiply a 2-digit number by a 1-digit number without regrouping.  In this video, we will multiply 32x3.

title: Division intro
description: Sal uses an array and understanding of multiplication to divide.

title: Division: place value and area
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to divide 5600÷8 and 846÷2.

title: Multi-digit division (no remainders)
description: Watch an introduction to long division with the problem 96÷4.

title: Remainders
description: Sal shows how a remainder is what's left over in a division problem.

title: Multi-digit division (remainders)
description: Learn to divide 9815÷65.  The answer does not have a remainder.

title: Multiplication and division word problems
description: Sal solves a division word problem.

description: Mysterious negative numbers! What ARE they? They are numbers less than zero. If you understand the nature of below zero temperatures, you can understand negative numbers. We'll help.

description: Sal puts -25, -30, -7, -10, and -40 in order from least to greatest.

title: Number opposites
description: Learn about number opposites like 3 and -3 or -4 and 4 using a number line.

description: Learn how to find the absolute value of 5, -10, and 12.

title: Intro to adding negative numbers
description: Use a number line to add -15 + (-46) + (-29)

description: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers. The problems solved in this video are 2 - 3 = -1 and -2 - 3 = -5 and -2 + 3 = 1 and 2 - (-3) = 5 and -2 - (-3).

title: Adding & subtracting negative numbers
description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29

title: Multiplying & dividing negative numbers
description: Use the repeated addition model of multiplication to give an understanding of multiplying negative numbers.

title: Fractions intro

title: Fractions on the number line
description: Learn to graph and locate fractions on a number line.

title: Multiplying whole numbers and fractions
description: Sal gives a visual explanation of multiplying a fraction and a whole number.

title: Multiplying fractions

title: Multiplying mixed numbers

title: Dividing unit fractions and whole numbers

title: Dividing fractions by fractions
description: Using a number line, we'll explain why multiplying by the inverse is the same as dividing.

title: Dividing fractions word problems
description: Dividing a whole number by a fraction? Turn the tables and multiply by the reciprocal of the fraction. Boom!
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Intro to decimals
description: Sal introduces decimal numbers and understanding place value to the right of the decimal.

title: Decimals on the number line
description: Lindsay graphs 0.6 on a number line.

title: Rounding decimals
description: Learn to round 9.564 to the nearest tenth.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Comparing decimals
description: Sal compares decimals like 0.0093 and 0.01 with greater and less than symbols.

title: Rewriting decimals as fractions
description: Sal shows the connection between decimals and fractions using a grid diagram and number lines.

title: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems
description: Here's a simple word problem asking us to put our adding decimals skill to work.

title: Multiplying decimals
description: Sal introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.

title: Dividing decimals
description: Sal divides 63÷35.

title: Lines, line segments, and rays
description: Learn about geometry terms like point, line, and ray.  We will also learn how to label them.

title: Parallel and perpendicular
description: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Angle introduction
description: Two rays that share the same endpoint form an angle. Learn about angles and the parts of an angle, like the vertex.

title: Measuring and drawing angles
description: Learn how to measure an angle with a protractor.

title: Angles in circles
description: Learn to measure angles as part of a circle.

title: Angle types
description: Acute angles measure less than 90 degrees.  Right angles measure 90 degrees.  Obtuse angles measure more than 90 degrees.  Learn about angles types and see examples of each.

title: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles
description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles, as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

title: Angles between intersecting lines
description: Learn about parallel lines, transversals, and the angles they form.

title: Properties of shapes
description: Sal classifies shapes based on their number of sides, number of corners, and side-lengths.

title: Quadrilaterals
description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid, parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, and square.

title: Triangles
description: Learn to categorize triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.

title: Classifying geometric shapes
description: Sal categorizes shapes based on their sides and angles.

title: Triangle angles
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Coordinate plane: 4 quadrants
description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points, lines, and more.

title: Quadrants on the coordinate plane
description: Learn about the 4 quadrants that make up a coordinate plane.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Reflecting points on coordinate plane
description: Just like looking at a mirror image of yourself, but flipped....a reflection point is the mirror point on the opposite side of the axis. Watch this tutorial and reflect :)

title: Quadrilaterals on the coordinate plane
description: Given three of the vertices of a rectangle, can you find the fourth?

title: Drawing polygons in the coordinate plane
description: Sal draws a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane using the coordinates of its vertices.

title: Count unit squares to find area
description: Sal covers figures with square units to find their area.

title: Area of rectangles

title: Substitution method for systems of equations
description:
To solve a system of equations using substitution...
1. Isolate one of the variables in one of the equations, e.g. rewrite 2x+y=3 as y=3-2x.
2. You can now express the isolated variable using the other one. *Substitute* that expression into the second equation, e.g. rewrite x+2y=5 as x+2(3-2x)=5.
3. Now you have an equation with one variable! Solve it, and use what you got to find the other variable.
