title: Determining the domain of a function
description: Finding the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Recognizing functions
description: Checking whether a given set of points can represent a function. For the set to represent a function, each domain element must have one corresponding range element at most.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Maximum and minimum points
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing
description: Function values can be positive or negative, and they can increase or decrease as the input increases. Here we introduce these basic properties of functions.

title: Interpreting features of graphs
description: When a function models a real-world context, we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video, we consider a graph that models temperature over time.

title: Average rate of change
description: What's the average rate of change of a function over an interval?

title: Average rate of change word problems
description: Average rate of change tells us how much the function changed per a single time unit, over a specific interval. It has many real-world applications. In this video, we compare the average rate of change of temperature over different time periods.

title: Interpreting linear functions and equations
description: Sal finds the slope of a linear relationship between the number of work hours and the money earned. He then interprets what this slope means in that context.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Comparing linear functions
description: Sal is given the formula of a linear function and the graph of another, and is asked to determine which function increases faster.

title: Constructing linear models for real-world relationships
description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a truck's fuel consumption, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

title: Linear models word problems
description: Sal solves a word problem about a person reading a book, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

title: Introduction to arithmetic sequences
description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms"), like 2,5,8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example, 2,5,8 follows the pattern "add 3," and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example, 2,5,8,... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Introduction to geometric sequences
description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio.

title: Introduction to systems of equations
description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method
description: Sal uses simple elimination to figure out how many cupcakes are eaten by children and adults.

title: Solving systems of equations with substitution
description:
To solve a system of equations using substitution...
1. Isolate one of the variables in one of the equations, e.g. rewrite 2x+y=3 as y=3-2x.
2. You can now express the isolated variable using the other one. *Substitute* that expression into the second equation, e.g. rewrite x+2y=5 as x+2(3-2x)=5.
3. Now you have an equation with one variable! Solve it, and use what you got to find the other variable.

title: Number of solutions to systems of equations
description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

title: Systems of equations word problems
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

title: Checking solutions of two-variable inequalities
description: Sal checks if the ordered pairs (3,5) and (1,-7) are solutions of the inequality 5x-3y≥25.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphing two-variable inequalities
description: Learn how to graph two-variable linear inequalities like y≤4x+3.

title: Piecewise functions
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. Some functions have simple rules, like "for every x, return x²." However, there can be other rules that are more elaborate. For example, "If x<0, return 2x, and if x≥0, return 3x." These are called *piecewise functions*, because their rules aren't uniform, but consist of multiple pieces

title: Radicals
description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Rational exponents intro
description: What does it mean to take a number by a power which is a unit fraction? For example, what is the result of 3 raised to ½?

title: Advanced exponent & radical evaluation
description: Sal shows how to evaluate 64^(2/3) and (8/27)^(-2/3).

title: Simplifying square roots
description: Roots are nice, but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So, for example, instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer, like √20? Still, we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5, which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Simplifying radicals (higher-index roots)
description: Multiple examples of simplifications of higher-index radicals. For example, simplifying ⁵√96 as 2⁵√3.

title: Exponential vs. linear growth
description: In exponential functions the variable is in the exponent, like y=3ˣ. Here we introduce this concept with a few examples.

title: Graphs of exponential growth
description: Analyzing the features of exponential graphs through the example of y=5ˣ.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding & subtracting polynomials
description: Sal simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding and subtracting polynomials: two variables
description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3x² - 2y) + (8xy - 3x² + 2x²y + 4).

title: Multiplying monomials
description: Learn how to multiply monomials like 5x² * 4x⁶ or 4p³ * p.

title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials
description: Sal expresses the product (10a-3)(5a² + 7a - 1) as 50a³+55a²-31a+3.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Polynomials word problems
description: Sal finds the volume of a tank whose base has an area of 3x² + 30x + 5 square feet and whose height is 8x - 5 feet.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors
description: Sal shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).

title: Evaluating expressions with unknown variables
description: Sal solved a few examples where we need to evaluate an expression, but we don't know the individual variable values.

title: Factoring quadratics by grouping
description: Sal introduces the method of grouping, which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.

title: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms
description: Sal factors 35k^2+100k-15 as 5(k+3)(7k-1).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Factoring polynomials with special product forms
description: Sal factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+3=75 by isolating x^2 and taking the square root of both sides.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Quadratic vertex form
description: One of the common forms for quadratic functions is called vertex form, because it highlights the coordinates of the vertex of the function's graph.

title: Solving quadratics by factoring
description: Sal solves the equation s^2-2s-35=0 by factoring the expression on the left as (s+5)(s-7) and finding the s-values that make each factor equal to zero.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Completing the square
description: Some quadratic expressions can be factored as perfect squares. For example, x²+6x+9=(x+3)². However, even if an expression isn't a perfect square, we can turn it into one by adding a constant number. For example, x²+6x+5 isn't a perfect square, but if we add 4 we get (x+3)². This, in essence, is the method of *completing the square*

title: The quadratic formula
description: With the quadratic formula, we can solve any quadratic equation! Learn how to use it with an example.

title: Quadratic standard form
description: Sal rewrites the equation y=-5x^2-20x+15 in vertex form (by completing the square) in order to identify the vertex of the corresponding parabola.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Features & forms of quadratic functions
description: Different forms of quadratic functions reveal different features of those functions. Here, Sal rewrites f(x)=x²-5x+6 in factored form to reveal its zeros and in vertex form to reveal its vertex.

title: Transforming parabolas
description: Sal discusses how we can shift and scale the graph of a parabola to obtain any other parabola, and how this affects the equation of the parabola.

title: Irrational numbers
description: Learn what rational and irrational numbers are and how to tell them apart.

title: Sums and products of rational and irrational numbers
description: Sal proves that the sum, or the product, of any two rational numbers will always be a rational number.

title: Proofs concerning irrational numbers
description: Sal proves that the square root of 2 is an irrational number, i.e. it cannot be given as the ratio of two integers.

title: Intro to Euclidean geometry
description: Euclid was a great mathematician and often called the father of geometry.  Learn more about Euclid and how some of our math concepts came about and how influential they have become.

title: Angles
description: Learn how to measure an angle with a protractor.

title: Polygons
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Area
description: Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape. Area measures the space inside a shape. Learn how to calculate perimeter and area for various shapes.

title: Introduction to rigid transformations
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Symmetry
description: Introduction to the concept of an "axis of symmetry"

title: Transformations & congruence
description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are congruent by mapping one onto the other using rigid transformations.

title: Triangle congruence
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

title: Theorems concerning triangle properties
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Working with triangles
description: We write the letters of congruent triangles so their order tells us which parts are corresponding. In this video, Sal uses this notation to solve some angles.

title: Theorems concerning quadrilateral properties
description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: Proofs of general theorems that use triangle congruence
description: Sal proves that a point is the midpoint of a segment using triangle congruence.

title: Constructing bisectors of lines & angles
description: Sal constructs a perpendicular bisector to a given line segment using compass and straightedge.

title: Definitions of similarity
description: Sal is given pairs of polygons, and then he determines whether they are similar by trying to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations.

title: Introduction to triangle similarity
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar, and how this follows from the definition of similarity.

title: Solving similar triangles
description: Sal solves two problems where a missing side length is found by proving that triangles are similar and using this to find the measure.

title: Angle bisector theorem
description: Sal introduces the angle-bisector theorem and proves it.

title: Solving problems with similar & congruent triangles
description: Sal uses the similarity of triangles and the congruence of others in this multi-step problem to find the area of a polygon.

title: Solving modeling problems with similar & congruent triangles
description: Triangle similarity, the Golden ratio, and art, all converge in this inspiring video!

title: Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Pythagorean theorem proofs
description: James Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean Theorem.

title: Special right triangles
description: Introduction to 45-45-90 Triangles

title: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal introduces sine, cosine, and tangent, and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.

title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Modeling with right triangles
description: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.

title: Trigonometric ratios & similarity
description: Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Sine & cosine of complementary angles
description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Law of sines
description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Law of cosines
description: Learn how to use the law of cosines to find the missing side length of a triangle when given two side lengths and the contained angle measure.

title: Solving general triangles
description: Sal solves a word problem about the distance between stars using the law of cosines.

title: Solid geometry intro
description: Using the formulas for the volume of triangular prism and cube to solve some solid geometry problems.

title: Density
description: Sal solves a word problem about the number of passengers a blimp can carry, using his knowledge of volume and density.

title: 2D vs. 3D objects
description: What happens when you slice vertically into a rectangular pyramid? What kind of geometric shape results?

title: Distance and midpoints
description: Learn how to find the distance between two points by using the distance formula, which is an application of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Dividing line segments
description: Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio. A graph is given to make it easier to visualize the problem.

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane
description: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Circle basics
description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs

title: Arc length (degrees)
description: Finding the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: Arc length (radians)
description: Sal finds the fraction of an arc length out of the entire circumference using the radian measure of the central angle subtended by the arc.

title: Sectors
description: A worked example of finding the area of a circle's sector using the area of the circle and the central angle of the sector.

title: Standard equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Expanded equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.

title: Constructing regular polygons inscribed in circles
description: Sal constructs a square that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Constructing circumcircles & incircles
description: Sal constructs a circle that inscribes a given triangle using compass and straightedge.

title: Constructing a line tangent to a circle
description: Sal constructs a line tangent to a circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Combining functions
description: Given that f(x)=9-x^2 and g(x)=5x^2+2x+1, Sal finds (f+g)(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Composing functions
description: Sal explains what it means to compose two functions. He gives examples for finding the values of composite functions given the equations, the graphs, or tables of values of the two composed functions.

title: Modeling situations by combining and composing functions
description: Sal models the height of a tower on top of a tree, by adding the functions that model the growth of the tower and the tree separately.

title: Stretching functions
description: Sal walks through several examples of how to write g(x) implicitly in terms of f(x) when g(x) is a shift or a reflection of f(x).

title: Introduction to inverses of functions
description: Sal explains what inverse functions are. Then he explains how to algebraically find the inverse of a function and looks at the graphical relationship between inverse functions.

title: Finding inverse functions
description: Sal finds the inverses of f(x)=-x+4 and g(x)=-2x-1.

title: What are the imaginary numbers?
description: Sal introduces the imaginary unit i, which is defined by the equation i^2=-1. He then gets to know this special number better by thinking about its powers.

title: What are the complex numbers?
description: Sal explains how we obtain complex numbers by adding real numbers and imaginary numbers.

title: The complex plane
description: Sal shows how to plot various numbers on the complex plane.

title: Adding and subtracting complex numbers
description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multiplying complex numbers
description: Sal multiplies (1-3i) by (2+5i).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding and subtracting polynomials
description: Sal simplifies (x³ + 3x - 6) + (-2x² + x - 2) - (3x - 4).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multiplying polynomials
description: Sal expresses the product (10a-3)(5a² + 7a - 1) as 50a³+55a²-31a+3.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Long division of polynomials
description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding how to rewrite quotients like that is *polynomial long division*.

title: Synthetic division of polynomials
description: Sal shows how synthetic division of polynomials works.

title: Practice dividing polynomials with remainders
description: Sal divides (18x^4-3x^2+6x-4) by 6x.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Polynomial Remainder Theorem
description: The Polynomial Remainder Theorem allows us to determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a polynomial expression easily. Check it out!

title: The binomial theorem
description: Sal explains what's the binomial theorem, why it's useful, and how to use it.

title: Understanding the binomial theorem
description: Sal explains why we use the combinatorial formula for (n choose k) to expand binomial expressions.

title: Factoring polynomials - Quadratic forms
description: Sal factors x^2-14x+40 as (x-4)(x-10) and x^2-x-12 as (x+3)(x-4).

title: Factoring polynomials - Special product forms
description: If we expand (a+b)(a-b) we will get a²-b². Factorization goes the other way: suppose we have an expression that is the difference of two squares, like x²-25 or 49x²-y², then we can factor is using the roots of those squares. For example, x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This is an extremely useful method that is used throughout math.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Advanced polynomial factorization methods
description: Sal factors p(x)=2x^5+x^4-2x-1 as (2x+1)(x^4-1) using grouping. Then he further factors (x^4-1) as (x^2+1)(x+1)(x-1) using the special product form of difference of squares.

title: Proving polynomial identities
description: Sal considers two cases of polynomial identities and their proofs.

title: Polynomial identities with complex numbers
description: Learn how expressions of the form x^2+y^2 can be factored into linear factors. This would not be possible without the aid of complex numbers!

title: Quadratic equations with complex numbers
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+5=6x using the quadratic formula, and finds that the solutions are complex numbers.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: The Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
description: Sal introduces the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, which, as is reflected in its name, is a very important theorem about polynomials.

title: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs
description: Sal uses the zeros of y=x^3+3x^2+x+3 to determine its corresponding graph.

title: End behavior of polynomial functions
description: Sal explains what "end behavior" is and what affects the end behavior of polynomial functions.

title: Introduction to symmetry of functions
description: Sal explains what it means for a function to be even, odd, or neither, both algebraically and graphically.

title: Solving square-root equations
description: Sal explains what square-root equations are, and shows an example of solving such an equation and checking for extraneous solutions.

title: Solving cube-root equations
description: Sal solves the equation -∛y=4∛y+5.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Domain of radical functions
description: Finding the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphs of radical functions
description: Sal shows various examples of functions and their graphs that are a result of shifting and/or flipping y=√x.

title: Simplifying rational expressions
description: Sal explains what it means to simplify a rational expression and why we would want to do that. Just don't forget the excluded values!

title: Nested fractions
description: Sal starts with a simple case of multiplying two fractions and proceeds to simplifying a nested fraction expression.

title: Solving rational equations
description: Sal solves the equation (14x+4)/(-3x-2)=8.

title: Direct and inverse variation
description: Sal explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.

title: Graphs of rational functions
description: Sal analyzes the function f(x)=(3x^2-18x-81)/(6x^2-54) and determines its horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities.

title: Modeling with rational functions
description: Sal solves a word problem about the unknown number of bears, cats, and dogs in a pet store. This is part 1 where Sal uses a visual reasoning.

title: Equivalent forms of exponential expressions
description: Sal simplifies the expression 10*9^(0.5t+2)*5^(3t) as 810*375^t.

title: Introduction to logarithms
description: Sal explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.

title: The constant e and the natural logarithm
description: Sal introduces a very special number in the world of math (and beyond!), the constant 𝑒.

title: Properties of logarithms
description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for addition and subtraction of logarithms.

title: The change of base formula for logarithms
description: Sal approximates log₅(100) by rewriting it as log(100)/log(5) using the change of base rule, then evaluates with a calculator.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Solving exponential equations with logarithms
description: Sal solves the equation 10^(2t-3)=7.

title: Graphs of logarithmic functions
description: Sal graphs y=2^x and y=log_2(x) on the same coordinate plane, showing how they relate as graphs of inverse functions.

title: Logarithmic scale (optional)
description: Vi Hart and Sal talk about how we humans perceive things nonlinearly

title: Introduction to radians
description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine, cosine, and tangent for all real numbers.

title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Basic trigonometric identities
description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.

title: Trigonometric values of special angles
description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.

title: The Pythagorean identity
description: Sal proves the Pythagorean identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1 for all real numbers.

title: Introduction to amplitude, midline, and extrema of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.

title: Finding amplitude and midline of sinusoidal functions from their formulas
description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Period of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphing sinusoidal functions
description: Sal graphs y=2*sin(-x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and a horizontal reflection of y=sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Constructing sinusoidal functions
description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2,-5) and the maximum point (2,1) are highlighted.

title: Systems of quadratic equations
description: Sal solves a system of a quadratic equation and a linear equation by graphing both equations and looking for their intersections, and then checks the solution algebraically.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Interpreting the symmetry of algebraic models
description: Sal interprets the significance of modeling function being even.

title: Comparing features of functions
description: Given several functions represented in different forms (as a formula, as a graph, and as a table of values), Sal finds the one with that has no x-intercepts.

title: Arithmetic sequences
description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms"), like 2,5,8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example, 2,5,8 follows the pattern "add 3," and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example, 2,5,8,... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Basic sigma notation
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Geometric sequences
description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio.

title: Finite geometric series
description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn more about it here.

title: Finite geometric series applications
description: Watch Sal solve an example of using a geometric series to answer a fun word problem.

title: Modeling with one-variable equations and inequalities
description: Sal models a context that concerns the number and price of pizza slices. The model turns out to be a rational equation.

title: Manipulating formulas
description: Sal rewrites the formula for the perimeter of a rectangle so it is solved for width.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Introduction to conic sections
description: Sal introduces the four conic sections and shows how they are derived by intersecting planes with cones in certain ways.

title: Standard equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Expanded equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.

title: Focus and directrix of a parabola
description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.

title: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal introduces sine, cosine, and tangent, and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.

title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Modeling with right triangles
description: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.

title: Trigonometric ratios and similarity
description: Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Sine and cosine of complementary angles
description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Introduction to the Pythagorean trigonometric identity
description: Sal introduces and proves the identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1, which arises from the Pythagorean theorem!

title: The reciprocal trigonometric ratios
description: Sal finds all six trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent, secant, cosecant, and cotangent) of an angle in a given right triangle.

title: The law of sines
description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

title: The law of cosines
description: Learn how to use the law of cosines to find the missing side length of a triangle when given two side lengths and the contained angle measure.

title: Solving general triangles
description: Sal solves a word problem about the distance between stars using the law of cosines.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine, cosine, and tangent for all real numbers.

title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Basic trigonometric identities
description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.

title: Trigonometric values of special angles
description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.

title: The Pythagorean identity
description: Sal proves the Pythagorean identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1 for all real numbers.

title: Long live Tau
description: Why Tau might be a better number to look at than Pi

title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Introduction to amplitude, midline, and extrema of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.

title: Finding amplitude and midline of sinusoidal functions from their formulas
description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Period of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphing sinusoidal functions
description: Sal graphs y=2*sin(-x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and a horizontal reflection of y=sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Constructing sinusoidal functions
description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2,-5) and the maximum point (2,1) are highlighted.

title: The inverse trigonometric functions
description: Sal introduces arcsine, which is the inverse function of sine, and discusses its principal range.

title: Solving basic sinusoidal equations
description: Sal finds the expressions that together represent all possible solutions to the equation sin(x)=1/3.

title: Solving sinusoidal models
description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by solving a sinusoidal equation.

title: Introduction to the trigonometric angle addition identities
description: Sal reviews all the different trigonometric angle addition identities: sin(a+b), sin(a-c), cos(a+b), cos(a-b), cos(2a), and sin(2a).

title: Using trigonometric identities to solve problems
description: Sal finds the value of sin(7π/12) by rewriting it as sin(π/3+π/4) and then using the sine angle addition formula.

title: Challenging trigonometry problems
description: Sal solves a very complicated geometrical trig problem that appeared as problem 11 in the 2003 AIME II exam.

title: Analyzing one categorical variable
description: Identifying individuals, variables and categorical variables in a data set

title: Two-way tables
description: Sal uses a Venn diagram to introduce two-way frequency tables.

title: Distributions in two-way tables
description: Marginal distribution and conditional distribution

title: Displaying quantitative data with graphs
description: Here are a few of the many ways to look at data. Which is your favorite?

title: Describing and comparing distributions
description: Some distributions are symmetrical, with data evenly distributed about the mean. Other distributions are "skewed," with data tending to the left or right of the mean. We sometimes say that skewed distributions have "tails."

title: More on data displays
description: A line graph is way to visually represent data, especially data that changes over time.  Let's take a look at an example.

title: Measuring center in quantitative data
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: More on mean and median
description: Sal compares the means of two different distributions given as dot plots.

title: Interquartile range (IQR)
description: The IQR describes the middle 50% of values when ordered from lowest to highest. To find the interquartile range (IQR), ​first find the median (middle value) of the lower and upper half of the data. These values are quartile 1 (Q1) and quartile 3 (Q3). The IQR is the difference between Q3 and Q1.

title: Variance and standard deviation of a population
description: Sal discusses the three most common measures of spread!

title: Variance and standard deviation of a sample
description: Thinking about how we can estimate the variance of a population by looking at the data in a sample.

title: More on standard deviation
description: Another visualization providing evidence that dividing by n-1 truly gives an unbiased estimate of population variance. Simulation at: http://www.khanacademy.org/cs/unbiased-variance-visualization/1167453164

title: Box and whisker plots
description: Learn how to create a box plot. The data set used in this example has 11 data points.

title: Other measures of spread
description: The range is the difference between the largest and smallest numbers. The midrange is the average of the largest and smallest number. Practice with this problem.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Z-scores
description: Z-score practice

title: Normal distributions and the empirical rule
description: Discussion of how "normal" a distribution might be

title: More on normal distributions
description: Exploring the normal distribution

title: Introduction to scatterplots
description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

title: Introduction to trend lines
description: Sal creates a scatter plot and then fits a line to data on the median California family income.

title: More on regression
description: Introduction to the idea that one can find a line that minimizes the squared distances to the points

title: Statistical questions
description: What makes a question a "statistical question"?

title: Sampling and observational studies
description: To make a valid conclusion, you'll need a representaive, not skewed, sample.

title: Sampling methods
description: Sal determines if a few different methods of a magician choosing a volunteer are fair.

title: Types of studies (experimental vs. observational)
description: Types of statistical studies

title: Experiments
description: Introduction to experiment design. Explanatory and response variables. Control and treatment groups.

title: Basic theoretical probability
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Probability using sample spaces
description: The probability of getting exactly 2 heads when flipping three coins. Thinking about this by visualy depicting all of the outcomes.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Basic set operations
description: Sal shows examples of intersection and union of sets and introduces some set notation.

title: Experimental probability
description: Based on past experience, we can make reasonable estimates of the likelihood of future events.

title: Addition rule
description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.

title: Multiplication rule for independent events
description: Explore the notion of a "sample space". See a sample space represented as a tree diagram, table, and list.

title: Multiplication rule for dependent events
description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.

title: Conditional probability and independence
description: Sal solves a conditional probability example where he thinks about probabilities like P(A | B) where the events are about lunch and breakfast!

title: Counting principle and factorial
description: Tree diagrams display all the possible outcomes of an event. Each branch in a tree diagram represents a possible outcome. Tree diagrams can be used to find the number of possible outcomes and calculate the probability of possible outcomes.

title: Permutations
description: Sal explains the permutation formula and how to use it.

title: Combinations
description: Sal introduces the basic idea of combinations.

title: Combinatorics and probability
description: Probability of getting exactly 3 heads in 8 flips of a fair coin.

title: Discrete random variables
description: Basic idea and definitions of random variables

title: Continuous random variables
description: Probability density functions for continuous random variables.

title: Binomial mean and standard deviation formulas
description: Sal calculates the mean and variance of a Bernoulli distribution (in this example the responses are either favorable or unfavorable).

title: More on expected value
description: Understanding an insurance company's sense of my chances of dying.

title: Poisson distribution
description: Introduction to Poisson Processes and the Poisson Distribution.

title: What is a sampling distribution?
description: Introduction to sampling distributions

title: Sampling distribution of a sample proportion
description: Formulas for the mean and standard deviation of a sampling distribution of sample proportions.

title: Sampling distribution of a sample mean
description: Much of statistics is based upon using data from a random sample that is representative of the population at large. From that sample mean, we can infer things about the greater population mean. We'll explain.

title: Introduction to confidence intervals
description: Confidence intervals and margin of error

title: Estimating a population proportion
description: Sal calculates a 99% confidence interval for the proportion of teachers who felt computers are an essential tool.

title: Estimating a population mean
description: An introduction to why we use t statistics.

title: More confidence interval videos
description: Sal computes a confidence interval for the emission from an engine with a new design.

title: The idea of significance tests
description: Sal walks through an example about who should do the dishes that gets at the idea behind hypothesis testing.

title: Error probabilities and power
description: Introduction to Type I and Type II errors in significance testing. Significance levels as the probability of making a Type I error.

title: Tests about a population proportion
description: Constructing hypotheses for a significance test about a proportion

title: Tests about a population mean
description: Example of constructing hypotheses for a test about a mean

title: More significance testing videos
description: Sal walks through an example about a neurologist testing the effect of a drug to discuss hypothesis testing and p-values.

title: Comparing two proportions
description: Sal uses an election example to compare population proportions.

title: Comparing two means
description: Sal determines if the results of an experiment about advertising are statistically significant.

title: Chi-square goodness-of-fit tests
description: Chi-Square Distribution Introduction

title: Chi-square tests for relationships
description: Give the row and column totals, Sal fills in the cells of a frequency table so that the events are independent.

title: Inference about slope
description: Introducing the conditions for making a confidence interval or doing a test about slope in least-squares regression.

title: Nonlinear regression
description: Sal determines if a quadratic or exponential model fits the data better, then uses the model to make a prediction.

title: Analysis of variance (ANOVA)
description: Analysis of Variance 1 - Calculating SST (Total Sum of Squares)

title: Creating and interpreting scatterplots
description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

title: Estimating with trend lines
description: Sal solves a problem where he has to estimate the line of best fit for a scatter plot.

title: Displays of distributions
description: Learn to organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).

title: Summarizing center of distributions (central tendency)
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Summarizing spread of distributions
description: The IQR describes the middle 50% of values when ordered from lowest to highest. To find the interquartile range (IQR), ​first find the median (middle value) of the lower and upper half of the data. These values are quartile 1 (Q1) and quartile 3 (Q3). The IQR is the difference between Q3 and Q1.

title: Box and whisker plots
description: Here's a word problem that's perfectly suited for a box and whiskers plot to help analyze data. Let's construct one together, shall we?
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Comparing distributions
description: Sal examines two distributions in dot plots to draw conclusions about the times of Olympic swimmers.

title: Two-way relative frequency tables
description: Worked example video where we are asked to find a two-way table of column relative frequencies.

title: Samples and surveys
description: To make a valid conclusion, you'll need a representaive, not skewed, sample.

title: Probability basics
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Counting with permutations
description: Find the number of ways you can put four types of flowers into three types of pots.

title: Counting with combinations
description: Sal introduces the basic idea of combinations.

title: Probability with counting, permutations, combinations
description: The probability of getting exactly 2 heads when flipping three coins. Thinking about this by visualy depicting all of the outcomes.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multiplication rule for independent events
description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Multiplication rule for dependent events
description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.

title: Addition rule for probability
description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.

title: Binomial probability
description: Sal calculates the probability of making 2 shots out of 6 using the binomial distribution.

title: Normal distributions
description: Using the empirical rule (or 68-95-99.7 rule) to estimate probabilities for normal distributions

title: Welcome to AP Statistics
description: A former high school teacher for 10 years in Kalamazoo, Michigan, Jeff taught Algebra 1, Geometry, Algebra 2, Introductory Statistics, and AP Statistics. Today Jeff is Khan Academy’s math content creator. He is hard at work creating new exercises and articles for AP Statistics (thank you, Jeff!).

description: Learn to organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).

title: Histograms and stem-and-leaf plots
description: A histogram is a graphical display of data using bars of different heights. In a histogram, each bar groups numbers into ranges. Taller bars show that more data falls in that range. A histogram displays the shape and spread of continuous sample data.

title: Describing and comparing distributions
description: Classifying distributions as being symmetric, left skewed, right skewed, uniform or bimodal.

title: Measuring center in quantitative data
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: More on mean and median
description: Learn how to find the value of a missing piece of data if you know the mean of the data set.

title: Measuring spread in quantitative data
description: The IQR describes the middle 50% of values when ordered from lowest to highest. To find the interquartile range (IQR), ​first find the median (middle value) of the lower and upper half of the data. These values are quartile 1 (Q1) and quartile 3 (Q3). The IQR is the difference between Q3 and Q1.

title: More on standard deviation (optional)
description: Reviewing the population mean, sample mean, population variance, sample variance and building an intuition for why we divide by n-1 for the unbiased sample variance

title: Box and whisker plots
description: Learn how to create a box plot. The data set used in this example has 11 data points.

description: Discussion of how "normal" a distribution might be

description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

title: Least-squares regression equations
description: Regression lines as a way to quantify a linear trend. Residuals at a point as the difference between the actual y value at a point and the estimated y value from the regression line given the x coordinate of that point.

description: Identifying a sample and population

description: Techniques for generating a simple random sample

description: Introduction to experiment design. Explanatory and response variables. Control and treatment groups.

title: Randomness, probability, and simulation
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Addition rule
description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.

title: Multiplication rule
description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Discrete random variables
description: Sal breaks down how to create the probability distribution of the number of "heads" after 3 flips of a fair coin.

title: What is a sampling distribution?
description: Introduction to sampling distributions

title: Sampling distribution of a sample proportion
description: Formulas for the mean and standard deviation of a sampling distribution of sample proportions.

description: Introduction to the central limit theorem and the sampling distribution of the mean

description: Confidence intervals and margin of error

description: Conditions for valid confidence intervals

description: Constructing hypotheses for a significance test about a proportion

title: Testing hypotheses about a mean
description: Example of constructing hypotheses for a test about a mean

description: Introducing two-sample z intervals to estimate the difference between two population proportions.

title: Testing the difference between two proportions
description: Hypothesis test for difference in proportions

title: Confidence intervals for the difference between two means
description: Conditions for inference for difference of means

title: Testing the difference between two means
description: Example of how to write hypotheses for a two-sample t test, and how to distinguish between paired and two-sample comparisons between means.

title: Chi-square goodness-of-fit tests
description: Chi-square statistic for hypothesis testing (chi-square goodness-of-fit test)

title: Chi-square tests for relationships
description: Introduction to the chi-square test for homogeneity
