description: Introduction to sample slopes and using them to make confidence intervals or do a test about the population slope in least-squares regression

title: Transformations to achieve linearity
description: Use logarithms to transform nonlinear data into a linear relationship so we can use least-squares regression methods.

title: Prepare for the exam
description: Carrying out every step of a significance test on a proportion.

title: The inverse trigonometric functions
description: Sal introduces arcsine, which is the inverse function of sine, and discusses its principal range.

title: Solving basic sinusoidal equations
description: Sal finds the expressions that together represent all possible solutions to the equation sin(x)=1/3.

title: Solving sinusoidal models
description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by solving a sinusoidal equation.

title: Introduction to the trigonometric angle addition identities
description: Sal reviews all the different trigonometric angle addition identities: sin(a+b), sin(a-c), cos(a+b), cos(a-b), cos(2a), and sin(2a).

title: Using trigonometric identities to solve problems
description: Sal finds the value of sin(7π/12) by rewriting it as sin(π/3+π/4) and then using the sine angle addition formula.

title: Introduction to conic sections
description: Sal introduces the four conic sections and shows how they are derived by intersecting planes with cones in certain ways.

title: Standard equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Expanded equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.

title: Center and radii of an ellipse
description: Sal introduces ellipses and shows how their standard equation relates to their center and radii (ellipses have two radii: major and minor).

title: Foci of an ellipse
description: Sal explains how the radii and the foci of an ellipse relate to each other, and how we can use this relationship in order to find the foci from the equation of an ellipse.

title: Focus and directrix of a parabola
description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.

title: Introduction to hyperbolas
description: Sal introduces the standard equation for hyperbolas, and how it can be used in order to determine the direction of the hyperbola and its vertices.

title: Foci of a hyperbola
description: Sal discusses the foci of hyperbolas and shows how they relate to hyperbola equations.

title: Hyperbolas not centered at the origin
description: Sal analyzes the hyperbola whose equation is (x-1)^2/16-(y+1)^2/4=1, and graphs it.

title: Identifying conic sections from their expanded equations
description: Sal manipulates the equation x^2+y^2-3x+4y=4 in order to find that it represents a circle, and the equation 2x^2+y+12x+16=0 in order to find it represents a parabola.

title: Challenging conic section problems (IIT JEE)
description: How a tangent line relates to a hyperbola. Might be useful for some competitive exams where there isn't time to derive (like we are doing in this video).

title: Vector basics
description: The difference between vectors and scalars. ​Introduction to distance, displacement, speed, and velocity.

title: Unit vectors
description: Unit vectors are vectors whose magnitude is exactly 1 unit. They are very useful for different reasons. Specifically, the unit vectors [0,1] and [1,0] can form together any other vector.

title: Adding vectors in magnitude and direction form
description: Watch Sal add two vectors given in magnitude and direction form by breaking them down into components first.

title: Introduction to matrices
description: Take the red pill and enter the Matrix!

title: Row-echelon form and Gaussian elimination
description: Sal solves a linear system with 3 variables by representing it with an augmented matrix and bringing the matrix to reduced row-echelon form.

title: Adding and subtracting matrices
description: Sal defines what it means to add or subtract matrices. He shows a few examples and discusses some important properties of matrix addition and subtraction.

title: Multiplying matrices by scalars
description: Sal defines what it means to multiply a matrix by a scalar (in the world of matrices, a scalar is simply a regular number).

title: Multiplying matrices by matrices
description: Sal explains what it means to multiply two matrices, and gives an example.

title: Properties of matrix multiplication
description: Sal discusses the conditions of matrix dimensions for which addition or multiplication are defined.

title: Matrices as transformations
description: Sal transforms a 2-dimensional vector using a 2x2 matrix, and draws the original vector and its image on the plane.

title: The determinant of a 2x2 matrix
description: Sal shows how to find the determinant of a 2x2 matrix.

title: Introduction to matrix inverses
description: Sal introduces the concept of an inverse matrix.

title: Finding the inverse of a matrix using its determinant
description: Sal gives an example of how to find the inverse of a given 2x2 matrix.

title: Solving equations with inverse matrices
description: Sal shows how a system of two linear equations can be represented with the equation A*x=b where A is the coefficient matrix, x is the variable vector, and b is the constant vector.

title: Model real-world situations with matrices
description: Sal shows how matrices can be used to efficiently represent data about the prices of toilet paper and toothpaste in two different cities.

title: What are the imaginary numbers?
description: Sal introduces the imaginary unit i, which is defined by the equation i^2=-1. He then gets to know this special number better by thinking about its powers.

title: What are the complex numbers?
description: Sal explains how we obtain complex numbers by adding real numbers and imaginary numbers.

title: The complex plane
description: Sal shows how to plot various numbers on the complex plane.

title: Adding and subtracting complex numbers
description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Distance and midpoint of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the distance between (2+3i) and (-5-i) and then he finds their midpoint on the complex plane.

title: Multiplying complex numbers
description: Sal multiplies (1-3i) by (2+5i).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Complex conjugates and dividing complex numbers
description: Sal explains what is the conjugate of a complex number, and shows how the product of a complex number and its conjugate is always a real number.

title: Absolute value and angle of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the absolute value of (3-4i).

title: Polar form of complex numbers
description: Sal rewrites the complex number -3+2i (which is given in rectangular form) in its polar form.

title: Multiplying and dividing complex numbers in polar form
description: Sal shows how complex division affects the modulus and the argument of the divisor and the dividend.

title: Challenging complex number problems
description: Paper 1 Problem 39 from the challenging 2010 IIT JEE exam, about complex numbers.

title: Basic probability
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Venn diagrams and the addition rule
description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.

title: Compound probability of independent events using diagrams
description: We're thinking about the probability of rolling doubles on a pair of dice. Let's create a grid of all possible outcomes.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Compound probability of independent events using the multiplication rule
description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Dependent events
description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.

title: Permutations
description: Sal explains a tricky factorial problem about counting seat arrangements.

title: Combinations
description: Sal introduces the basic idea of combinations.

title: Probability using combinatorics
description: Probability of getting exactly 3 heads in 8 flips of a fair coin.

title: Arithmetic sequences
description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms"), like 2,5,8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example, 2,5,8 follows the pattern "add 3," and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example, 2,5,8,... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Basic sigma notation
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Geometric sequences
description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio.

title: Finite geometric series
description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn more about it here.

title: Finite geometric series applications
description: Watch Sal solve an example of using a geometric series to answer a fun word problem.

title: Limits intro
description: A limit tells us the value that a function approaches as that function’s inputs get closer and closer to some number. The idea of a limit is the basis of all calculus.

title: Formal definition of limits (epsilon-delta)
description: A quick reminder of what limits are, to set up for the formal definition of a limit.

title: Properties of limits
description: What is the limit of the sum of two functions?  What about the product?

title: Limits using algebraic manipulation
description: Sal finds the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) at x=2 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Squeeze theorem
description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers, and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k), then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0, by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

title: Removing discontinuities
description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(6x²+18x+12)/(x²-4) should have at x=-2 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Infinite limits
description: Introducing the notation of infinite limits.

title: Limits at infinity
description: Introduction to the idea and notion of limits at infinity (and negative infinity).

title: Intermediate value theorem
description: Introduction to the Intermediate value theorem. If f is a continuous function over [a,b], then it takes on every value between f(a) and f(b) over that interval.

title: Average vs. instantaneous rate of change
description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Secant lines
description: What is the slope of a line between two points on a curve?  This is called a "secant" line.

title: Derivative definition
description: The derivative of function f at x=c is the limit of the slope of the secant line from x=c to x=c+h as h approaches 0. Symbolically, this is the limit of [f(c)-f(c+h)]/h as h→0.

title: Power rule
description: Sal introduces the power rule, which tells us how to find the derivative of xⁿ.

title: Derivative rules: constant, sum, difference, and constant multiple
description: Once you know how to take the derivative of x^n, it turns out you can take the derivative of any polynomial.  Let's see why...

title: Product rule
description: Introduction to the product rule, which tells us how to take the derivative of a product of functions.

title: Proof videos
description: Sal shows that if a function is differentiable at a point, it is also continuous at that point.

title: Chain rule
description: The chain rule states that the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). In other words, it helps us differentiate *composite functions*. For example, sin(x²) is a composite function because it can be constructed as f(g(x)) for f(x)=sin(x) and g(x)=x². Using the chain rule and the derivatives of sin(x) and x², we can then find the derivative of sin(x²).

title: Implicit differentiation
description: Some relationships cannot be represented by an explicit function. For example, x²+y²=1. Implicit differentiation helps us find ​dy/dx even for relationships like that. This is done using the chain ​rule, and viewing y as an implicit function of x. For example, according to the chain rule, the derivative of y² would be 2y⋅(dy/dx).

title: Implicit differentiation (advanced examples)
description: Implicit differentiation of y = cos(5x - 3y)

title: Differentiating inverse functions
description: Functions f and g are inverses if f(g(x))=x=g(f(x)). For every pair of such functions, the derivatives f' and g' have a special relationship. Learn about this relationship and see how it applies to 𝑒ˣ and ln(x) (which are inverse functions!).

title: Derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions
description: Derivative of inverse sine

title: Logarithmic differentiation
description: Sal finds the derivatives of xˣ and x^(xˣ). They are surprisingly fun to do!

title: Proof videos
description: Sal shows that if a function is differentiable at a point, it is also continuous at that point.

title: Meaning of the derivative in context
description: When derivatives are used to describe real-world situations, we need to know how to make sense of them.

title: Straight-line motion
description: The position of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by s(t)=t³-6t²+9t. Sal analyzes it to find the times when the particle is "speeding up."

title: Non-motion applications of derivatives
description: Let's face it, sometimes it feels like we forget much of what we learn.  In this example we model that forgetful phenomenon.

title: Introduction to related rates
description: What's the relationship between how fast a circle's radius changes, and how fast its area changes?

title: Solving related rates problems
description: As two cars approach the same intersection from different roads, how does the rate of change of the distance between them change?

title: Approximation with local linearity
description: Sal introduces the idea of approximating curves using their tangent line equations. This is also called "local linearization."

title: L’Hôpital’s rule
description: When you are solving a limit, and get 0/0 or ∞/∞, L'Hôpital's rule is the tool you need.

title: L’Hôpital’s rule: composite exponential functions
description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at 0 of (sinx)^(1/lnx).

title: Mean value theorem
description: The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b] and differentiable on the open interval (a,b), then there exists a point c in the interval (a,b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a,b]. In other words, the graph has a tangent somewhere in (a,b) that is parallel to the secant line over [a,b].

title: Extreme value theorem and critical points
description: The Extreme value theorem states that if a function is continuous on a closed interval [a,b], then the function must have a maximum and a minimum on the interval. This makes sense: when a function is continuous you can draw its graph without lifting the pencil, so you must hit a high point and a low point on that interval.

title: Relative (local) extrema
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Absolute (global) extrema
description: Sal finds the absolute maximum value of f(x)=8ln(x)-x² over the interval [1,4].

title: Concavity and inflection points intro
description: Sal introduces the concept of concavity, what it means for a graph to be "concave up" or "concave down," and how this relates to the second derivative of a function.

title: Sketching curves
description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=3x⁴-4x³+2 including extremum and inflection points.

title: Solving optimization problems
description: What is the minimum possible value of x^2+y^2 given that their product has to be fixed at xy = -16

title: Analyzing implicit relations
description: Finding the equation of a horizontal tangent to a curve that is defined implicitly as an equation in x and y.

title: Parametric equations intro
description: Sal gives an example of a situation where parametric equations are very useful: driving off a cliff!

title: Vector-valued functions
description: Using a position vector valued function to describe a curve or path

title: Approximation with Riemann sums
description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: Summation notation review
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Riemann sums in summation notation
description: Generalizing the technique of approximating area under a curve with rectangles.

title: Defining integrals with Riemann sums
description: Definite integrals represent the exact area under a given curve, and Riemann sums are used to approximate those areas. However, if we take Riemann sums with infinite rectangles of infinitely small width (using limits), we get the exact area, i.e. the definite integral!

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus and accumulation functions
description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how, in some sense, integration is the opposite of differentiation.

title: Properties of definite integrals
description: We learned that definite integrals give us the area under the curve and above the x-axis. But what if the curve itself is below the x-axis? In this case, the definite integral is still related to area, but it's negative. See how this works and get some intuition for why this is so.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus and definite integrals
description: There are really two versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus, and we go through the connection here.

title: Reverse power rule
description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Indefinite integrals of common functions
description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw, this is ln(x). However, if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

title: Integrating with u-substitution
description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

title: Integrating using long division and completing the square
description: Here we do polynomial long division to make an integral more computable.

title: Integrating using trigonometric identities
description: A specialized form of u-substitution involves taking advantage of trigonometric identities.

title: Trigonometric substitution
description: Introduction to trigonometric substitution

title: Integration by parts
description: By looking at the product rule for derivatives in reverse, we get a powerful integration tool.

title: Integrating using linear partial fractions
description: Finding the integral of a rational function using linear partial fraction decomposition.

title: Improper integrals
description: Improper integrals are definite integrals where one or both of the ​boundaries is at infinity, or where the integrand has a vertical asymptote in the interval of integration. As crazy as it may sound, we can actually calculate some improper integrals using some clever methods that involve limits.

title: Proof videos
description: The first part of the fundamental theorem of calculus tells us that if we define 𝘍(𝘹) to be the definite integral of function ƒ from some constant 𝘢 to 𝘹, then 𝘍 is an antiderivative of ƒ. In other words, 𝘍'(𝘹)=ƒ(𝘹). See why this is so.

title: Differential equations introduction
description: Differential equations are equations that relate a function with one or more of its derivatives. This means their solution is a function! Learn more in this video.

title: Verifying solutions for differential equations
description: We can check whether a potential solution to a differential equation is indeed a solution. What we need to do is differentiate and substitute both the solution and the derivative into the equation.

title: Sketching slope fields
description: Slope fields allow us to analyze differential equations graphically. Learn how to draw them and use them to find particular solutions.

title: Reasoning using slope fields
description: Given the slope field of a differential equation, we can sketch various solutions to the equation.

title: Approximation with Euler’s method
description: Euler's method is a numerical tool for approximating values for solutions of differential equations. See how (and why) it works.

title: Separation of variables
description: "Separation of variables" allows us to rewrite differential equations so we obtain an equality between two integrals we can evaluate. Separable equations are the class of differential equations that can be solved using this method.

title: Exponential models
description: Assuming a quantity grows proportionally to its size results in the general equation dy/dx=ky. Solving it with separation of variables results in the general exponential function y=Ceᵏˣ.

title: Logistic models
description: Population should grow proportionally to its size, but it can't keep growing forever! Learn more about this problem, posed by Malthus, and embark on a journey towards its mathematical solution.

title: Average value of a function
description: Average value of a function over a closed interval

title: Non-motion applications of integrals
description: If you have a function representing rate, what does the area under its curve represent?

title: Area: vertical area between curves
description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Volume: squares and rectangles cross sections
description: Using definite integration to find volume of a solid whose base is given as a region between function and whose cross sections are squares.

title: Volume: triangles and semicircles cross sections
description: The volume of a solid with semi-circular cross sections and a triangular base.

title: Volume: disc method (revolving around x- and y-axes)
description: Finding the solid of revolution (constructed by revolving around the x-axis) using the disc method.

title: Volume: disc method (revolving around other axes)
description: Solid of revolution constructing by rotating around line that is not an axis

title: Volume: washer method (revolving around x- and y-axes)
description: Finding the volume of a solid of revolution that is defined between two functions

title: Volume: washer method (revolving around other axes)
description: Washer method when rotating around a horizontal line that is not the x-axis

title: Arc length
description: We can use definite integrals to find the length of a curve. See how it's done and get some intuition into why the formula works.

title: Area: polar regions (single curve)
description: Develop intuition for the area enclosed by polar graph formula

title: Area: polar regions (two curves)
description: More practice with the area encloised by polar functions, this time with two graphs.

title: Arc length: polar curves
description: Sal shows the polar arc length formula, and explains why it is true.

title: Calculator-active practice
description: Here we walk through how to use a graphing calculator to compute the integral found in the last video.

title: Convergent and divergent infinite series
description: A sequence is "converging" if its terms approach a specific value as we progress through them to infinity. Get an intuitive sense of what that even means!

title: nth-term test
description: If the terms of an infinite series don't approach zero, the series must diverge. Learn more about this test in this video.

title: Integral test
description: The integral test helps us determine a series convergence by comparing it to an improper integral, which is something we already know how to find. Learn how it works in this video.

title: Comparison tests
description: If every term in one series is less than the corresponding term in some convergent series, it must converge as well. This notion is at the basis of the direct convergence test. Learn more about it here.

title: Alternating series test
description: When a series alternates (plus, minus, plus, minus,...) there's a fairly simple way to determine whether it converges or diverges: see if the terms of the series approach 0.

title: Ratio test
description: The ratio test is a most useful test for series convergence. It caries over intuition from geometric series to more general series. Learn more about it here.

title: Absolute and conditional convergence
description: "Absolute convergence" means a series will converge even when you take the absolute value of each term, while "Conditional convergence" means the series converges but not absolutely.

title: Alternating series error bound
description: By computing only the first few terms of an alternating series, we can get a pretty good estimate for the infinite sum.  See why.

title: Taylor and Maclaurin polynomials intro
description: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials are a very clever way of approximating any function with a polynomial. Learn how these polynomials work.

title: Lagrange error bound
description: The more terms we have in a Taylor polynomial approximation of a function, the closer we get to the function. But HOW close? Let's embark on a journey to find a bound for the error of a Taylor polynomial approximation.

title: Power series intro
description: Power series is a sum of terms of the general form aₙ(x-a)ⁿ. Whether the series converges or diverges, and the value it converges to, depend on the chosen x-value, which makes power series a function.

title: Maclaurin series of eˣ, sin(x), and cos(x)
description: Approximating cos(x) with a Maclaurin series (which is like a Taylor polynomial centered at x=0 with infinitely many terms). It turns out that this series is exactly the same as the function itself!

title: Telescoping series
description: Telescoping series is a series where all terms cancel out except for the first and last one. This makes such series easy to analyze. In this video, we use partial fraction decomposition to find sum of telescoping series.

title: Proof videos
description: A sequence is "converging" if its terms approach a specific value at infinity. This video is a more formal definition of what it means for a sequence to converge.

title: Defining limits and using limit notation
description: A limit tells us the value that a function approaches as that function’s inputs get closer and closer to some number. The idea of a limit is the basis of all calculus.

title: Determining limits using algebraic properties of limits: limit properties
description: What is the limit of the sum of two functions?  What about the product?

title: Determining limits using algebraic manipulation
description: Sal finds the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) at x=2 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Determining limits using the squeeze theorem
description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers, and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k), then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0, by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

title: Removing discontinuities
description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(6x²+18x+12)/(x²-4) should have at x=-2 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Connecting infinite limits and vertical asymptotes
description: Introducing the notation of infinite limits.

title: Connecting limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes
description: Introduction to the idea and notion of limits at infinity (and negative infinity).

title: Working with the intermediate value theorem
description: Introduction to the Intermediate value theorem. If f is a continuous function over [a,b], then it takes on every value between f(a) and f(b) over that interval.

title: Optional videos
description: A quick reminder of what limits are, to set up for the formal definition of a limit.

title: Defining average and instantaneous rates of change at a point
description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Defining the derivative of a function and using derivative notation
description: The derivative of function f at x=c is the limit of the slope of the secant line from x=c to x=c+h as h approaches 0. Symbolically, this is the limit of [f(c)-f(c+h)]/h as h→0.

title: Applying the power rule
description: Sal introduces the power rule, which tells us how to find the derivative of xⁿ.

title: Derivative rules: constant, sum, difference, and constant multiple: introduction
description: Once you know how to take the derivative of x^n, it turns out you can take the derivative of any polynomial.  Let's see why...

title: The product rule
description: Introduction to the product rule, which tells us how to take the derivative of a product of functions.

title: Optional videos
description: Sal shows that if a function is differentiable at a point, it is also continuous at that point.

title: The chain rule: introduction
description: The chain rule states that the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). In other words, it helps us differentiate *composite functions*. For example, sin(x²) is a composite function because it can be constructed as f(g(x)) for f(x)=sin(x) and g(x)=x². Using the chain rule and the derivatives of sin(x) and x², we can then find the derivative of sin(x²).

title: Implicit differentiation
description: Some relationships cannot be represented by an explicit function. For example, x²+y²=1. Implicit differentiation helps us find ​dy/dx even for relationships like that. This is done using the chain ​rule, and viewing y as an implicit function of x. For example, according to the chain rule, the derivative of y² would be 2y⋅(dy/dx).

title: Differentiating inverse functions
description: Functions f and g are inverses if f(g(x))=x=g(f(x)). For every pair of such functions, the derivatives f' and g' have a special relationship. Learn about this relationship and see how it applies to 𝑒ˣ and ln(x) (which are inverse functions!).

title: Differentiating inverse trigonometric functions
description: Derivative of inverse sine

title: Optional videos
description: Sal shows that if a function is differentiable at a point, it is also continuous at that point.

title: Interpreting the meaning of the derivative in context
description: When derivatives are used to describe real-world situations, we need to know how to make sense of them.

title: Straight-line motion: connecting position, velocity, and acceleration
description: The position of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by s(t)=t³-6t²+9t. Sal analyzes it to find the times when the particle is "speeding up."

title: Rates of change in other applied contexts (non-motion problems)
description: Let's face it, sometimes it feels like we forget much of what we learn.  In this example we model that forgetful phenomenon.

description: What's the relationship between how fast a circle's radius changes, and how fast its area changes?

title: Solving related rates problems
description: As two cars approach the same intersection from different roads, how does the rate of change of the distance between them change?

title: Approximating values of a function using local linearity and linearization
description: Sal introduces the idea of approximating curves using their tangent line equations. This is also called "local linearization."

title: Using L’Hôpital’s rule for finding limits of indeterminate forms
description: When you are solving a limit, and get 0/0 or ∞/∞, L'Hôpital's rule is the tool you need.

title: Optional videos
description: This isn't a full proof of L'Hopital's rule, but it should give some intuition for why it works.

title: Using the mean value theorem
description: The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b] and differentiable on the open interval (a,b), then there exists a point c in the interval (a,b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a,b]. In other words, the graph has a tangent somewhere in (a,b) that is parallel to the secant line over [a,b].

description: The Extreme value theorem states that if a function is continuous on a closed interval [a,b], then the function must have a maximum and a minimum on the interval. This makes sense: when a function is continuous you can draw its graph without lifting the pencil, so you must hit a high point and a low point on that interval.

title: Using the first derivative test to find relative (local) extrema
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Using the candidates test to find absolute (global) extrema
description: Sal finds the absolute maximum value of f(x)=8ln(x)-x² over the interval [1,4].

title: Determining concavity of intervals and finding points of inflection: graphical
description: Sal introduces the concept of concavity, what it means for a graph to be "concave up" or "concave down," and how this relates to the second derivative of a function.

title: Sketching curves of functions and their derivatives
description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=3x⁴-4x³+2 including extremum and inflection points.

title: Solving optimization problems
description: What is the minimum possible value of x^2+y^2 given that their product has to be fixed at xy = -16

title: Exploring behaviors of implicit relations
description: Finding the equation of a horizontal tangent to a curve that is defined implicitly as an equation in x and y.

title: Approximating areas with Riemann sums
description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: Riemann sums, summation notation, and definite integral notation
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: The fundamental theorem of calculus and accumulation functions
description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how, in some sense, integration is the opposite of differentiation.

title: The fundamental theorem of calculus and definite integrals
description: There are really two versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus, and we go through the connection here.

title: Finding antiderivatives and indefinite integrals: basic rules and notation: reverse power rule
description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Finding antiderivatives and indefinite integrals: basic rules and notation: common indefinite integrals
description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

title: Integrating using substitution
description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

title: Integrating functions using long division and completing the square
description: Here we do polynomial long division to make an integral more computable.

title: Optional videos

title: Finding the average value of a function on an interval
description: Average value of a function over a closed interval

title: Using accumulation functions and definite integrals in applied contexts
description: If you have a function representing rate, what does the area under its curve represent?

title: Finding the area between curves expressed as functions of x
description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Volumes with cross sections: squares and rectangles
description: Using definite integration to find volume of a solid whose base is given as a region between function and whose cross sections are squares.

title: Volumes with cross sections: triangles and semicircles
description: The volume of a solid with semi-circular cross sections and a triangular base.

title: Volume with disc method: revolving around x- or y-axis
description: Finding the solid of revolution (constructed by revolving around the x-axis) using the disc method.

title: Volume with disc method: revolving around other axes
description: Solid of revolution constructing by rotating around line that is not an axis

title: Volume with washer method: revolving around x- or y-axis
description: Finding the volume of a solid of revolution that is defined between two functions

title: Volume with washer method: revolving around other axes
description: Washer method when rotating around a horizontal line that is not the x-axis

title: AP Calculus AB 2015 free response
description: Water in a pipe

title: AP Calculus AB 2011 free response
description: Determining whether speed is increasing. Difference between speed and acceleration

title: Determining concavity of intervals and finding points of inflection: graphical
description: Sal introduces the concept of concavity, what it means for a graph to be "concave up" or "concave down," and how this relates to the second derivative of a function.

title: Sketching curves of functions and their derivatives
description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=3x⁴-4x³+2 including extremum and inflection points.

title: Solving optimization problems
description: What is the minimum possible value of x^2+y^2 given that their product has to be fixed at xy = -16

title: Exploring behaviors of implicit relations
description: Finding the equation of a horizontal tangent to a curve that is defined implicitly as an equation in x and y.

title: Approximating areas with Riemann sums
description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: Riemann sums, summation notation, and definite integral notation
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: The fundamental theorem of calculus and accumulation functions
description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how, in some sense, integration is the opposite of differentiation.

title: Applying properties of definite integrals
description: We learned that definite integrals give us the area under the curve and above the x-axis. But what if the curve itself is below the x-axis? In this case, the definite integral is still related to area, but it's negative. See how this works and get some intuition for why this is so.

title: The fundamental theorem of calculus and definite integrals
description: There are really two versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus, and we go through the connection here.

title: Finding antiderivatives and indefinite integrals: basic rules and notation: reverse power rule
description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Finding antiderivatives and indefinite integrals: basic rules and notation: common indefinite integrals
description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw, this is ln(x). However, if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

title: Integrating using substitution
description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

title: Integrating functions using long division and completing the square
description: Here we do polynomial long division to make an integral more computable.

title: Using integration by parts
description: By looking at the product rule for derivatives in reverse, we get a powerful integration tool.

title: Integrating using linear partial fractions
description: Finding the integral of a rational function using linear partial fraction decomposition.

title: Evaluating improper integrals
description: Improper integrals are definite integrals where one or both of the ​boundaries is at infinity, or where the integrand has a vertical asymptote in the interval of integration. As crazy as it may sound, we can actually calculate some improper integrals using some clever methods that involve limits.

title: Optional videos
description: The first part of the fundamental theorem of calculus tells us that if we define 𝘍(𝘹) to be the definite integral of function ƒ from some constant 𝘢 to 𝘹, then 𝘍 is an antiderivative of ƒ. In other words, 𝘍'(𝘹)=ƒ(𝘹). See why this is so.

title: Modeling situations with differential equations
description: Differential equations are equations that relate a function with one or more of its derivatives. This means their solution is a function! Learn more in this video.

title: Verifying solutions for differential equations
description: We can check whether a potential solution to a differential equation is indeed a solution. What we need to do is differentiate and substitute both the solution and the derivative into the equation.

title: Sketching slope fields
description: Slope fields allow us to analyze differential equations graphically. Learn how to draw them and use them to find particular solutions.

title: Reasoning using slope fields
description: Given the slope field of a differential equation, we can sketch various solutions to the equation.

title: Approximating solutions using Euler’s method
description: Euler's method is a numerical tool for approximating values for solutions of differential equations. See how (and why) it works.

title: Finding general solutions using separation of variables
description: "Separation of variables" allows us to rewrite differential equations so we obtain an equality between two integrals we can evaluate. Separable equations are the class of differential equations that can be solved using this method.

title: Exponential models with differential equations
description: Assuming a quantity grows proportionally to its size results in the general equation dy/dx=ky. Solving it with separation of variables results in the general exponential function y=Ceᵏˣ.

title: Logistic models with differential equations
description: Population should grow proportionally to its size, but it can't keep growing forever! Learn more about this problem, posed by Malthus, and embark on a journey towards its mathematical solution.

title: Finding the average value of a function on an interval
description: Average value of a function over a closed interval

title: Using accumulation functions and definite integrals in applied contexts
description: If you have a function representing rate, what does the area under its curve represent?

title: Finding the area between curves expressed as functions of x
description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Volumes with cross sections: squares and rectangles
description: Using definite integration to find volume of a solid whose base is given as a region between function and whose cross sections are squares.

title: Volumes with cross sections: triangles and semicircles
description: The volume of a solid with semi-circular cross sections and a triangular base.

title: Volume with disc method: revolving around x- or y-axis
description: Finding the solid of revolution (constructed by revolving around the x-axis) using the disc method.

title: Volume with disc method: revolving around other axes
description: Solid of revolution constructing by rotating around line that is not an axis

title: Volume with washer method: revolving around x- or y-axis
description: Finding the volume of a solid of revolution that is defined between two functions

title: Volume with washer method: revolving around other axes
description: Washer method when rotating around a horizontal line that is not the x-axis

title: The arc length of a smooth, planar curve and distance traveled
description: We can use definite integrals to find the length of a curve. See how it's done and get some intuition into why the formula works.

title: Defining and differentiating parametric equations
description: Sal gives an example of a situation where parametric equations are very useful: driving off a cliff!

title: Defining and differentiating vector-valued functions
description: Using a position vector valued function to describe a curve or path

title: Finding the area of a polar region or the area bounded by a single polar curve
description: Develop intuition for the area enclosed by polar graph formula

title: Finding the area of the region bounded by two polar curves
description: More practice with the area encloised by polar functions, this time with two graphs.

title: Calculator-active practice
description: Here we walk through how to use a graphing calculator to compute the integral found in the last video.

title: Defining convergent and divergent infinite series
description: A sequence is "converging" if its terms approach a specific value as we progress through them to infinity. Get an intuitive sense of what that even means!

title: The nth-term test for divergence
description: If the terms of an infinite series don't approach zero, the series must diverge. Learn more about this test in this video.

title: Integral test for convergence
description: The integral test helps us determine a series convergence by comparing it to an improper integral, which is something we already know how to find. Learn how it works in this video.

title: Comparison tests for convergence
description: If every term in one series is less than the corresponding term in some convergent series, it must converge as well. This notion is at the basis of the direct convergence test. Learn more about it here.

title: Alternating series test for convergence
description: When a series alternates (plus, minus, plus, minus,...) there's a fairly simple way to determine whether it converges or diverges: see if the terms of the series approach 0.

title: Ratio test for convergence
description: The ratio test is a most useful test for series convergence. It caries over intuition from geometric series to more general series. Learn more about it here.

title: Determining absolute or conditional convergence
description: "Absolute convergence" means a series will converge even when you take the absolute value of each term, while "Conditional convergence" means the series converges but not absolutely.

title: Alternating series error bound
description: By computing only the first few terms of an alternating series, we can get a pretty good estimate for the infinite sum.  See why.

title: Finding Taylor polynomial approximations of functions
description: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials are a very clever way of approximating any function with a polynomial. Learn how these polynomials work.

title: Lagrange error bound
description: The more terms we have in a Taylor polynomial approximation of a function, the closer we get to the function. But HOW close? Let's embark on a journey to find a bound for the error of a Taylor polynomial approximation.

title: Radius and interval of convergence of power series
description: Power series is a sum of terms of the general form aₙ(x-a)ⁿ. Whether the series converges or diverges, and the value it converges to, depend on the chosen x-value, which makes power series a function.

title: Optional videos
description: A sequence is "converging" if its terms approach a specific value at infinity. This video is a more formal definition of what it means for a sequence to converge.

title: AP Calculus BC 2011
description: Velocity and acceleration vectors for particle

title: AP Calculus BC 2008
description: Part 1a of the 2008 BC free response

title: Limits intro
description: A limit tells us the value that a function approaches as that function’s inputs get closer and closer to some number. The idea of a limit is the basis of all calculus.

title: Formal definition of limits (epsilon-delta)
description: A quick reminder of what limits are, to set up for the formal definition of a limit.

title: Properties of limits
description: What is the limit of the sum of two functions?  What about the product?

title: Limits using algebraic manipulation
description: Sal finds the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) at x=2 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Squeeze theorem
description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers, and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k), then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0, by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

title: Removing discontinuities
description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(6x²+18x+12)/(x²-4) should have at x=-2 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Infinite limits
description: Introducing the notation of infinite limits.

title: Limits at infinity
description: Introduction to the idea and notion of limits at infinity (and negative infinity).

title: Intermediate value theorem
description: Introduction to the Intermediate value theorem. If f is a continuous function over [a,b], then it takes on every value between f(a) and f(b) over that interval.

title: Average vs. instantaneous rate of change
description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Secant lines
description: What is the slope of a line between two points on a curve?  This is called a "secant" line.

title: Derivative definition
description: The derivative of function f at x=c is the limit of the slope of the secant line from x=c to x=c+h as h approaches 0. Symbolically, this is the limit of [f(c)-f(c+h)]/h as h→0.

title: Power rule
description: Sal introduces the power rule, which tells us how to find the derivative of xⁿ.

title: Derivative rules: constant, sum, difference, and constant multiple
description: Once you know how to take the derivative of x^n, it turns out you can take the derivative of any polynomial.  Let's see why...

title: Product rule
description: Introduction to the product rule, which tells us how to take the derivative of a product of functions.

title: Proof videos
description: Sal shows that if a function is differentiable at a point, it is also continuous at that point.

title: Chain rule
description: The chain rule states that the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). In other words, it helps us differentiate *composite functions*. For example, sin(x²) is a composite function because it can be constructed as f(g(x)) for f(x)=sin(x) and g(x)=x². Using the chain rule and the derivatives of sin(x) and x², we can then find the derivative of sin(x²).

title: Implicit differentiation
description: Some relationships cannot be represented by an explicit function. For example, x²+y²=1. Implicit differentiation helps us find ​dy/dx even for relationships like that. This is done using the chain ​rule, and viewing y as an implicit function of x. For example, according to the chain rule, the derivative of y² would be 2y⋅(dy/dx).

title: Implicit differentiation (advanced examples)
description: Implicit differentiation of y = cos(5x - 3y)

title: Differentiating inverse functions
description: Functions f and g are inverses if f(g(x))=x=g(f(x)). For every pair of such functions, the derivatives f' and g' have a special relationship. Learn about this relationship and see how it applies to 𝑒ˣ and ln(x) (which are inverse functions!).

title: Derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions
description: Derivative of inverse sine

title: Logarithmic differentiation
description: Sal finds the derivatives of xˣ and x^(xˣ). They are surprisingly fun to do!

title: Proof videos
description: Sal shows that if a function is differentiable at a point, it is also continuous at that point.

title: Meaning of the derivative in context
description: When derivatives are used to describe real-world situations, we need to know how to make sense of them.

title: Straight-line motion
description: The position of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by s(t)=t³-6t²+9t. Sal analyzes it to find the times when the particle is "speeding up."

title: Non-motion applications of derivatives
description: Let's face it, sometimes it feels like we forget much of what we learn.  In this example we model that forgetful phenomenon.

title: Introduction to related rates
description: What's the relationship between how fast a circle's radius changes, and how fast its area changes?

title: Solving related rates problems
description: As two cars approach the same intersection from different roads, how does the rate of change of the distance between them change?

title: Approximation with local linearity
description: Sal introduces the idea of approximating curves using their tangent line equations. This is also called "local linearization."

title: L’Hôpital’s rule
description: When you are solving a limit, and get 0/0 or ∞/∞, L'Hôpital's rule is the tool you need.

title: L’Hôpital’s rule: composite exponential functions
description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at 0 of (sinx)^(1/lnx).

title: Mean value theorem
description: The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b] and differentiable on the open interval (a,b), then there exists a point c in the interval (a,b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a,b]. In other words, the graph has a tangent somewhere in (a,b) that is parallel to the secant line over [a,b].

title: Extreme value theorem and critical points
description: The Extreme value theorem states that if a function is continuous on a closed interval [a,b], then the function must have a maximum and a minimum on the interval. This makes sense: when a function is continuous you can draw its graph without lifting the pencil, so you must hit a high point and a low point on that interval.

title: Relative (local) extrema
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Absolute (global) extrema
description: Sal finds the absolute maximum value of f(x)=8ln(x)-x² over the interval [1,4].

title: Concavity and inflection points intro
description: Sal introduces the concept of concavity, what it means for a graph to be "concave up" or "concave down," and how this relates to the second derivative of a function.

title: Sketching curves
description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=3x⁴-4x³+2 including extremum and inflection points.

title: Solving optimization problems
description: What is the minimum possible value of x^2+y^2 given that their product has to be fixed at xy = -16

title: Analyzing implicit relations
description: Finding the equation of a horizontal tangent to a curve that is defined implicitly as an equation in x and y.

title: Approximation with Riemann sums
description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: Summation notation review
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Riemann sums in summation notation
description: Generalizing the technique of approximating area under a curve with rectangles.

title: Defining integrals with Riemann sums
description: Definite integrals represent the exact area under a given curve, and Riemann sums are used to approximate those areas. However, if we take Riemann sums with infinite rectangles of infinitely small width (using limits), we get the exact area, i.e. the definite integral!

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus and accumulation functions
description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how, in some sense, integration is the opposite of differentiation.

title: Properties of definite integrals
description: We learned that definite integrals give us the area under the curve and above the x-axis. But what if the curve itself is below the x-axis? In this case, the definite integral is still related to area, but it's negative. See how this works and get some intuition for why this is so.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus and definite integrals
description: There are really two versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus, and we go through the connection here.

description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Indefinite integrals of common functions
description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw, this is ln(x). However, if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

title: Integrating with u-substitution
description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

title: Integrating using long division and completing the square
description: Here we do polynomial long division to make an integral more computable.

title: Integrating using trigonometric identities
description: A specialized form of u-substitution involves taking advantage of trigonometric identities.

title: Proof videos
description: The first part of the fundamental theorem of calculus tells us that if we define 𝘍(𝘹) to be the definite integral of function ƒ from some constant 𝘢 to 𝘹, then 𝘍 is an antiderivative of ƒ. In other words, 𝘍'(𝘹)=ƒ(𝘹). See why this is so.

description: Average value of a function over a closed interval

title: Non-motion applications of integrals
description: If you have a function representing rate, what does the area under its curve represent?

title: Area: vertical area between curves
description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Volume: squares and rectangles cross sections
description: Using definite integration to find volume of a solid whose base is given as a region between function and whose cross sections are squares.

title: Volume: triangles and semicircles cross sections
description: The volume of a solid with semi-circular cross sections and a triangular base.

title: Volume: disc method (revolving around x- and y-axes)
description: Finding the solid of revolution (constructed by revolving around the x-axis) using the disc method.

title: Volume: disc method (revolving around other axes)
description: Solid of revolution constructing by rotating around line that is not an axis

title: Volume: washer method (revolving around x- and y-axes)
description: Finding the volume of a solid of revolution that is defined between two functions

title: Volume: washer method (revolving around other axes)
description: Washer method when rotating around a horizontal line that is not the x-axis

description: Develop intuition for the area enclosed by polar graph formula

title: Area: polar regions (two curves)
description: More practice with the area encloised by polar functions, this time with two graphs.

title: Arc length: polar curves
description: Sal shows the polar arc length formula, and explains why it is true.

title: Calculator-active practice
description: Here we walk through how to use a graphing calculator to compute the integral found in the last video.

title: Taylor and Maclaurin polynomials intro
description: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials are a very clever way of approximating any function with a polynomial. Learn how these polynomials work.

title: Lagrange error bound
description: The more terms we have in a Taylor polynomial approximation of a function, the closer we get to the function. But HOW close? Let's embark on a journey to find a bound for the error of a Taylor polynomial approximation.

title: Power series intro
description: Power series is a sum of terms of the general form aₙ(x-a)ⁿ. Whether the series converges or diverges, and the value it converges to, depend on the chosen x-value, which makes power series a function.

title: Maclaurin series of eˣ, sin(x), and cos(x)
description: Approximating cos(x) with a Maclaurin series (which is like a Taylor polynomial centered at x=0 with infinitely many terms). It turns out that this series is exactly the same as the function itself!

title: Telescoping series
description: Telescoping series is a series where all terms cancel out except for the first and last one. This makes such series easy to analyze. In this video, we use partial fraction decomposition to find sum of telescoping series.

title: Proof videos
description: A sequence is "converging" if its terms approach a specific value at infinity. This video is a more formal definition of what it means for a sequence to converge.

title: Introduction to multivariable calculus
description: An introduction to multivariable functions, and a welcome to the multivariable calculus content as a whole.

title: Visualizing scalar-valued functions
description: Learn how to represent and think about points and vectors in three-dimensional space.

title: Visualizing vector-valued functions
description: When a function has a one-dimensional input, but a multidimensional output, you can think of it as drawing a curve in space.

title: Transformations
description: One fun way to think about functions is to imagine that they literally move the points from the input space over to the output space. See what this looks like with some one-dimensional examples.

title: Partial derivatives
description: Partial derivatives tell you how a multivariable function changes as you tweak just one of the variables in its input.

title: Gradient and directional derivatives
description: The gradient captures all the partial derivative information of a scalar-valued multivariable function.

title: Differentiating parametric curves
description: Using a position vector valued function to describe a curve or path

title: Multivariable chain rule
description: This is the simplest case of taking the derivative of a composition involving multivariable functions.

title: Curvature
description: An introduction to curvature, the radius of curvature, and how you can think about each one geometrically.

title: Partial derivatives of vector-valued functions
description: When a function has a multidimensional input, and a multidimensional output, you can take its partial derivative by computing the partial derivative of each component in the output.

title: Divergence
description: Vector fields can be thought of as representing fluid flow, and divergence is all about studying the change in fluid density during that flow.

title: Curl
description: A description of how vector fields relate to fluid rotation, laying the intuition for what the operation of curl represents.

title: Laplacian
description: A visual understanding for how the Laplace operator is an extension of the second derivative to multivariable functions.

title: Jacobian
description: Before jumping into the Jacobian, it's important to make sure we all know how to think about matrices geometrically. This is targetted towards those who have seen linear algebra but may need a quick refresher.

title: Tangent planes and local linearization
description: The "tangent plane" of the graph of a function is, well, a two-dimensional plane that is tangent to this graph. Here you can see what that looks like.

title: Quadratic approximations
description: After learning about local linearizations of multivariable functions, the next step is to understand how to approximate a function even more closely with a quadratic approximation.

title: Optimizing multivariable functions
description: A description of maxima and minima of multivariable functions, what they look like, and a little bit about how to find them.

title: Lagrange multipliers and constrained optimization
description: The Lagrange multiplier technique is how we take advantage of the observation made in the last video, that the solution to a constrained optimization problem occurs when the contour lines of the function being maximized are tangent to the constraint curve.

title: Line integrals for scalar functions (videos)
description: Introduction to the Line Integral

title: Line integrals in vector fields (videos)
description: Using line integrals to find the work done on a particle moving through a vector field

title: Double integrals (videos)
description: Introduction to the double integral

title: Triple integrals (videos)
description: Introduction to the triple integral

title: Surface integral preliminaries (videos)
description: Introduction to Parametrizing a Surface with Two Parameters

title: Surface integrals (videos)
description: Introduction to the surface integral

title: Flux in 3D (videos)
description: Conceptual understanding of flux across a two-dimensional surface

title: Green's theorem (videos)
description: Part 1 of the proof of Green's Theorem

title: 2D divergence theorem
description: Figuring out a unit normal vector at any point along a curve defined by a position vector function

title: Stokes' theorem (videos)
description: Conceptual understanding of why the curl of a vector field along a surface would relate to the line integral around the surface's boundary

title: 3D divergence theorem (videos)
description: Intuition behind the Divergence Theorem in three dimensions

title: Proof of Stokes' theorem
description: The beginning of a proof of Stokes' theorem for a special class of surfaces. Finding the curl of our vector field.

title: Types of regions in three dimensions
description: Definition of Type 1 regions.  Visualizing what is and isn't a Type I region

title: Divergence theorem proof
description: Setting up the proof for the divergence theorem

title: Intro to differential equations
description: Differential equations are equations that relate a function with one or more of its derivatives. This means their solution is a function! Learn more in this video.

title: Slope fields
description: Slope fields allow us to analyze differential equations graphically. Learn how to draw them and use them to find particular solutions.

title: Euler's Method
description: Euler's method is a numerical tool for approximating values for solutions of differential equations. See how (and why) it works.

title: Separable equations
description: "Separation of variables" allows us to rewrite differential equations so we obtain an equality between two integrals we can evaluate. Separable equations are the class of differential equations that can be solved using this method.

title: Exponential models
description: Assuming a quantity grows proportionally to its size results in the general equation dy/dx=ky. Solving it with separation of variables results in the general exponential function y=Ceᵏˣ.

title: Logistic models
description: Population should grow proportionally to its size, but it can't keep growing forever! Learn more about this problem, posed by Malthus, and embark on a journey towards its mathematical solution.

title: Exact equations and integrating factors
description: Chain rule using partial derivatives (not a proof; more intuition).

title: Homogeneous equations
description: Introduction to first order homogenous equations.

title: Linear homogeneous equations
description: Introduction to 2nd order, linear, homogeneous differential equations with constant coefficients.

title: Complex and repeated roots of characteristic equation
description: What happens when the characteristic equations has complex roots?!

title: Method of undetermined coefficients
description: Using the method of undetermined coefficients to solve nonhomogeneous linear differential equations.

title: Laplace transform
description: Introduction to the Laplace Transform

title: Properties of the Laplace transform
description: Useful properties of the Laplace Transform

title: Laplace transform to solve a differential equation
description: Using the Laplace Transform to solve an equation we already knew how to solve.

title: The convolution integral
description: Introduction to the Convolution

title: Vectors
description: A vector has both magnitude and direction. We use vectors to, for example, describe the velocity of moving objects. In this video, you'll learn how to write and draw vectors.

title: Linear combinations and spans
description: Understanding linear combinations and spans of vectors

title: Linear dependence and independence
description: Introduction to linear dependence and independence

title: Subspaces and the basis for a subspace
description: Introduction to linear subspaces of Rn

title: Vector dot and cross products
description: Definitions of the vector dot product and vector length

title: Matrices for solving systems by elimination
description: Sal solves a linear system with 3 equations and 4 variables by representing it with an augmented matrix and bringing the matrix to reduced row-echelon form.

title: Null space and column space
description: Defining and understanding what it means to take the product of a matrix and a vector

title: Functions and linear transformations
description: A more formal understanding of functions

title: Linear transformation examples
description: Creating scaling and reflection transformation matrices (which are diagonal)

title: Transformations and matrix multiplication
description: Introduction to compositions of Linear Transformations

title: Inverse functions and transformations
description: Introduction to the inverse of a function

title: Finding inverses and determinants
description: Determining a method for constructing inverse transformation matrices

title: More determinant depth
description: The determinant when a row is multiplied by a scalar

title: Transpose of a matrix
description: Transpose of a matrix

title: Orthogonal complements
description: Orthogonal Complements as subspaces.

title: Orthogonal projections
description: Projections onto subspaces

title: Change of basis
description: Understanding alternate coordinate systems

title: Orthonormal bases and the Gram-Schmidt process
description: Looking at sets and bases that are orthonormal -- or where all the vectors have length 1 and are orthogonal to each other.

title: Eigen-everything
description: What eigenvectors and eigenvalues are and why they are interesting

title: Fractions
description: Sal uses the Khan Academy number line widget.

title: Properties of numbers
description: Commutative Law of Addition
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Unit conversion
description: Learn to convert 37 centimeters to meters.

title: Area
description: Sal uses an area model to multiply 78x65.

title: Volume
description: Sal transitions from measuring volume with unit cubes to multiplying area times length.

title: Coordinate plane
description: Bridging algebra and geometry. What makes linear equations so linear.

title: Number patterns
description: Sal completes a pattern using a table and then graphs the results on a coordinate plane.

title: Variables and expressions
description: Basics of expression with two variables

title: Statistics
description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean, median, and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Probability
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Place value and decimals
description: Sal regroups 4500 different ways.

title: Multiplication and division
description: Learn to multiply 0.44 times 1000 using powers of 10.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Properties of numbers and order of operations
description: Commutative Law of Addition
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Number patterns
description: Sal uses factors and multiples to figure out days of the week.

title: Variables and equations
description: Basics of expression with two variables

title: Angles
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Perimeter and Area
description: Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape. Area measures the space inside a shape. Learn how to calculate perimeter and area for various shapes.

title: Triangles and Polygons
description: Learn to categorize triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.

title: Coordinate plane
description: Sal graphs ordered pairs, such as (8, 10) in quadrant 1 on a coordinate plane.

title: Transformations
description: Introduction to the concept of an "axis of symmetry"

title: Data
description: A line graph is way to visually represent data, especially data that changes over time.  Let's take a look at an example.

title: Probability
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Topic A: Multiplication and the meaning of the factors
description: Sal uses arrays and repeated addition to visualize multiplication.

title: Topic B: Division as an unknown factor problem
description: Sal uses an array and understanding of multiplication to divide.

title: Topic C: Multiplication using units of 2 and 3
description: Sal uses pictures and practice problems to see commutativity and associativity in multiplication.

title: Topic E: Multiplication and division using units of 4
description: Sal talks about the relationship between multiplication and division problems.

title: Topic F: Distributive property and problem solving using units of 2–5 and 10
description: Sal uses pictures and practice problems to see commutativity and associativity in multiplication.

title: Topic A: Time measurement and problem solving
description: Sal tells time on a labeled analog clock.

title: Topic B: Measuring weight and liquid volume in metric units
description: Sal talks about what mass means. He also examines the masses of real objects in grams and kilograms.

title: Topic C: Rounding to the nearest ten and hundred
description: Learn to use a number line to round 2-digit numbers to the nearest ten.

title: Topic D: Two- and three-digit measurement addition using the standard algorithm
description: Sal introduces place value using a toy with beads (an abacus).

title: Topic E: Two- and three-digit measurement subtraction using the standard algorithm
description: Sal adds and subtracts numbers like 585 and 368 using a number line. Numbers used in these problems are less than 1000.

title: Topic A: The properties of multiplication and division
description: Sal finds the missing number in multiplication and division equations.

title: Topic C: Multiplication and division using units up to 8
description: Sal uses arrays and repeated addition to multiply.

title: Topic D: Multiplication and division using units of 9
description: Learn about even and odd numbers, how to figure out if a number is even or odd, and what happens when you add them.

title: Topic E: Analysis of patterns and problem solving including units of 0 and 1
description: The identity property of 1 says that any number multiplied by 1 keeps its identity. In other words, any number multiplied by 1 stays the same. The reason the number stays the same is because multiplying by 1 means we have 1 copy of the number. For example, 32x1=32.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic A: Foundations for understanding area
description: Sal covers figures with square units to find their area.

title: Topic B: Concepts of area measurement
description: Lindsay finds the area of a shape by counting whole and partial unit squares.

title: Topic C: Arithmetic properties using area models
description: Sal uses the distributive property to find area of rectangles.

title: Topic D: Applications of area using side lengths of figures
description: Lindsay finds the area of an irregular shape by decomposing it into 2 rectangles.

title: Topic A: Partitioning a whole into equal parts
description: Sal divides wholes into equal-sized pieces to create unit fractions.

title: Topic B: Unit fractions and their relation to the whole
description: Sal uses fractions to name parts of a whole.

title: Topic C: Comparing unit fractions and specifying the whole
description: Sal shades visual fraction models to compare fractions.

title: Topic D: Fractions on the number line
description: Learn to graph and locate fractions on a number line.

title: Topic E: Equivalent fractions
description: Sal uses same-sized wholes to show equivalent fractions.

title: Topic F: Comparison, order, and size of fractions
description: Sal shades visual fraction models to compare fractions.

title: Topic A: Generate and analyze categorical data
description: Sal uses picture graphs to solve word problems.

title: Topic B: Generate and analyze measurement data
description: A line plot is a graph that displays data using a number line. To create a line plot, ​first create a number line that includes all the values in the data set. Next, place an X (or dot) above each data value on the number line. If a value occurs more than once in a data set, place ​an Xs​ over that number for each time it occurs.

title: Topic B: Attributes of two-dimensional figures
description: Sal discovers attributes and features of four-sided shapes, including parallelograms, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares.

title: Topic C: Problem solving with perimeter
description: Perimeter is the distance around the edge of a shape. Learn how to find the perimeter by adding up the side lengths of various shapes

title: Topic E: Problem solving with perimeter and area
description: Sal compares the areas and perimeters of rectangles to a given rectangle.

title: Topic A: Place value of multi-digit whole numbers
description: Sal solves multiplication comparison problems.

title: Topic C: Rounding multi-digit whole numbers
description: Sal rounds 24,259 to the nearest hundred.

title: Topic D: Multi-digit whole number addition
description: Learn to use regrouping, or carrying to add 536+398.

description: Sal discusses metric units of mass or weight such as milligram, gram, and kilogram.

description: Sal converts kilograms to milligrams and tons to ounces.

description: Sal uses place value, the distributive property, associative property, and an area model to show more ways to multiply.

description: Sal finds the factors of 120.
