description: Learn to multiply two-digit numbers.  In this video, we will multiply 36 times 27.

title: Topic A: Line and angles
description: Learn about geometry terms like point, line, and ray.  We will also learn how to label them.

title: Topic B: Angle measurement
description: Learn to measure angles as part of a circle.

title: Topic C: Problem solving with the addition of angle measures
description: Sal finds the measure of angles by adding or subtracting.

title: Topic D: Two-dimensional figures and symmetry
description: Introduction to the concept of an "axis of symmetry"

title: Topic A: Decomposition and fraction equivalence
description: Sal uses a tape diagram to decompose 7/9.

title: Topic B: Fraction equivalence using multiplication and division
description: Sal introduces equivalent fractions with pizza.

title: Topic C: Fraction comparison
description: Sal compares fractions with unlike denominators by drawing bars

title: Topic D: Fraction addition and subtraction
description: Sal adds 3/15+7/15.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic E: Extending fraction equivalence to fractions greater than 1
description: Sal multiplies 1/2 x 5 using repeated addition and fraction models.

title: Topic F: Addition and subtraction of fractions by decomposition
description: Sal adds 2 mixed numbers with common (like) denominators.

title: Topic G: Repeated addition of fractions as multiplication
description: Sal gives a visual explanation of multiplying a fraction and a whole number.

title: Topic A: Exploration of tenths
description: Sal introduces decimal numbers and understanding place value to the right of the decimal.

title: Topic B: Tenths and hundredths
description: Sal uses grid diagrams to determine what decimal is represented by a shaded area.

title: Topic C: Decimal comparison
description: Sal compares 0.17 and 0.2 using grid diagrams.

title: Topic D: Addition with tenths and hundredths
description: Decimals can be written in fraction form. To convert a decimal to a fraction, place the decimal number over its place value. For example, in 0.6, the six is in the tenths place, so we place 6 over 10 to create the equivalent fraction, 6/10. If needed, simplify the fraction.

title: Topic A: Measurement conversion tables
description: Sal converts between gallons, quarts, pints, cups, and fluid ounces.

title: Topic B: Problem solving with measurement
description: Sal discusses US customary units of mass or weight such as ounce, pound, and ton.

title: Topic A: Multiplicative patterns on the place value chart
description: Introduction to decimal place values and the value of decimal digits
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic B: Decimal fractions and place value patterns
description: Learn to write 905.074 in expanded form.

title: Topic C: Place value and rounding decimal fractions
description: Learn to round 9.564 to the nearest tenth.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic E: Multiplying decimals
description: Sal introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.

title: Topic F: Dividing decimals
description: Sal divides 63÷35.

title: Topic A: Mental strategies for multi-digit whole number multiplication
description: Sal decomposes multiples of ten to multiply.

title: Topic B: The standard algorithm for multi-digit whole number multiplication
description: Sal uses place value, the distributive property, associative property, and an area model to show more ways to multiply.

title: Topic C: Decimal multi-digit multiplication
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to multiply 2.91x3.2.

title: Topic D: Measurement word problems with whole number and decimal multiplication
description: There are 60 minutes in 1 hour. To convert from minutes to hours, divide the number of minutes by 60. For example, 120 minutes equals 2 hours because 120/60=2.

title: Topic A: Equivalent fractions
description: Sal introduces equivalent fractions with pizza.

title: Topic C: Making like units numerically
description: Sal adds 19 3/18 + 18 2/3 by rewriting each mixed number to have a common denominator.

title: Topic D: Further applications
description: Sal solves 1/4+3/5 -3/10 by rewriting each fraction to have a common denominator.

title: Topic A: Line plots of fraction measurements
description: Sal uses different bags of trail mix to find the amount of trail mix each bag would contain if the total amount in all the bags were redistributed equally.

title: Topic B: Fractions as division
description: Sal shows how a/b and a÷b are equivalent. That is, the fraction bar and the division symbol mean the same thing.

title: Topic D: Fraction expressions and word problems
description: Sal solves a word problem by constructing a numerical expression.

title: Topic E: Multiplication of a fraction by a fraction
description: Sal introduces multiplying 2 fractions.

title: Topic F: Multiplication with fractions and decimals as scaling and word problems
description: Sal compares the following expressions by thinking about multiplication as scaling: 2/3x7/8, 8/7x2/3, and (5x2)/(3x5)

title: Topic G: Division of fractions and decimal fractions
description: Sal uses fraction models and number lines to divide whole numbers by unit fractions.

title: Topic H: Interpretation of numerical expressions
description: Sal interprets written statements and writes them as mathematical expressions.

title: Topic A: Concepts of volume
description: Sal introduces volume and compares it to length and area.  He also introduces cube units.

title: Topic B: Volume and the operations of multiplication and addition
description: Sal finds the volume of a rectangular prism with labeled side lengths.

title: Topic D: Drawing, analysis, and classification of two-dimensional shapes
description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid, parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, and square.

title: Topic B: Patterns in the coordinate plane and graphing number patterns from rules
description: Sal completes a pattern using a table and then graphs the results on a coordinate plane.

title: Topic A: Representing and reasoning about ratios
description: A ratio is a comparison of two quantities.  Learn how to find the ratio between two things, for example apples to oranges.

title: Topic B: Collections of equivalent ratios
description: Sal uses double number lines to visualize equivalent ratios and describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.

title: Topic C: Unit rates
description: Sal introduces rates using examples like 35 miles per hour and 10 dollars per hour.

title: Topic D: Percents
description: Let's think about what percent really means by looking at a 10 by 10 grid.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic A: Dividing fractions by fractions
description: Using a number line, we'll explain why multiplying by the inverse is the same as dividing.

title: Topic B: Multi‐digit decimal operations—adding, subtracting, and multiplying
description: Sal solves 9.087+15.31 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Topic C: Dividing whole numbers and decimals
description: Learn to divide 9815÷65.  The answer does not have a remainder.

title: Topic D: Number theory—thinking logically about multiplicative arithmetic
description: Worked example of basic divisibility tests.

title: Topic A: Understanding positive and negative numbers on the number line
description: Mysterious negative numbers! What ARE they? They are numbers less than zero. If you understand the nature of below zero temperatures, you can understand negative numbers. We'll help.

title: Topic B: Order and absolute value
description: Sal puts -25, -30, -7, -10, and -40 in order from least to greatest.

title: Topic C: Rational numbers and the coordinate plane
description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points, lines, and more.

title: Topic B: Special notations of operations
description: Sal shows how exponents are repeated multiplication

title: Topic C: Replacing letters and numbers
description: Our focus here is understanding that a variable is just a symbol that can represent different values in an expression. We got this. Just watch.

title: Topic D: Expanding, factoring, and distributing expressions
description: Explore how the values of algebraic expressions like 100-x, 5/x + 5, and (3y)/(2y) change as the values of the variables change.

title: Topic E: Expressing operations in algebraic form
description: Sal writes an expression to represent 11 more than a.

title: Topic F: Writing and evaluating expressions and formulas
description: Learn how to evaluate an expression with variables using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic G: Solving equations
description: Learn what variables, expressions, and equations are.

title: Topic H: Applications of equations
description: Using information from the Super Yoga word problem, explore all the possible combinations and create equations which express the possibilities. Let's figure out which plan is best!

title: Topic A: Area of triangles, quadrilaterals, and polygons
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a parallelogram is base times height, just like the formula for the area of a rectangle.

title: Topic B: Polygons on the coordinate plane
description: Sal draws a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane using the coordinates of its vertices.

title: Topic C: Volume of right rectangular prisms
description: Another way of finding the volume of a rectangular prism involves dividing it into fractional cubes, finding the volume of one, and then multiplying that volume by the number of cubes that fit into our rectangular prism.

title: Topic A: Understanding distributions
description: Here are a few of the many ways to look at data. Which is your favorite?

title: Topic B: Summarizing a distribution that is approximately symmetric using the mean and mean absolute deviation
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Topic C: Summarizing a distribution that is skewed using the median and the interquartile range
description: The IQR describes the middle 50% of values when ordered from lowest to highest. To find the interquartile range (IQR), ​first find the median (middle value) of the lower and upper half of the data. These values are quartile 1 (Q1) and quartile 3 (Q3). The IQR is the difference between Q3 and Q1.

title: Topic D: Summarizing and describing distributions
description: Sal solves practice problems where he thinks about which data displays would be helpful in which situations.

title: Topic A: Proportional relationships
description: Sal introduces the idea of a proportional relationship by looking at tables of values.

title: Topic B: Unit rate and constant of proportionality
description: Sal introduces rates using examples like 35 miles per hour and 10 dollars per hour.

title: Topic C: Ratios and rates involving fractions
description: Sal solves an example problem with rates with fractions.

title: Topic D: Ratios of scale drawings
description: Sal uses virtual manipulatives to identify figures that scale proportionally.

title: Topic A: Addition and subtraction of integers and rational numbers
description: Use a number line to add -15 + (-46) + (-29)

title: Topic B: Multiplication and division of integers and rational numbers
description: Use the distributive property to understand the products of negative numbers.

title: Topic C: Applying operations with rational numbers to expressions and equations
description: Simplify this tricky expression using the order of operations.   Expression include negative numbers and exponents.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic A: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions
description: In simple addition we learned to add all the numbers together to get a sum. In algebra, numbers are sometimes attached to variables and we need to make sure that the variables are alike before we add the numbers.

title: Topic B: Solve problems using expressions, equations, and inequalities
description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

title: Topic C: Use equations and inequalities to solve geometry problems
description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

title: Topic A: Finding the whole
description: Percent means per-hundred.  Use that knowledge to solve problems like what percent of 16 is 4?

title: Topic B: Percent problems including more than one whole
description: We'll use algebra to solve this percent problem.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic C: Scale drawings
description: Sal uses virtual manipulatives to identify figures that scale proportionally.

title: Topic A: Calculating and interpreting probabilities
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Topic B: Estimating probabilities
description: Compare expected probabilities to what really happens when we run experiments.

title: Topic C: Random sampling and estimating population characteristics
description: To make a valid conclusion, you'll need a representaive, not skewed, sample.

title: Topic D: Comparing populations
description: Sal examines two distributions in dot plots to draw conclusions about the times of Olympic swimmers.

title: Topic A: Unknown angles
description: Two rays that share the same endpoint form an angle. Learn about angles and the parts of an angle, like the vertex.

title: Topic B: Constructing triangles
description: Can you build a triangle that is both a right triangle and an isosceles triangle?

title: Topic C: Slicing solids
description: What happens when you slice vertically into a rectangular pyramid? What kind of geometric shape results?

title: Topic D: Problems involving area and surface area
description: Learn how to find the circumference, the distance around a circle, when given the area.

title: Topic E: Problems involving volume
description: See if you can find the incremental volume of a ring in cubic inches. You'll need to put to use your knowledge of how to measure volume.

title: Topic A: Exponential notation and properties of integer exponents
description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video, we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Topic B: Magnitude and scientific notation
description: Scientific notation is a way of writing very large or very small numbers. A number is written in scientific notation when a number between 1 and 10 is multiplied by a power of 10. For example, 650,000,000 can be written in scientific notation as 6.5 ✕ 10^8.

title: Topic A: Definitions and properties of the basic rigid motions
description: how are virtual sets built in the computer?

title: Topic C: Congruence and angle relationships
description: Watch Sal work through a basic congruence and similarity problem.

title: Topic A: Dilation
description: Sal is given a rectangle on the coordinate plane and he draws the image of the rectangle under a dilation with scale factor 1 2/3 about an arbitrary point.

title: Topic B: Similar figures
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar, and how this follows from the definition of similarity.

title: Topic C: The Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Topic A: Writing and solving linear equations
description: Worked example: Learn to solve the equation 2x + 3 = 5x - 2.

title: Topic B: Linear equations in two variables and their graphs
description: Sal compares a rate given in an equation to a rate shown on a graph.

title: Topic C: Slope and equations of lines
description: Sal determines the x-intercept of a linear equation from a graph. Afterwards, he checks his work by plugging values back into the equation.

title: Topic D: Systems of linear equations and their solutions
description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Topic A: Functions
description: Functions assign a single output for each of their inputs. In this video, we see examples of various kinds of functions.

title: Topic B: Volume
description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h, and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

title: Topic A: Linear functions
description: Learn to recognize if a function is linear.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic B: Bivariate numerical data
description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

title: Topic C: Linear and nonlinear models
description: Sal discusses how we would go about making sense of the direction of a linear graph that represents a relationship between two real-world quantities.

title: Topic D: Bivariate categorical data
description: Sal uses a Venn diagram to introduce two-way frequency tables.

title: Topic A: Square and cube roots
description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Topic B: Decimal expansions of numbers
description: Learn how to rewrite 19/27 as a repeating decimal. What's a repeating decimal? THAT is a great question. This video explains.

title: Topic A: Lessons 1-3: Piecewise, quadratic, and exponential functions
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. Some functions have simple rules, like "for every x, return x²." However, there can be other rules that are more elaborate. For example, "If x<0, return 2x, and if x≥0, return 3x." These are called *piecewise functions*, because their rules aren't uniform, but consist of multiple pieces

title: Topic A: Lessons 4-5: Analyzing graphs
description: When a function models a real-world context, we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video, we consider a graph that models temperature over time.

title: Topic B: Lesson 8: Adding and subtracting polynomials with 2 variables
description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3x² - 2y) + (8xy - 3x² + 2x²y + 4).

title: Topic B: Lesson 9: Multiplying monomials
description: Learn how to multiply monomials like 5x² * 4x⁶ or 4p³ * p.

title: Topic C: Lessons 10-13: Solving Equations
description: A solution to an equation makes that equation true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an equation true.

title: Topic C: Lesson 14: Solving inequalities
description: A solution to an inequality makes that inequality true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an inequality true.

title: Topic C: Lessons 15-16 Compound inequalities
description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5z+7<27 OR -3z≤18.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic C: Lesson 20: Solution sets to equations with two variables
description: Learn about a class of equations in two variables that's called "linear equations." They are called that way because their graph is a line. These are the most basic and probably most useful equations you will ever know!

title: Topic C: Lesson 21: Solution sets to inequalities with two variables
description: Sal checks if the ordered pairs (3,5) and (1,-7) are solutions of the inequality 5x-3y≥25.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic C: Lesson 22: Solution sets to simultaneous equations
description: Sal checks whether (-1,7) is a solution of the system: x+2y=13 and 3x-y=-11.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic C: Lesson 23: Solution sets to simultaneous equations
description: Sal uses simple elimination to figure out how many cupcakes are eaten by children and adults.

title: Topic C: Lesson 24: Applications of systems of equations and inequalities
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

title: Topic D: Creating equations to solve problems
description: Sal solves two related proportion word problems about a squirrel crossing the road and a car that approaches it. He does that using dimensional analysis.

title: Topic A: Lesson 1: Dot plots and histograms
description: Here are a few of the many ways to look at data. Which is your favorite?

title: Topic A: Lesson 1: Box plots and shape
description: Learn how to create a box plot. The data set used in this example has 11 data points.

title: Topic A: Lesson 2: Describing the center of a distribution
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Topic A: Lesson 3: Estimating centers and interpreting the mean as a balance point
description: Sal compares the means of two different distributions given as dot plots.

title: Topic B: Lessons 5-6: Standard deviation and variability
Topic B: Lesson 7: Measuring variability for skewed distributions (interquartile range)
description: The IQR describes the middle 50% of values when ordered from lowest to highest. To find the interquartile range (IQR), ​first find the median (middle value) of the lower and upper half of the data. These values are quartile 1 (Q1) and quartile 3 (Q3). The IQR is the difference between Q3 and Q1.

title: Topic B: Lesson 8: Comparing distributions
description: Sal examines two distributions in dot plots to draw conclusions about the times of Olympic swimmers.

title: Topic C: Lessons 9-10: Bivariate categorical data
description: Sal uses a Venn diagram to introduce two-way frequency tables.

title: Topic C: Lesson 11: Conditional relative frequencies and association
description: Learn how to read two-way tables.

title: Topic D: Lessons 12-13: Relationships between two numerical variables
description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

title: Topic D: Lesson 14: Modeling relationships with a line
description: Sal creates a scatter plot and then fits a line to data on the median California family income.

title: Topic A: Lessons 1-3: Arithmetic sequence intro
description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms"), like 2,5,8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example, 2,5,8 follows the pattern "add 3," and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example, 2,5,8,... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Topic A: Lessons 1-3: Geometric sequence intro
description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio.

title: Topic A: Lessons 4-6: Exponential growth
description: In exponential functions the variable is in the exponent, like y=3ˣ. Here we introduce this concept with a few examples.

title: Topic A: Lesson 7: Exponential decay
description: Analyzing the features of exponential graphs through the example of y=5ˣ.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic B: Lessons 8-12: Functions intro
description: Functions assign a single output for each of their inputs. In this video, we see examples of various kinds of functions.

title: Topic B: Lessons 8-12: Function domain and range
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. The domain of a function is the set of all possible inputs for the function. For example, the domain of f(x)=x² is all real numbers, and the domain of g(x)=1/x is all real numbers except for x=0. We can also define special functions whose domains are more limited.

title: Topic B: Lessons 8-12:  Recognizing functions
description: Checking whether a given set of points can represent a function. For the set to represent a function, each domain element must have one corresponding range element at most.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic B: Lesson 13: Interpreting the graph of a function
description: Function values can be positive or negative, and they can increase or decrease as the input increases. Here we introduce these basic properties of functions.

title: Topic C: Lesson 15: Piecewise functions
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. Some functions have simple rules, like "for every x, return x²." However, there can be other rules that are more elaborate. For example, "If x<0, return 2x, and if x≥0, return 3x." These are called *piecewise functions*, because their rules aren't uniform, but consist of multiple pieces

title: Topic A: Lessons 1-2: Common factor
description: Sal finds the greatest common factor of 10cd^2 and 25c^3d^2.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic A: Lessons 3-4: Special forms
description: Sal factors 45x^2-125 as 5(3x+5)(3x-5).

title: Topic A: Lessons 3-4: Factoring by grouping
description: Sal introduces the method of grouping, which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.

title: Topic A: Lessons 6-7: Solving basic one-variable quadratic equations
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+3=75 by isolating x^2 and taking the square root of both sides.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic B: Lessons 11-13: Completing the square
description: Some quadratic expressions can be factored as perfect squares. For example, x²+6x+9=(x+3)². However, even if an expression isn't a perfect square, we can turn it into one by adding a constant number. For example, x²+6x+5 isn't a perfect square, but if we add 4 we get (x+3)². This, in essence, is the method of *completing the square*

title: Topic B: Lessons 14-15: The quadratic formula
description: With the quadratic formula, we can solve any quadratic equation! Learn how to use it with an example.

title: Topic B: Lesson 16: Graphing quadratic equations from the vertex form
description: One of the common forms for quadratic functions is called vertex form, because it highlights the coordinates of the vertex of the function's graph.

title: Topic B: Lesson 17: Graphing quadratic functions from the standard form
description: Sal rewrites the equation y=-5x^2-20x+15 in vertex form (by completing the square) in order to identify the vertex of the corresponding parabola.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic C: Lessons 18-19: Translating graphs of functions
description: Sal discusses how we can shift and scale the graph of a parabola to obtain any other parabola, and how this affects the equation of the parabola.

title: Topic A: Basic constructions
description: Sal constructs a line that bisects a given angle using compass and straightedge.

title: Topic B: Lesson 6: Solve for unknown angles—angles and lines at a point
description: Given algebraic expressions that represent a pair of two vertical angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Topic B: Lesson 7: Solve for unknown angles—transversals
description: Learn about parallel lines, transversals, and the angles they form.

title: Topic B: Lesson 8: Solve for unknown angles—angles in a triangle
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Topic C: Lesson 12: Transformations—The next level
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Topic C: Lesson 13: Rotations
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, and he manually draws the image of that rotation.

title: Topic C: Lesson 14: Reflections
description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane and the definition of a reflection, and he draws the image of the segments under that reflection.

title: Topic C: Lesson 15: Rotations, reflections, and symmetry
description: Introduction to the concept of an "axis of symmetry"

title: Topic C: Lesson 16: Translations
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation, and he draws the image of the triangle under that translation.

title: Topic C: Lessons 17-21: Applications of transformations
Topic D: Lessons 22-25: Congruence criteria
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

title: Topic D: Lessons 26-27: Triangle congruency proofs
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Topic E:  Proving properties of geometric figures
description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: Topic B: Dilations
description: Sal shows how to perform a dilation on a hexagon using our interactive widget!

title: Topic C: Lessons 12-14: Similarity intro
description: Sal is given pairs of polygons, and then he determines whether they are similar by trying to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations.

title: Topic C: Lessons 15-17: Triangle similarity
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar, and how this follows from the definition of similarity.

title: Topic C: Lessons 18-20: Similarity applications
description: Sal introduces the angle-bisector theorem and proves it.

title: Topic D: Applying similarity to right triangles
description: Roots are nice, but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So, for example, instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer, like √20? Still, we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5, which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Topic E: Lessons 25-26: Trigonometry intro
description: Sal introduces sine, cosine, and tangent, and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.

title: Topic E: Lesson 27: Sine and cosine of complementary angles and special angles
description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Topic E: Lessons 28-31: Trigonometry applications
description: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.

title: Topic E: Lessons 32-33: Laws of sines and cosines
description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Topic A: Area
description: Sal covers figures with square units to find their area.

title: Topic B: Lessons 5-9: Volume properties
description: In a three-dimensional space, a plane can be defined by three points it contains, as long as those points are not on the same line. Learn more about it in this video.

title: Topic B: Lessons 10-13: Volume formulas
description: Using the formulas for the volume of triangular prism and cube to solve some solid geometry problems.

title: Topic A: Rectangular and triangular regions defined by inequalities
description: Learn how to graph two-variable linear inequalities like y≤4x+3.

title: Topic B: Perpendicular and parallel lines in the Cartesian plane
description: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Topic D: Partitioning and extending segments and parameterization of lines
description: Learn how to use the midpoint formula to find the midpoint of a line segment on the coordinate plane, or find the endpoint of a line segment given one point and the midpoint.

title: Topic B: Lessons 9-10: Arc length and sector area
description: Finding the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.

title: Topic D: Equations for circles and their tangents
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Topic A: Polynomials—from base ten to base X
description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding how to rewrite quotients like that is *polynomial long division*.

title: Topic B: Lessons 12-13: Factorization
description: Sal factors 35k^2+100k-15 as 5(k+3)(7k-1).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic B: Lesson 14: Graphing factored polynomials
description: Sal uses the zeros of y=x^3+3x^2+x+3 to determine its corresponding graph.

title: Topic B: Lesson 15: Structure in graphs of polynomial functions
description: Sal explains what it means for a function to be even, odd, or neither, both algebraically and graphically.

title: Topic B: Lessons 16-21: Remainder theorem and modeling
description: The Polynomial Remainder Theorem allows us to determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a polynomial expression easily. Check it out!

title: Topic C: Lessons 22-23: Simplifying rational expressions
description: Sal explains what it means to simplify a rational expression and why we would want to do that. Just don't forget the excluded values!

title: Topic C: Lessons 26-27: Rational equations
description: Sal solves the equation (14x+4)/(-3x-2)=8.

title: Topic C: Lessons 28-29: Radical equations
description: Sal explains what square-root equations are, and shows an example of solving such an equation and checking for extraneous solutions.

title: Topic C: Lesson 30: Linear systems in three variables
description: Sal discusses how we approach solving systems of three variables algebraically, and how we visualize it graphically.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic C: Lesson 31: Systems of equations
description: Sal solves a system of a quadratic equation and a linear equation by graphing both equations and looking for their intersections, and then checks the solution algebraically.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic C: Lessons 33-35: Parabolas
description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.

title: Topic D: Lesson 37: Complex numbers intro
description: Sal introduces the imaginary unit i, which is defined by the equation i^2=-1. He then gets to know this special number better by thinking about its powers.

title: Topic D: Lesson 37: Complex number operations
description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic D: Lessons 38-40: Complex roots and the fundamental theorem of algebra
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+5=6x using the quadratic formula, and finds that the solutions are complex numbers.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic A: Lessons 1-7: Unit circle definition of trig functions
description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine, cosine, and tangent for all real numbers.

title: Topic A: Lessons 8-10: Trigonometric graphs and radians
description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic B: Lesson 11: Graphing sinusoidal functions
description: Sal graphs y=2*sin(-x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and a horizontal reflection of y=sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic B: Lesson 11: Features of sinusoidal graphs
description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.

title: Topic B: Lessons 12-13: Modeling with sinusoidal functions
description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2,-5) and the maximum point (2,1) are highlighted.

title: Topic B: Lesson 14: Graphing the tangent function
description: Sal draws the graph of the tangent function based on the unit circle definition of the function.

title: Topic B: Lessons 15-17: Trigonometric identities
description: Sal proves the Pythagorean identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1 for all real numbers.

title: Topic A: Lesson 2: Scientific notation
description: Can you imagine if you had to do calculations with very, very small numbers? How would you handle all those zeros to the right of the decimal? Thank goodness for scientific notation!
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic A: Lessons 3-6: Rational exponents
description: What does it mean to take a number by a power which is a unit fraction? For example, what is the result of 3 raised to ½?

title: Topic B: Lessons 10-12: Logarithm properties
description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for addition and subtraction of logarithms.

title: Topic B: Lesson 13: Changing the base
description: Sal approximates log₅(100) by rewriting it as log(100)/log(5) using the change of base rule, then evaluates with a calculator.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic B: Lessons 13-15: Logarithms and equations
description: Sal solves the equation 10^(2t-3)=7.

title: Topic C: Lesson 16: Rational and Irrational Numbers
description: Learn how to find the approximate values of square roots. The examples used in this video are √32, √55, and √123. The technique used is to compare the squares of whole numbers to the number we're taking the square root of.

title: Topic C: Lessons 17-22: Graphs of exponential and logarithmic functions
description: Sal rewrites 100=10^2 as a logarithmic equation and log_5(1/125)=-3 as an exponential equation.

title: Topic E: Lesson 29: Geometric series
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Topic A: Lesson 1: Chance experiments, sample spaces, and events
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Topic A: Lessons 2-4: Two-way tables, conditional probability, and independence
description: Sal solves a conditional probability example where he thinks about probabilities like P(A | B) where the events are about lunch and breakfast!

title: Topic A: Lessons 5-7: Venn diagrams and probability rules
description: Sal shows examples of intersection and union of sets and introduces some set notation.

title: Topic B: Lesson 8: Distributions—Center, shape, and spread
description: Some distributions are symmetrical, with data evenly distributed about the mean. Other distributions are "skewed," with data tending to the left or right of the mean. We sometimes say that skewed distributions have "tails."

title: Topic B: Lessons 10-11: Normal distributions
description: Z-score practice

title: Topic C: Lesson 12: Types of statistical studies
description: Types of statistical studies

title: Topic C: Lesson 13: Using sample data to estimate a population characteristic
description: Identifying a sample and population

title: Topic C: Lessons 18-19: Sampling variability in the sample mean
description: Much of statistics is based upon using data from a random sample that is representative of the population at large. From that sample mean, we can infer things about the greater population mean. We'll explain.

title: Topic D: Lesson 23: Experiments and the role of random assignment
description: Types of statistical studies

title: Topic A: Lessons 1-6: Complex numbers review
description: The imaginary unit i is defined such that i²=-1. So what's i³? i³=i²⋅i=-i. What's i⁴? i⁴=i²⋅i²=(-1)²=1. What's i⁵? i⁵=i⁴⋅i=1⋅i=i. This pattern repeats itself all the time, so we can quickly tell what iⁿ for any positive integer n.

title: Topic A: Lessons 7-8: Complex number division
description: Sal explains what is the conjugate of a complex number, and shows how the product of a complex number and its conjugate is always a real number.

title: Topic B: Lessons 9-12: Distance and midpoint of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the distance between (2+3i) and (-5-i) and then he finds their midpoint on the complex plane.

title: Topic B: Lesson 13: Trigonometry and complex numbers
description: Sal finds the absolute value of (3-4i).

title: Topic B: Lessons 14-17: Multiplying and dividing complex numbers in polar form
description: Sal shows how complex division affects the modulus and the argument of the divisor and the dividend.

title: Topic C: Lessons 18-19: Exploiting the connection to trigonometry
description: Sal simplifies the 20th power of a complex number given in polar form.

title: Topic C: Lessons 21-23: Transforming vectors with matrices
description: Take the red pill and enter the Matrix!

title: Topic C: Lesson 24: Matrix notation encompasses new transformations!
description: Sal transforms a triangle using a 2x2 matrix.

title: Topic C: Lesson 25: Properties of matrix addition
description: Sal defines what it means to add or subtract matrices. He shows a few examples and discusses some important properties of matrix addition and subtraction.

title: Topic C: Lesson 25: Properties of matrix multiplication
description: Just as any number remains the same when multiplied by 1, any matrix remains the same when multiplied by the identity matrix. Learn more from Sal.

title: Topic C: Lessons 26-30: Matrix inverses
description: Sal shows how to find the determinant of a 2x2 matrix.

title: Topic C: Systems of linear equations
description: Sal shows how a system of two linear equations can be represented with the equation A*x=b where A is the coefficient matrix, x is the variable vector, and b is the constant vector.

title: Topic D: Lessons 17-18: Vectors in the coordinate plane
description: The difference between vectors and scalars. ​Introduction to distance, displacement, speed, and velocity.

title: Topic D: Lessons 23-24: Why are vectors useful?
Topic A: Lesson 1: Solutions to polynomial equations
description: Sal factors p(x)=2x^5+x^4-2x-1 as (2x+1)(x^4-1) using grouping. Then he further factors (x^4-1) as (x^2+1)(x+1)(x-1) using the special product form of difference of squares.

title: Topic A: Lessons 2-3: Roots of complex numbers
description: Sal simplifies the 20th power of a complex number given in polar form.

title: Topic A: Lessons 4-5: The binomial theorem
description: Sal explains what's the binomial theorem, why it's useful, and how to use it.

title: Topic A: Lessons 6-7: Ellipses
description: Sal introduces ellipses and shows how their standard equation relates to their center and radii (ellipses have two radii: major and minor).

title: Topic A: Lesson 8: Hyperbolas
description: Sal introduces the standard equation for hyperbolas, and how it can be used in order to determine the direction of the hyperbola and its vertices.

title: Topic B: Lessons 10-11: Simplifying rational expressions
description: Sal explains what it means to simplify a rational expression and why we would want to do that. Just don't forget the excluded values!

title: Topic B: Lessons 14-15: Graphing rational functions
description: Sal analyzes the function f(x)=(3x^2-18x-81)/(6x^2-54) and determines its horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities.

title: Topic B: Lessons 16-17: Function composition
description: Sal explains what it means to compose two functions. He gives examples for finding the values of composite functions given the equations, the graphs, or tables of values of the two composed functions.

title: Topic C: Lesson 18: Inverse functions
description: Sal explains what inverse functions are. Then he explains how to algebraically find the inverse of a function and looks at the graphical relationship between inverse functions.

title: Topic C: Lessons 20-21: Inverse relationship of exponentials and logarithms
description: Sal rewrites 100=10^2 as a logarithmic equation and log_5(1/125)=-3 as an exponential equation.

title: Topic A: Lessons 1-2: Special values and properties of trigonometric functions
description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.

title: Topic A: Lessons 3-4: Addition and subtraction formulas
description: Sal reviews all the different trigonometric angle addition identities: sin(a+b), sin(a-c), cos(a+b), cos(a-b), cos(2a), and sin(2a).

title: Topic B: Trigonometry and triangles
description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Topic C: Inverse trigonometric functions
description: Sal introduces arcsine, which is the inverse function of sine, and discusses its principal range.

title: Topic A: Lesson 1: The general multiplication rule
description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Topic A: Lesson 2: Counting rules—The fundamental counting principle and permutations
description: Tree diagrams display all the possible outcomes of an event. Each branch in a tree diagram represents a possible outcome. Tree diagrams can be used to find the number of possible outcomes and calculate the probability of possible outcomes.

title: Topic A: Lesson 3: Counting rules—Combinations
description: Sal introduces the basic idea of combinations.

title: Topic A: Lesson 4: Using permutations and combinations to compute probabilities
description: A different way to think about the probability of getting 2 heads in 4 flips

title: Topic B: Lessons 5-6: Discrete random variables
description: Basic idea and definitions of random variables

title: Topic B: Lessons 9-12: Creating probability distributions
description: Sal breaks down how to create the probability distribution of the number of "heads" after 3 flips of a fair coin.

title: Topic C: Lessons 13-19: Applications of expected value and probability
description: Understanding an insurance company's sense of my chances of dying.

title: Topic A, B, C, D, E, & F: Foundations
description: Sal solves word problems by adding the same number many times.

title: Topic A: Foundations
description: Sal measures objects with a ruler.

title: Topic B: Foundations
description: Sal estimates the length of an object when given the length of another object.

title: Topic C: Foundations
description: Sal compares 394 and 397.

title: Topic D & E: Foundations
description: Sal adds 3-digit numbers by adding ones, tens, and hundreds.

title: Topic A, C, D, & E: Foundations
description: Sal solves an addition word problem with numbers less than 100.

title: Topic B: Foundations
description: Sal adds 53+17 by breaking apart the numbers and making a group of 10.

title: Topic F: Foundations
description: Sal uses the number 37 to explain why we use a "ones place" and a "tens place" when writing numbers.

title: Topic A: Foundations
description: Sal measures objects with a ruler.

title: Topic B, C, & D: Foundations
description: Sal solves word problems by adding the same number many times.

title: Topic A, B, C, D, E, & F: Foundations
description: Sal determines if shapes are divided into 2 or 4 equal sections.

title: Topic A: Foundations
description: Sal solves length word problems with addition and subtraction.

title: Topic B: Foundations

description: Dividing two fractions is the same as multiplying the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second fraction. The first step to dividing fractions is to find the reciprocal (reverse the numerator and denominator) of the second fraction. Next, multiply the two numerators. Then, multiply the two denominators. Finally, simplify the fractions if needed.

title: Topic B: Foundations
description:
How to multiply fractions?

The first step when multiplying fractions is to multiply the two numerators. The second step is to multiply the two denominators. Finally, simplify the new fractions. The fractions can also be simplified before multiplying by factoring out common factors in the numerator and denominator. Simplifying before multiplying helps avoid dealing with large numbers.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Topic A: Foundations
description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

title: Topic B & C: Foundations
description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points, lines, and more.

title: Linear equations with variables on both sides
description: We will use a scale to try to achieve balance and help explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation, even when the variable appears on both sides.

title: Linear equations with parentheses
description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Analyzing the number of solutions to linear equations
description: See how some equations have one solution, others have no solutions, and still others have infinite solutions.

title: Multi-step inequalities
description: Sal solves the inequality -3p-7<p+9, draws the solution on a number line and checks a few values to verify the solution.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Compound inequalities
description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5z+7<27 OR -3z≤18.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Rate conversion
description: Sal shows how we can treat units of measurement algebraically, and use these tools in order to convert between different units of the same quantity.

title: Word problems with multiple units
description: Sal solves two related proportion word problems about a squirrel crossing the road and a car that approaches it. He does that using dimensional analysis.

title: Two-variable linear equations intro
description: Learn about a class of equations in two variables that's called "linear equations." They are called that way because their graph is a line. These are the most basic and probably most useful equations you will ever know!

title: x-intercepts and y-intercepts
description: Learn what x- and y-intercepts are.  The equations used in this video are y = 0.5x - 3 and 5x + 6y = 30.

title: Slope
description: Sal shows how to find the slope of a line.

title: Horizontal & vertical lines
description: When two points have the same y-value, it means they lie on a horizontal line. The slope of such a line is 0, and you will also find this by using the slope formula.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Intro to slope-intercept form
description: Slope-intercept form, y=mx+b, of linear equations, emphasizes the slope and the y-intercept of the line. Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Graphing slope-intercept equations
description: To graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form, we can use the information given by that form. For example, y=2x+3 tells us that the slope of the line is 2 and the y-intercept is at (0,3). This gives us one point the line goes through, and the direction we should continue from that point to draw the entire line.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Writing slope-intercept equations
description: Learn to write equations in slope-intercept form for three different lines.

title: Point-slope form
description: Point-slope is the general form y-y₁=m(x-x₁) for linear equations. It emphasizes the slope of the line and a point on the line (that is not the y-intercept). Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Standard form
description: The standard form for linear equations in two variables is Ax+By=C. For example, 2x+3y=5 is a linear equation in standard form. When an equation is given in this form, it's pretty easy to find both intercepts (x and y). This form is also very useful when solving systems of two linear equations.

title: Evaluating functions
description: Functions assign a single output for each of their inputs. In this video, we see examples of various kinds of functions.

title: Inputs and outputs of a function
description: Sal finds the input value for which f(t)=13, given that f(t)=-2t+5.

title: Functions and equations
description: Equations and functions are not the same thing, but they can be related in several ways. Watch Jesse Roe and Sal talk about the difference between equations and functions

title: Interpreting function notation
description: Learn how to interpret expressions that contain a function within a real-world context. In this video, the function we interpret models an account balance over time.

title: Introduction to the domain and range of a function
description: Introducing intervals, which are bounded sets of numbers and are very useful when describing domain and range.

title: Determining the domain of a function
description: Finding the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Recognizing functions
description: Checking whether a given set of points can represent a function. For the set to represent a function, each domain element must have one corresponding range element at most.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Maximum and minimum points
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing
description: Function values can be positive or negative, and they can increase or decrease as the input increases. Here we introduce these basic properties of functions.

title: Interpreting features of graphs
description: When a function models a real-world context, we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video, we consider a graph that models temperature over time.

title: Average rate of change
description: What's the average rate of change of a function over an interval?

title: Average rate of change word problems
description: Average rate of change tells us how much the function changed per a single time unit, over a specific interval. It has many real-world applications. In this video, we compare the average rate of change of temperature over different time periods.

title: Interpreting linear functions and equations
description: Sal finds the slope of a linear relationship between the number of work hours and the money earned. He then interprets what this slope means in that context.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Comparing linear functions
description: Sal is given the formula of a linear function and the graph of another, and is asked to determine which function increases faster.

title: Constructing linear models for real-world relationships
description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a truck's fuel consumption, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

title: Linear models word problems
description: Sal solves a word problem about a person reading a book, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

title: Systems of equations overview
description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Introduction to systems of equations
description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method
description: Sal uses simple elimination to figure out how many cupcakes are eaten by children and adults.

title: Solving systems of equations with substitution
description:
To solve a system of equations using substitution...
1. Isolate one of the variables in one of the equations, e.g. rewrite 2x+y=3 as y=3-2x.
2. You can now express the isolated variable using the other one. *Substitute* that expression into the second equation, e.g. rewrite x+2y=5 as x+2(3-2x)=5.
3. Now you have an equation with one variable! Solve it, and use what you got to find the other variable.

title: Number of solutions to systems of equations
description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

title: Systems of equations word problems
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

title: Checking solutions of two-variable inequalities
description: Sal checks if the ordered pairs (3,5) and (1,-7) are solutions of the inequality 5x-3y≥25.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphing two-variable inequalities
description: Learn how to graph two-variable linear inequalities like y≤4x+3.

title: Creating and interpreting scatterplots
description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

title: Estimating with trend lines
description: Sal solves a problem where he has to estimate the line of best fit for a scatter plot.

title: Displays of distributions
description: Learn to organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).

title: Summarizing center of distributions (central tendency)
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Box and whisker plots
description: Here's a word problem that's perfectly suited for a box and whiskers plot to help analyze data. Let's construct one together, shall we?
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Comparing distributions
description: Sal examines two distributions in dot plots to draw conclusions about the times of Olympic swimmers.

title: Two-way relative frequency tables
description: Worked example video where we are asked to find a two-way table of column relative frequencies.

title: Introduction to arithmetic sequences
description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms"), like 2,5,8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example, 2,5,8 follows the pattern "add 3," and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example, 2,5,8,... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Introduction to geometric sequences
description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio.

title: Radicals
description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Rational exponents intro
description: What does it mean to take a number by a power which is a unit fraction? For example, what is the result of 3 raised to ½?

title: Advanced exponent & radical evaluation
description: Sal shows how to evaluate 64^(2/3) and (8/27)^(-2/3).

title: Simplifying square roots
description: Roots are nice, but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So, for example, instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer, like √20? Still, we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5, which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Simplifying radicals (higher-index roots)
description: Multiple examples of simplifications of higher-index radicals. For example, simplifying ⁵√96 as 2⁵√3.

title: Exponential vs. linear growth
description: In exponential functions the variable is in the exponent, like y=3ˣ. Here we introduce this concept with a few examples.

title: Graphs of exponential growth
description: Analyzing the features of exponential graphs through the example of y=5ˣ.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Introduction to rigid transformations
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Translations
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation, and he draws the image of the triangle under that translation.

title: Rotations
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, and he manually draws the image of that rotation.

title: Reflections
description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane and the definition of a reflection, and he draws the image of the segments under that reflection.

title: Dilations
description: Sal shows how to perform a dilation on a hexagon using our interactive widget!

title: Properties & definitions of transformations
description: Sal is given information about a transformation in terms of a few pairs of points and their corresponding images, and he determines what kind of transformation it can be.

title: Symmetry
description: Introduction to the concept of an "axis of symmetry"

title: Transformations & congruence
description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are congruent by mapping one onto the other using rigid transformations.

title: Triangle congruence
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

title: Theorems concerning triangle properties
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Working with triangles
description: We write the letters of congruent triangles so their order tells us which parts are corresponding. In this video, Sal uses this notation to solve some angles.

title: Theorems concerning quadrilateral properties
description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: Proofs of general theorems that use triangle congruence
description: Sal proves that a point is the midpoint of a segment using triangle congruence.

title: Constructing bisectors of lines & angles
description: Sal constructs a perpendicular bisector to a given line segment using compass and straightedge.

title: Distance and midpoints
description: Learn how to find the distance between two points by using the distance formula, which is an application of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Dividing line segments
description: Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio. A graph is given to make it easier to visualize the problem.

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane
description: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Coordinate plane proofs
description: Watch Sal classify a quadrilateral as a square, rhombus, rectangle, parallelogram, or trapezoid given its four vertices.

title: Piecewise functions
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. Some functions have simple rules, like "for every x, return x²." However, there can be other rules that are more elaborate. For example, "If x<0, return 2x, and if x≥0, return 3x." These are called *piecewise functions*, because their rules aren't uniform, but consist of multiple pieces

title: Adding & subtracting polynomials
description: Sal simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding & subtracting polynomials: two variables
description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3x² - 2y) + (8xy - 3x² + 2x²y + 4).

title: Multiplying monomials
description: Learn how to multiply monomials like 5x² * 4x⁶ or 4p³ * p.

title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials
description: Sal expresses the product (10a-3)(5a² + 7a - 1) as 50a³+55a²-31a+3.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Polynomials word problems
description: Sal finds the volume of a tank whose base has an area of 3x² + 30x + 5 square feet and whose height is 8x - 5 feet.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Long division of polynomials
description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding how to rewrite quotients like that is *polynomial long division*.

title: Synthetic division of polynomials
description: Sal shows how synthetic division of polynomials works.

title: Practice dividing polynomials with remainders
description: Sal divides (18x^4-3x^2+6x-4) by 6x.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors
description: Sal shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).

title: Evaluating expressions with unknown variables
description: Sal solved a few examples where we need to evaluate an expression, but we don't know the individual variable values.

title: Factoring quadratics by grouping
description: Sal introduces the method of grouping, which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.

title: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms
description: Sal factors 35k^2+100k-15 as 5(k+3)(7k-1).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Factoring polynomials with special product forms
description: Sal factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Polynomial Remainder Theorem
description: The Polynomial Remainder Theorem allows us to determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a polynomial expression easily. Check it out!

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+3=75 by isolating x^2 and taking the square root of both sides.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Quadratic vertex form
description: One of the common forms for quadratic functions is called vertex form, because it highlights the coordinates of the vertex of the function's graph.

title: Solving quadratics by factoring
description: Sal solves the equation s^2-2s-35=0 by factoring the expression on the left as (s+5)(s-7) and finding the s-values that make each factor equal to zero.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Completing the square
description: Some quadratic expressions can be factored as perfect squares. For example, x²+6x+9=(x+3)². However, even if an expression isn't a perfect square, we can turn it into one by adding a constant number. For example, x²+6x+5 isn't a perfect square, but if we add 4 we get (x+3)². This, in essence, is the method of *completing the square*

title: The quadratic formula
description: With the quadratic formula, we can solve any quadratic equation! Learn how to use it with an example.

title: Quadratic standard form
description: Sal rewrites the equation y=-5x^2-20x+15 in vertex form (by completing the square) in order to identify the vertex of the corresponding parabola.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Features & forms of quadratic functions
description: Different forms of quadratic functions reveal different features of those functions. Here, Sal rewrites f(x)=x²-5x+6 in factored form to reveal its zeros and in vertex form to reveal its vertex.

title: Transforming parabolas
description: Sal discusses how we can shift and scale the graph of a parabola to obtain any other parabola, and how this affects the equation of the parabola.

title: Irrational numbers
description: Learn what rational and irrational numbers are and how to tell them apart.

title: Sums & products of rational/irrational numbers
description: Sal proves that the sum, or the product, of any two rational numbers will always be a rational number.

title: Proofs concerning irrational numbers
description: Sal proves that the square root of 2 is an irrational number, i.e. it cannot be given as the ratio of two integers.

title: What are the imaginary numbers?
description: Sal introduces the imaginary unit i, which is defined by the equation i^2=-1. He then gets to know this special number better by thinking about its powers.

title: What are the complex numbers?
description: Sal explains how we obtain complex numbers by adding real numbers and imaginary numbers.

title: The complex plane
description: Sal shows how to plot various numbers on the complex plane.

title: Adding & subtracting complex numbers
description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multiplying complex numbers
description: Sal multiplies (1-3i) by (2+5i).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Equivalent forms of exponential expressions
description: Sal simplifies the expression 10*9^(0.5t+2)*5^(3t) as 810*375^t.

title: Modeling with one-variable equations & inequalities
description: Sal models a context that concerns the number and price of pizza slices. The model turns out to be a rational equation.

title: Manipulating formulas
description: Sal rewrites the formula for the perimeter of a rectangle so it is solved for width.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Definitions of similarity
description: Sal is given pairs of polygons, and then he determines whether they are similar by trying to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations.

title: Introduction to triangle similarity
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar, and how this follows from the definition of similarity.

title: Solving similar triangles
description: Sal solves two problems where a missing side length is found by proving that triangles are similar and using this to find the measure.

title: Angle bisector theorem
description: Sal introduces the angle-bisector theorem and proves it.

title: Solving problems with similar & congruent triangles
description: Sal uses the similarity of triangles and the congruence of others in this multi-step problem to find the area of a polygon.

title: Solving modeling problems with similar & congruent triangles
description: Triangle similarity, the Golden ratio, and art, all converge in this inspiring video!

title: Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Pythagorean theorem proofs
description: James Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean Theorem.

title: Special right triangles
description: Introduction to 45-45-90 Triangles

title: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal introduces sine, cosine, and tangent, and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.

title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Modeling with right triangles
description: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.

title: Trigonometric ratios & similarity
description: Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Sine & cosine of complementary angles
description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Solid geometry intro
description: Using the formulas for the volume of triangular prism and cube to solve some solid geometry problems.

title: Density
description: Sal solves a word problem about the number of passengers a blimp can carry, using his knowledge of volume and density.

title: 2D vs. 3D objects
description: What happens when you slice vertically into a rectangular pyramid? What kind of geometric shape results?

title: Circle basics
description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs

title: Arc length (degrees)
description: Finding the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: Arc length (radians)
description: Sal finds the fraction of an arc length out of the entire circumference using the radian measure of the central angle subtended by the arc.

title: Sectors
description: A worked example of finding the area of a circle's sector using the area of the circle and the central angle of the sector.

title: Area of inscribed triangle
description: Sal proves that if a radius in a circle is drawn so it bisects a chord, then the radius is also perpendicular to that chord. The proof uses SSS congruence.

title: Constructing regular polygons inscribed in circles
description: Sal constructs a square that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Constructing circumcircles & incircles
description: Sal constructs a circle that inscribes a given triangle using compass and straightedge.

title: Constructing a line tangent to a circle
description: Sal constructs a line tangent to a circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Introduction to conic sections
description: Sal introduces the four conic sections and shows how they are derived by intersecting planes with cones in certain ways.

title: Standard equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Expanded equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.

title: Focus & directrix of a parabola
description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.

title: Probability basics
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Counting with combinations
description: Sal introduces the basic idea of combinations.

title: Probability with counting, permutations, combinations
description: The probability of getting exactly 2 heads when flipping three coins. Thinking about this by visualy depicting all of the outcomes.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multiplication rule for independent events
description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Multiplication rule for dependent events
description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.

title: Addition rule for probability
description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.

title: Combining functions
description: Given that f(x)=9-x^2 and g(x)=5x^2+2x+1, Sal finds (f+g)(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Composing functions
description: Sal explains what it means to compose two functions. He gives examples for finding the values of composite functions given the equations, the graphs, or tables of values of the two composed functions.

title: Modeling situations by combining & composing functions
description: Sal models the height of a tower on top of a tree, by adding the functions that model the growth of the tower and the tree separately.

title: Stretching functions
description: Sal walks through several examples of how to write g(x) implicitly in terms of f(x) when g(x) is a shift or a reflection of f(x).

title: Introduction to inverses of functions
description: Sal explains what inverse functions are. Then he explains how to algebraically find the inverse of a function and looks at the graphical relationship between inverse functions.

title: Finding inverse functions
description: Sal finds the inverses of f(x)=-x+4 and g(x)=-2x-1.

title: Binomial theorem
description: Sal explains what's the binomial theorem, why it's useful, and how to use it.

title: Understanding the binomial theorem
description: Sal explains why we use the combinatorial formula for (n choose k) to expand binomial expressions.

title: Advanced polynomial factorization methods
description: Sal factors p(x)=2x^5+x^4-2x-1 as (2x+1)(x^4-1) using grouping. Then he further factors (x^4-1) as (x^2+1)(x+1)(x-1) using the special product form of difference of squares.

title: Proving polynomial identities
description: Sal considers two cases of polynomial identities and their proofs.

title: Polynomial identities with complex numbers
description: Learn how expressions of the form x^2+y^2 can be factored into linear factors. This would not be possible without the aid of complex numbers!
