title: Quadratic equations with complex numbers
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+5=6x using the quadratic formula, and finds that the solutions are complex numbers.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Fundamental theorem of Algebra
description: Sal introduces the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, which, as is reflected in its name, is a very important theorem about polynomials.

title: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs
description: Sal uses the zeros of y=x^3+3x^2+x+3 to determine its corresponding graph.

title: End behavior of polynomial functions
description: Sal explains what "end behavior" is and what affects the end behavior of polynomial functions.

title: Introduction to symmetry of functions
description: Sal explains what it means for a function to be even, odd, or neither, both algebraically and graphically.

title: Square-root equations
description: Sal explains what square-root equations are, and shows an example of solving such an equation and checking for extraneous solutions.

title: Cube-root equations
description: Sal solves the equation -∛y=4∛y+5.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Domain of radical functions
description: Finding the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphs of radical functions
description: Sal shows various examples of functions and their graphs that are a result of shifting and/or flipping y=√x.

title: Simplifying rational expressions
description: Sal explains what it means to simplify a rational expression and why we would want to do that. Just don't forget the excluded values!

title: Nested fractions
description: Sal starts with a simple case of multiplying two fractions and proceeds to simplifying a nested fraction expression.

title: Rational equations
description: Sal solves the equation (14x+4)/(-3x-2)=8.

title: Direct and inverse variation
description: Sal explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.

title: Graphs of rational functions
description: Sal analyzes the function f(x)=(3x^2-18x-81)/(6x^2-54) and determines its horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities.

title: Modeling with rational functions
description: Sal solves a word problem about the unknown number of bears, cats, and dogs in a pet store. This is part 1 where Sal uses a visual reasoning.

title: Introduction to logarithms
description: Sal explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.

title: The constant e and the natural logarithm
description: Sal introduces a very special number in the world of math (and beyond!), the constant 𝑒.

title: Properties of logarithms
description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for addition and subtraction of logarithms.

title: Change of base formula for logarithms
description: Sal approximates log₅(100) by rewriting it as log(100)/log(5) using the change of base rule, then evaluates with a calculator.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Exponential equations: logarithms
description: Sal solves the equation 10^(2t-3)=7.

title: Graphs of logarithmic functions
description: Sal graphs y=2^x and y=log_2(x) on the same coordinate plane, showing how they relate as graphs of inverse functions.

title: Logarithmic scale (optional)
description: Vi Hart and Sal talk about how we humans perceive things nonlinearly

title: Law of sines
description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Law of cosines
description: Learn how to use the law of cosines to find the missing side length of a triangle when given two side lengths and the contained angle measure.

title: Solving general triangles
description: Sal solves a word problem about the distance between stars using the law of cosines.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: Unit circle definition of sine, cosine, & tangent
description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine, cosine, and tangent for all real numbers.

title: Graphs of sine, cosine, & tangent
description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Basic trigonometric identities
description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.

title: Trigonometric values of special angles
description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.

title: Pythagorean identity
description: Sal proves the Pythagorean identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1 for all real numbers.

title: Introduction to amplitude, midline, & extrema of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.

title: Finding amplitude & midline from formula
description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Period of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphing sinusoidal functions
description: Sal graphs y=2*sin(-x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and a horizontal reflection of y=sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Constructing sinusoidal functions
description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2,-5) and the maximum point (2,1) are highlighted.

title: Systems of quadratic equations
description: Sal solves a system of a quadratic equation and a linear equation by graphing both equations and looking for their intersections, and then checks the solution algebraically.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Interpreting the symmetry of algebraic models
description: Sal interprets the significance of modeling function being even.

title: Comparing features of functions
description: Given several functions represented in different forms (as a formula, as a graph, and as a table of values), Sal finds the one with that has no x-intercepts.

title: Basic sigma notation
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Finite geometric series
description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn more about it here.

title: Finite geometric series applications
description: Watch Sal solve an example of using a geometric series to answer a fun word problem.

title: Samples and surveys
description: To make a valid conclusion, you'll need a representaive, not skewed, sample.

title: Binomial probability
description: Sal calculates the probability of making 2 shots out of 6 using the binomial distribution.

title: Normal distributions
description: Using the empirical rule (or 68-95-99.7 rule) to estimate probabilities for normal distributions

title: Numbers 0 to 120
description: Sal goes through all the numbers from 0 to 100 and shows some interesting patterns.

title: Ones and tens
description: Sal uses the number 37 to explain why we use a "ones place" and a "tens place" when writing numbers.

title: Comparing 2-digit numbers
description: Greater than and less than symbols can be used to compare numbers and expressions. The greater than symbol is >. So, 9>7 is read as '9 is greater than 7'. The less than symbol is <. Two other comparison symbols are ≥ (greater than or equal to) and ≤ (less than or equal to).

title: Hundreds
description: Sal introduces place value using a toy with beads (an abacus).

title: Comparing 3-digit numbers
description: Sal compares 394 and 397.

title: Rounding
description: Learn to use a number line to round 2-digit numbers to the nearest ten.

title: Intro to place value
description: Sal finds the place value of 3 in 4356.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Ways to write whole numbers (expanded form and written form)
description: Sal writes 14,897 in expanded form.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Regrouping whole numbers
description: Sal regroups 4500 different ways.

title: Rounding whole numbers
description: Sal rounds 24,259 to the nearest hundred.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Basic addition and subtraction
description: Introduction to addition. Learn multiple visual ways to represent addition.

title: Making 10
description: Sal shows how to add two numbers to make 10. He uses 3 + ___ = 10 and 6 + ___ = 10 as examples.

title: Addition and subtraction word problems within 10
description: Sal solves word problems by adding small numbers (numbers 10 or less).

title: Addition and subtraction within 20
description: Sal adds 8 + 7 by making a group of ten.

title: Word problems within 20
description: Sal solves 1 addition and 1 subtraction word problem.

title: Word problems with "more" and "fewer"
description: Sal solves word problems comparing 2 numbers.  Numbers in the problems are less than 10.

title: Intro to addition with 2-digit numbers
description: Sal adds 71 + 24.

title: Intro to subtraction with 2-digit numbers
description: Sal subtracts 23 from 65 by thinking about tens and ones.

title: Strategies for adding and subtracting within 100
description: Sal adds 53+17 by breaking apart the numbers and making a group of 10.

title: Addition within 100
description: Sal adds 23 + 45 thinking about place value.

title: Subtraction within 100
description: Sal subtracts 23 from 65 by thinking about tens and ones.

title: Word problems within 100
description: Sal uses number lines to solve addition and subtraction word problems with numbers less than 100.

title: Adding 1s, 10s, and 100s
description: Sal adds 1, 10, or 100 to a number.

title: Subtracting 1s, 10s, and 100s
description: Sal subtracts 1, 10, or 100 from a number.

title: Strategies for adding 2- and 3-digit numbers
description: Sal shows ways to break up addition problems using place value.

title: Addition with regrouping within 1000
description: Learn to use regrouping to add 536+398.

title: Subtraction with regrouping within 1000
description: Learn to use regrouping (borrowing) and place value to subtract 971-659.

title: Addition and subtraction missing value problems
description: Sal solves for the missing number in problems like ___ + 261 = 630.

title: Multiplication intro
description: Sal uses arrays and repeated addition to visualize multiplication.

title: Multiplication facts
description: Introduction to the multiplication 'times tables' from 2-9.

title: Properties of multiplication
description: Sal uses pictures and practice problems to see commutativity and associativity in multiplication.

title: Multiplying by tens
description: Sal decomposes multiples of ten to multiply.

title: Multiplication: place value and area models
description: Sal uses place value, the distributive property, associative property, and an area model to show more ways to multiply.

title: Multi-digit multiplication
description: Learn to multiply a 2-digit number by a 1-digit number without regrouping.  In this video, we will multiply 32x3.

title: Relating multiplication and division
description: Sal talks about the relationship between multiplication and division problems.

title: Division intro
description: Sal uses an array and understanding of multiplication to divide.

title: Division: place value and area
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to divide 5600÷8 and 846÷2.

title: Multi-digit division (no remainders)
description: Watch an introduction to long division with the problem 96÷4.

title: Remainders
description: Sal shows how a remainder is what's left over in a division problem.

title: Multi-digit division (remainders)
description: Introduction to long division with remainders

title: Intro to negative numbers
description: Mysterious negative numbers! What ARE they? They are numbers less than zero. If you understand the nature of below zero temperatures, you can understand negative numbers. We'll help.

title: Number opposites
description: Learn about number opposites like 3 and -3 or -4 and 4 using a number line.

title: Absolute value
description: Learn how to find the absolute value of 5, -10, and 12.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Intro to adding negative numbers
description: Use a number line to add -15 + (-46) + (-29)
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Intro to subtracting negative numbers
description: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers. The problems solved in this video are 2 - 3 = -1 and -2 - 3 = -5 and -2 + 3 = 1 and 2 - (-3) = 5 and -2 - (-3).

title: Adding & subtracting negative numbers
description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding & subtracting with negatives on the number line
description: Sal shows how to model 6 + (-2) using vertical number lines.

title: Multiplying & dividing negative numbers
description: Learn some rules of thumb for multiplying positive and negative numbers.

title: Fractions intro
description: Sal divides wholes into equal-sized pieces to create unit fractions.

title: What fractions mean
description: Sal uses fractions to name parts of a whole.

title: Fractions on the number line
description: Learn to graph and locate fractions on a number line.

title: Fractions and whole numbers
description: Sal uses fraction models and a number line to represent 1 as a fraction.

title: Comparing fractions
description: Sal shades visual fraction models to compare fractions.

title: Equivalent fractions 1
description: Sal uses same-sized wholes to show equivalent fractions.

title: Equivalent fractions on the number line
description: Sal uses number lines and fraction models to show equivalent fractions.

title: Equivalent fractions 2
description: Sal introduces equivalent fractions with pizza.

title: Common denominators
description: Rewrite 2/8 and 5/6 to have the same denominator.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Decomposing fractions
description: Sal uses a tape diagram to decompose 7/9.

title: Adding and subtracting fractions with like denominators
description: Sal adds 3/15+7/15.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Mixed numbers
description: Sal rewrites 5 1/4 as an improper fraction.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding and subtracting mixed numbers
description: Sal adds 2 mixed numbers with common (like) denominators.

title: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators
description: Sal adds fractions like 3/4 and 1/5.

title: Adding and subtracting mixed number with unlike denominators
description: Sal adds 19 3/18 + 18 2/3 by rewriting each mixed number to have a common denominator.

title: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators word problems
description: Sal solves a word problem by adding mixed numbers with unlike denominators.

title: Multiplying unit fractions and whole numbers
description: Sal multiplies 1/2 x 5 using repeated addition and fraction models.

title: Multiplying whole numbers and fractions
description: Sal gives a visual explanation of multiplying a fraction and a whole number.

title: Multiplication as scaling
description: Sal compares the following expressions by thinking about multiplication as scaling: 2/3x7/8, 8/7x2/3, and (5x2)/(3x5)

title: Multiplying fractions
description: Sal introduces multiplying 2 fractions.

title: Multiplying mixed numbers
description: Sal introduces multiplying mixed numbers.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multiplying fractions word problems
description: Sal solves a word problem by multiplying 2 fractions.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Fractions as division
description: Sal shows how a/b and a÷b are equivalent. That is, the fraction bar and the division symbol mean the same thing.

title: Dividing fractions by fractions
description: Using a number line, we'll explain why multiplying by the inverse is the same as dividing.

title: Dividing fractions word problems
description: Dividing a whole number by a fraction? Turn the tables and multiply by the reciprocal of the fraction. Boom!
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Intro to decimals
description: Sal introduces decimal numbers and understanding place value to the right of the decimal.

title: Decimal place value intro
description: Introduction to decimal place values and the value of decimal digits
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Decimals on the number line
description: Sal compares decimals on a number line.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Rewriting decimals as fractions
description: Sal shows the connection between decimals and fractions using a grid diagram and number lines.

title: Adding decimals: standard algorithm
description: Sal solves 9.087+15.31 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Subtracting decimals
description: Sal subtracts 9.57-8.09 using "standard algorithm".

title: Subtracting decimals: standard algorithm
description: Just like when add, be sure you align decimals before subtracting.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems
description: Here's a simple word problem asking us to put our adding decimals skill to work.

title: Multiplying decimals
description: Sal introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.

title: Multiplying decimals: standard algorithm
description: Sometimes multiplying really small decimals (with all those zeros!) can be a little intimidating. Watch as we show you a handy trick to simplify these problems and solve them.

title: Dividing decimals
description: Sal divides 63÷35.

title: Dividing decimals: standard algorithm
description: Decimal divisors in the hundredths place can be a little confusing. In this video we'll show you how to move the decimal and make it a whole number. Pretty nifty! Watch.

title: Significant figures
description: Significant figures refers to the number of important single digits in a value, often a measurement.  This video is an introduction to significant figures.

title: Overview and history of algebra
description: Where did the word "Algebra" and its underlying ideas come from?

title: Introduction to variables
description: Our focus here is understanding that a variable is just a symbol that can represent different values in an expression. We got this. Just watch.

title: Substitution and evaluating expressions
description: We've done a few examples together where we were faced with 1 variable. Why not try one that has 2 variables?

title: Evaluating expressions word problems
description: In this example we have a formula for converting Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit. Let's substitute the variable with a value (Celsius temp) to get the degrees in Fahrenheit. Great problem to practice with us!
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Writing algebraic expressions introduction
description: Sal writes an expression to represent 11 more than a.

title: Introduction to equivalent algebraic expressions
description: Sal finds equivalent expressions by combining like terms and using the distributive property.

title: Dependent & independent variables
description: Identifying the dependent and the independent variables in a word problem.

title: Combining like terms
description: In simple addition we learned to add all the numbers together to get a sum. In algebra, numbers are sometimes attached to variables and we need to make sure that the variables are alike before we add the numbers.

title: Interpreting linear expressions
description: We match the expressions to their meaning in this example. We're reinforcing our knowledge of linear expressions.

title: Irrational numbers
description: Learn what rational and irrational numbers are and how to tell them apart.

title: Sums and products of rational and irrational numbers
description: Sal proves that the sum, or the product, of any two rational numbers will always be a rational number.

title: Proofs concerning irrational numbers
description: Sal proves that the square root of 2 is an irrational number, i.e. it cannot be given as the ratio of two integers.

title: Division by zero
description: As much as we would like to have an answer for "what's 1 divided by 0?" it's sadly impossible to have an answer. The reason, in short, is that whatever we may answer, we will then have to agree that that answer times 0 equals to 1, and that cannot be ​true, because anything times 0 is 0.

title: Algebraic equations basics
description: Learn what variables, expressions, and equations are.

title: Why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation
description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.

title: One-step addition & subtraction equations
description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.

title: One-step multiplication & division equations
description: Let's ease into this, shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!

title: Two-steps equations intro
description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

title: Two-step equation word problems
description: Learn how to construct and solve a basic linear equation to solve a word problem.

title: Linear equations with variables on both sides
description: We will use a scale to try to achieve balance and help explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation, even when the variable appears on both sides.

title: Linear equations with parentheses
description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Analyzing the number of solutions to linear equations
description: See how some equations have one solution, others have no solutions, and still others have infinite solutions.

title: Linear equations word problems
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: The sum of 4 consecutive odd integers is 136. What are the 4 integers?

title: Old school equations with Sal
description: equations of the form AX=B

title: Introduction to inequalities with variables
description: A solution to an inequality makes that inequality true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an inequality true.

title: One-step inequalities
description: Our discussion of linear inequalities begins with multiplying and dividing by negative numbers. Listen closely for the word "swap." Super important!

title: Two-step inequalities
description: Two-step inequalities are slightly more complicated than one-step inequalities (duh!). This is a worked example of solving ⅔>-4y-8⅓.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multi-step inequalities
description: Sal solves the inequality -3p-7<p+9, draws the solution on a number line and checks a few values to verify the solution.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Compound inequalities
description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5z+7<27 OR -3z≤18.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Two-variable linear equations intro
description: Learn about a class of equations in two variables that's called "linear equations." They are called that way because their graph is a line. These are the most basic and probably most useful equations you will ever know!

title: x-intercepts and y-intercepts
description: Learn what x- and y-intercepts are.  The equations used in this video are y = 0.5x - 3 and 5x + 6y = 30.

title: Slope
description: Sal shows how to find the slope of a line.

title: Horizontal & vertical lines
description: When two points have the same y-value, it means they lie on a horizontal line. The slope of such a line is 0, and you will also find this by using the slope formula.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Intro to slope-intercept form
description: Slope-intercept form, y=mx+b, of linear equations, emphasizes the slope and the y-intercept of the line. Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Graphing slope-intercept equations
description: To graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form, we can use the information given by that form. For example, y=2x+3 tells us that the slope of the line is 2 and the y-intercept is at (0,3). This gives us one point the line goes through, and the direction we should continue from that point to draw the entire line.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Writing slope-intercept equations
description: Learn to write equations in slope-intercept form for three different lines.

title: Point-slope form
description: Point-slope is the general form y-y₁=m(x-x₁) for linear equations. It emphasizes the slope of the line and a point on the line (that is not the y-intercept). Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Standard form
description: The standard form for linear equations in two variables is Ax+By=C. For example, 2x+3y=5 is a linear equation in standard form. When an equation is given in this form, it's pretty easy to find both intercepts (x and y). This form is also very useful when solving systems of two linear equations.

title: Interpreting linear functions and equations
description: Sal finds the slope of a linear relationship between the number of work hours and the money earned. He then interprets what this slope means in that context.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Comparing linear functions
description: Sal is given the formula of a linear function and the graph of another, and is asked to determine which function increases faster.

title: Constructing linear models for real-world relationships
description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a truck's fuel consumption, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

title: Linear models word problems
description: Sal solves a word problem about a person reading a book, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

title: Introduction to arithmetic sequences
description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms"), like 2,5,8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example, 2,5,8 follows the pattern "add 3," and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example, 2,5,8,... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Introduction to geometric sequences
description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio.

title: Systems of equations overview
description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Introduction to systems of equations
description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method
description: Sal uses simple elimination to figure out how many cupcakes are eaten by children and adults.

title: Solving systems of equations with substitution
description:
To solve a system of equations using substitution...
1. Isolate one of the variables in one of the equations, e.g. rewrite 2x+y=3 as y=3-2x.
2. You can now express the isolated variable using the other one. *Substitute* that expression into the second equation, e.g. rewrite x+2y=5 as x+2(3-2x)=5.
3. Now you have an equation with one variable! Solve it, and use what you got to find the other variable.

title: Number of solutions to systems of equations
description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

title: Systems of equations word problems
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

title: Systems with three variables
description: Sal discusses how we approach solving systems of three variables algebraically, and how we visualize it graphically.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Checking solutions of two-variable inequalities
description: Sal checks if the ordered pairs (3,5) and (1,-7) are solutions of the inequality 5x-3y≥25.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphing two-variable inequalities
description: Learn how to graph two-variable linear inequalities like y≤4x+3.

title: Evaluating functions
description: Functions assign a single output for each of their inputs. In this video, we see examples of various kinds of functions.

title: Inputs and outputs of a function
description: Sal finds the input value for which f(t)=13, given that f(t)=-2t+5.

title: Functions and equations
description: Equations and functions are not the same thing, but they can be related in several ways. Watch Jesse Roe and Sal talk about the difference between equations and functions

title: Interpreting function notation
description: Learn how to interpret expressions that contain a function within a real-world context. In this video, the function we interpret models an account balance over time.

title: Introduction to the domain and range of a function
description: Introducing intervals, which are bounded sets of numbers and are very useful when describing domain and range.

title: Determining the domain of a function
description: Finding the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Recognizing functions
description: Checking whether a given set of points can represent a function. For the set to represent a function, each domain element must have one corresponding range element at most.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Piecewise functions
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. Some functions have simple rules, like "for every x, return x²." However, there can be other rules that are more elaborate. For example, "If x<0, return 2x, and if x≥0, return 3x." These are called *piecewise functions*, because their rules aren't uniform, but consist of multiple pieces

title: Maximum and minimum points
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing
description: Function values can be positive or negative, and they can increase or decrease as the input increases. Here we introduce these basic properties of functions.

title: Interpreting features of graphs
description: When a function models a real-world context, we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video, we consider a graph that models temperature over time.

title: Average rate of change
description: What's the average rate of change of a function over an interval?

title: Average rate of change word problems
description: Average rate of change tells us how much the function changed per a single time unit, over a specific interval. It has many real-world applications. In this video, we compare the average rate of change of temperature over different time periods.

title: Combining functions
description: Given that f(x)=9-x^2 and g(x)=5x^2+2x+1, Sal finds (f+g)(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Composing functions (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal explains what it means to compose two functions. He gives examples for finding the values of composite functions given the equations, the graphs, or tables of values of the two composed functions.

title: Stretching functions
description: Sal walks through several examples of how to write g(x) implicitly in terms of f(x) when g(x) is a shift or a reflection of f(x).

title: Modeling situations by combining and composing functions (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal models the height of a tower on top of a tree, by adding the functions that model the growth of the tower and the tree separately.

title: Introduction to inverses of functions (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal explains what inverse functions are. Then he explains how to algebraically find the inverse of a function and looks at the graphical relationship between inverse functions.

title: Finding inverse functions (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal finds the inverses of f(x)=-x+4 and g(x)=-2x-1.

title: Determining the domain of advanced functions (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal covers many different kinds of functions and shows how to determine their domain.

title: Determining the range of a function (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal finds the domain and the range of f(x)=3x^2+6x-2.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphing nonlinear piecewise functions (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal is given the graph of a piecewise function and several possible formulas. He determines which is the correct formula.

title: Interpreting the symmetry of algebraic models (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal interprets the significance of modeling function being even.

title: Comparing features of functions (Algebra 2 level)
description: Given several functions represented in different forms (as a formula, as a graph, and as a table of values), Sal finds the one with that has no x-intercepts.

title: Two-variable functions
description: Sal solves a few problems where a new operator is defined and Sal evaluates some expression with it.

title: Solving absolute value equations
description: Absolute value equations are equations where the variable is within an absolute value operator, like |x-5|=9. The challenge is that the absolute value of a number depends on the number's sign: if it's positive, it's equal to the number: |9|=9. If the number is negative, then the absolute value is its opposite: |-9|=9. So when we're dealing with a variable, we need to consider both cases.

title: Solving absolute value inequalities
description: Sal introduces the concept of inequalities that contain absolute value expressions, and solves a bunch of examples.

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+3=75 by isolating x^2 and taking the square root of both sides.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Quadratic vertex form
description: One of the common forms for quadratic functions is called vertex form, because it highlights the coordinates of the vertex of the function's graph.

title: Solving quadratics by factoring
description: Sal solves the equation s^2-2s-35=0 by factoring the expression on the left as (s+5)(s-7) and finding the s-values that make each factor equal to zero.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Completing the square
description: Some quadratic expressions can be factored as perfect squares. For example, x²+6x+9=(x+3)². However, even if an expression isn't a perfect square, we can turn it into one by adding a constant number. For example, x²+6x+5 isn't a perfect square, but if we add 4 we get (x+3)². This, in essence, is the method of *completing the square*

title: The quadratic formula
description: With the quadratic formula, we can solve any quadratic equation! Learn how to use it with an example.

title: Quadratic standard form
description: Sal rewrites the equation y=-5x^2-20x+15 in vertex form (by completing the square) in order to identify the vertex of the corresponding parabola.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Features & forms of quadratic functions
description: Different forms of quadratic functions reveal different features of those functions. Here, Sal rewrites f(x)=x²-5x+6 in factored form to reveal its zeros and in vertex form to reveal its vertex.

title: Transforming parabolas
description: Sal discusses how we can shift and scale the graph of a parabola to obtain any other parabola, and how this affects the equation of the parabola.

title: Systems of quadratic equations
description: Sal solves a system of a quadratic equation and a linear equation by graphing both equations and looking for their intersections, and then checks the solution algebraically.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Quadratic inequalities
description: Sal solves x^2+3x>10.

title: Adding & subtracting polynomials
description: Sal simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Adding & subtracting polynomials: two variables
description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3x² - 2y) + (8xy - 3x² + 2x²y + 4).

title: Multiplying monomials
description: Learn how to multiply monomials like 5x² * 4x⁶ or 4p³ * p.

title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials
description: Sal expresses the product (10a-3)(5a² + 7a - 1) as 50a³+55a²-31a+3.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Polynomials word problems
description: Sal finds the volume of a tank whose base has an area of 3x² + 30x + 5 square feet and whose height is 8x - 5 feet.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors
description: Sal shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).

title: Evaluating expressions with unknown variables
description: Sal solved a few examples where we need to evaluate an expression, but we don't know the individual variable values.

title: Factoring quadratics by grouping
description: Sal introduces the method of grouping, which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.

title: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms
description: Sal factors 35k^2+100k-15 as 5(k+3)(7k-1).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Factoring polynomials with special product forms
description: Sal factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Long division of polynomials
description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding how to rewrite quotients like that is *polynomial long division*.

title: Synthetic division of polynomials
description: Sal shows how synthetic division of polynomials works.

title: Practice dividing polynomials with remainders
description: Sal divides (18x^4-3x^2+6x-4) by 6x.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Polynomial Remainder Theorem
description: The Polynomial Remainder Theorem allows us to determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a polynomial expression easily. Check it out!

title: Binomial theorem
description: Sal explains what's the binomial theorem, why it's useful, and how to use it.

title: Understanding the binomial theorem
description: Sal explains why we use the combinatorial formula for (n choose k) to expand binomial expressions.

title: Advanced polynomial factorization methods
description: Sal factors p(x)=2x^5+x^4-2x-1 as (2x+1)(x^4-1) using grouping. Then he further factors (x^4-1) as (x^2+1)(x+1)(x-1) using the special product form of difference of squares.

title: Proving polynomial identities
description: Sal considers two cases of polynomial identities and their proofs.

title: Polynomial identities with complex numbers
description: Learn how expressions of the form x^2+y^2 can be factored into linear factors. This would not be possible without the aid of complex numbers!

title: Quadratic equations with complex numbers
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+5=6x using the quadratic formula, and finds that the solutions are complex numbers.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
description: Sal introduces the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, which, as is reflected in its name, is a very important theorem about polynomials.

title: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs
description: Sal uses the zeros of y=x^3+3x^2+x+3 to determine its corresponding graph.

title: End behavior of polynomial functions
description: Sal explains what "end behavior" is and what affects the end behavior of polynomial functions.

title: Introduction to symmetry of functions
description: Sal explains what it means for a function to be even, odd, or neither, both algebraically and graphically.

title: Radicals
description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Rational exponents intro
description: What does it mean to take a number by a power which is a unit fraction? For example, what is the result of 3 raised to ½?

title: Advanced exponent & radical evaluation
description: Sal shows how to evaluate 64^(2/3) and (8/27)^(-2/3).

title: Simplifying square roots
description: Roots are nice, but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So, for example, instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer, like √20? Still, we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5, which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Simplifying radicals (higher-index roots)
description: Multiple examples of simplifications of higher-index radicals. For example, simplifying ⁵√96 as 2⁵√3.

title: Exponential vs. linear growth
description: In exponential functions the variable is in the exponent, like y=3ˣ. Here we introduce this concept with a few examples.

title: Graphs of exponential growth
description: Analyzing the features of exponential graphs through the example of y=5ˣ.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Equivalent forms of exponential expressions
description: Sal simplifies the expression 10*9^(0.5t+2)*5^(3t) as 810*375^t.

title: Introduction to rate of exponential growth and decay
description: Two word problem examples: one about a radioactive decay, and the other the exponential growth of a fast-food chain.

title: Introduction to logarithms (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.

title: The constant e and the natural logarithm (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal introduces a very special number in the world of math (and beyond!), the constant 𝑒.

title: Properties of logarithms (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for addition and subtraction of logarithms.

title: The change of base formula for logarithms (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal approximates log₅(100) by rewriting it as log(100)/log(5) using the change of base rule, then evaluates with a calculator.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Logarithmic equations (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal solves the equation log(x)+log(3)=2log(4)-log(2).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Solving exponential equations with logarithms (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal solves the equation 10^(2t-3)=7.

title: Graphs of logarithmic functions (Algebra 2 level)
description: Sal graphs y=2^x and y=log_2(x) on the same coordinate plane, showing how they relate as graphs of inverse functions.

title: Logarithmic scale (Algebra 2 level)
description: Vi Hart and Sal talk about how we humans perceive things nonlinearly

title: Solving square-root equations
description: Sal explains what square-root equations are, and shows an example of solving such an equation and checking for extraneous solutions.

title: Solving cube-root equations
description: Sal solves the equation -∛y=4∛y+5.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Domain of radical functions
description: Finding the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphs of radical functions
description: Sal shows various examples of functions and their graphs that are a result of shifting and/or flipping y=√x.

title: Simplifying rational expressions
description: Sal explains what it means to simplify a rational expression and why we would want to do that. Just don't forget the excluded values!

title: Nested fractions
description: Sal starts with a simple case of multiplying two fractions and proceeds to simplifying a nested fraction expression.

title: Solving rational equations
description: Sal solves the equation (14x+4)/(-3x-2)=8.

title: Direct and inverse variation
description: Sal explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.

title: Graphs of rational functions
description: Sal analyzes the function f(x)=(3x^2-18x-81)/(6x^2-54) and determines its horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities.

title: Modeling with rational functions
description: Sal solves a word problem about the unknown number of bears, cats, and dogs in a pet store. This is part 1 where Sal uses a visual reasoning.

title: Rational inequalities
description: Sal shows two ways to solve the inequality (x-1)/(x+2)>0.

title: Partial fraction expansion
description: Sal explains what partial fraction expansion is by rewriting (x²-2x-37)/(x²-3x-40) as the sum of 1 and two rational expressions with linear denominators.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, & tangent
description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine, cosine, and tangent for all real numbers.

title: The graphs of sine, cosine, & tangent
description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Basic trigonometric identities
description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.

title: Trigonometric values of special angles
description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.

title: Pythagorean identity
description: Sal proves the Pythagorean identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1 for all real numbers.

title: Introduction to amplitude, midline, & extrema of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.

title: Finding amplitude & midline of sinusoidal functions from their formulas
description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Period of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Graphing sinusoidal functions
description: Sal graphs y=2*sin(-x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and a horizontal reflection of y=sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Constructing sinusoidal functions
description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2,-5) and the maximum point (2,1) are highlighted.

title: The inverse trigonometric functions
description: Sal introduces arcsine, which is the inverse function of sine, and discusses its principal range.

title: Solving basic sinusoidal equations
description: Sal finds the expressions that together represent all possible solutions to the equation sin(x)=1/3.

title: Solving sinusoidal models
description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by solving a sinusoidal equation.

title: Introduction to the trigonometric angle addition identities
description: Sal reviews all the different trigonometric angle addition identities: sin(a+b), sin(a-c), cos(a+b), cos(a-b), cos(2a), and sin(2a).

title: Using trigonometric identities to solve problems
description: Sal finds the value of sin(7π/12) by rewriting it as sin(π/3+π/4) and then using the sine angle addition formula.

title: Parametric equations
description: Sal gives an example of a situation where parametric equations are very useful: driving off a cliff!

title: Rate conversion
description: Sal shows how we can treat units of measurement algebraically, and use these tools in order to convert between different units of the same quantity.

title: Word problems with multiple units
description: Sal solves two related proportion word problems about a squirrel crossing the road and a car that approaches it. He does that using dimensional analysis.

title: Modeling with one-variable equations & inequalities
description: Sal models a context that concerns the number and price of pizza slices. The model turns out to be a rational equation.

title: Manipulating formulas
description: Sal rewrites the formula for the perimeter of a rectangle so it is solved for width.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: What are the imaginary numbers?
description: Sal introduces the imaginary unit i, which is defined by the equation i^2=-1. He then gets to know this special number better by thinking about its powers.

title: What are the complex numbers?
description: Sal explains how we obtain complex numbers by adding real numbers and imaginary numbers.

title: The complex plane
description: Sal shows how to plot various numbers on the complex plane.

title: Adding & subtracting complex numbers
description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multiplying complex numbers
description: Sal multiplies (1-3i) by (2+5i).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Complex conjugates & dividing complex numbers
description: Sal explains what is the conjugate of a complex number, and shows how the product of a complex number and its conjugate is always a real number.

title: Absolute value & angle of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the absolute value of (3-4i).

title: Distance & midpoint of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the distance between (2+3i) and (-5-i) and then he finds their midpoint on the complex plane.

title: Polar form of complex numbers
description: Sal rewrites the complex number -3+2i (which is given in rectangular form) in its polar form.

title: Multiplying & dividing complex numbers in polar form
description: Sal shows how complex division affects the modulus and the argument of the divisor and the dividend.

title: Challenging complex number problems
description: Paper 1 Problem 39 from the challenging 2010 IIT JEE exam, about complex numbers.

title: Introduction to conic sections
description: Sal introduces the four conic sections and shows how they are derived by intersecting planes with cones in certain ways.

title: Standard equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Expanded equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.

title: Center and radii of an ellipse
description: Sal introduces ellipses and shows how their standard equation relates to their center and radii (ellipses have two radii: major and minor).

title: Foci of an ellipse
description: Sal explains how the radii and the foci of an ellipse relate to each other, and how we can use this relationship in order to find the foci from the equation of an ellipse.

title: Focus and directrix of a parabola
description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.

title: Introduction to hyperbolas
description: Sal introduces the standard equation for hyperbolas, and how it can be used in order to determine the direction of the hyperbola and its vertices.

title: Foci of a hyperbola
description: Sal discusses the foci of hyperbolas and shows how they relate to hyperbola equations.

title: Hyperbolas not centered at the origin
description: Sal analyzes the hyperbola whose equation is (x-1)^2/16-(y+1)^2/4=1, and graphs it.

title: Identifying conic sections from their expanded equations
description: Sal manipulates the equation x^2+y^2-3x+4y=4 in order to find that it represents a circle, and the equation 2x^2+y+12x+16=0 in order to find it represents a parabola.

title: Challenging conic section problems (IIT JEE)
description: How a tangent line relates to a hyperbola. Might be useful for some competitive exams where there isn't time to derive (like we are doing in this video).

title: Basic sigma notation
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Geometric sequences
description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio.

title: Finite geometric series
description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn more about it here.

title: Finite geometric series applications
description: Watch Sal solve an example of using a geometric series to answer a fun word problem.

title: Infinite geometric series
description: Sal uses a clever algebraic manipulation to find an expression for the sum of an infinite geometric series.

title: Infinite geometric series applications
description: Watch Sal determine the total vertical distance a bouncing ball moves using an infinite geometric series.

title: Deductive and inductive reasoning
description: Sal discusses the difference between inductive and deductive reasoning by considering a word problem.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Induction
description: Proving an expression for the sum of all positive integers up to and including n by induction

title: Sum of n squares
description: What is the sum of the first n squares, 1 + 4 + 9 + 16 + ... + n²? In this video we begin the journey towards finding a formula for this sum.

title: Vector basics
description: The difference between vectors and scalars. ​Introduction to distance, displacement, speed, and velocity.

title: Unit vectors
description: Learn what a unit vector is and how to find a unit vector in the direction of a given vector.

title: Adding vectors in magnitude & direction form
description: Watch Sal add two vectors given in magnitude and direction form by breaking them down into components first.

title: Introduction to matrices
description: Take the red pill and enter the Matrix!

title: Row-echelon form & Gaussian elimination
description: Sal solves a linear system with 3 variables by representing it with an augmented matrix and bringing the matrix to reduced row-echelon form.

title: Adding & subtracting matrices
description: Sal defines what it means to add or subtract matrices. He shows a few examples and discusses some important properties of matrix addition and subtraction.

title: Multiplying matrices by scalars
description: Sal defines what it means to multiply a matrix by a scalar (in the world of matrices, a scalar is simply a regular number).

title: Multiplying matrices by matrices
description: Sal explains what it means to multiply two matrices, and gives an example.

title: Properties of matrix multiplication
description: Sal discusses the conditions of matrix dimensions for which addition or multiplication are defined.

title: Matrices as transformations
description: Sal transforms a 2-dimensional vector using a 2x2 matrix, and draws the original vector and its image on the plane.

title: Determinant of a 2x2 matrix
description: Sal shows how to find the determinant of a 2x2 matrix.

title: Introduction to matrix inverses
description: Sal introduces the concept of an inverse matrix.

title: Finding the inverse of a matrix using its determinant
description: Sal gives an example of how to find the inverse of a given 2x2 matrix.

title: Determinants & inverses of large matrices
description: Sal shows the standard method for finding the determinant of a 3x3 matrix.

title: Solving equations with inverse matrices
description: Sal shows how a system of two linear equations can be represented with the equation A*x=b where A is the coefficient matrix, x is the variable vector, and b is the constant vector.

title: Model real-world situations with matrices
description: Sal shows how matrices can be used to efficiently represent data about the prices of toilet paper and toothpaste in two different cities.

title: Lines, line segments, and rays
description: Euclid was a great mathematician and often called the father of geometry.  Learn more about Euclid and how some of our math concepts came about and how influential they have become.

title: Measuring segments
description: In this example of measuring a line segment, the numbers span across the positive and negative. Remember, line segments and points are the foundations of geometry, so this is an important concept.

title: Parallel and perpendicular
description: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Points, lines, & planes
description: In a three-dimensional space, a plane can be defined by three points it contains, as long as those points are not on the same line. Learn more about it in this video.

title: Geometric definitions
description: Watch Sal solve a problem where he matches three students definition of parallel lines to a teacher's comments.

title: The golden ratio
description: An introduction to one of the most amazing ideas/numbers in mathematics

title: Angle introduction
description: Two rays that share the same endpoint form an angle. Learn about angles and the parts of an angle, like the vertex.

title: Measuring angles
description: Learn how to measure an angle with a protractor.

title: Constructing angles
description: Sal uses a protractor to create 10° and 155° angles.

title: Angles in circles
description: Learn to measure angles as part of a circle.

title: Angle types
description: Sal identifies acute, obtuse, and right angles in diagrams and pictures.

title: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles
description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles, as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

title: Angles between intersecting lines
description: Learn about parallel lines, transversals, and the angles they form.

title: Sal's old angle videos
description: What an angle is. Angles in a circle. Complementary and supplementary angles.

title: Properties of shapes
description: Sal classifies shapes based on their number of sides, number of corners, and side-lengths.

title: Classifying geometric shapes
description: Sal categorizes shapes based on their sides and angles.

title: Curves and polygons
description: In daily language, we all use the word curve to mean "not straight" but does the word curve have the same meaning in math? Can a straight line be a curve? Also, what makes a curve a 'simple curve'?

title: Angles with polygons
description: Learn how to find the sum of the interior angles of any polygon.

title: Triangle types
description: Learn to categorize triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.

title: Triangle angles
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Triangle inequality theorem
description: Intuition behind the triangle inequality theorem

title: Perpendicular bisectors
description: Multiple proofs showing that a point is on a perpendicular bisector of a segment if and only if it is equidistant from the endpoints. Using this to establish the circumcenter, circumradius, and circumcircle for a triangle.

title: Angle bisectors
description: Thinking about the distance between a point and a line. Proof that a point on an angle bisector is equidistant to the sides of the angle and a point equidistant to the sides is on an angle bisector.

title: Medians & centroids
description: Seeing that the centroid is 2/3 of the way along every median

title: Altitudes
description: Showing that any triangle can be the medial triangle for some larger triangle. Using this to show that the altitudes of a triangle are concurrent (at the orthocenter).

title: Bringing it all together
description: Comparing perpendicular bisectors to angle bisectors to medians to altitudes.

title: Quadrilateral types
description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid, parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, and square.

title: Quadrilateral proofs & angles
description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: Coordinate plane: quadrant 1
description: Sal graphs ordered pairs, such as (8, 10) in quadrant 1 on a coordinate plane.

title: Coordinate plane: 4 quadrants
description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points, lines, and more.

title: Quadrants on the coordinate plane
description: Learn about the 4 quadrants that make up a coordinate plane.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Reflecting points on coordinate plane
description: Just like looking at a mirror image of yourself, but flipped....a reflection point is the mirror point on the opposite side of the axis. Watch this tutorial and reflect :)

title: Quadrilaterals on the coordinate plane
description: Given three of the vertices of a rectangle, can you find the fourth?

title: Drawing polygons in the coordinate plane
description: Sal draws a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane using the coordinates of its vertices.

title: Count unit squares to find area
description: Sal covers figures with square units to find their area.

title: Area of rectangles
description: Lindsay finds the area of a rectangle both by counting unit squares and multiplying side lengths.

title: Perimeter
description: Perimeter is the distance around the edge of a shape. Learn how to find the perimeter by adding up the side lengths of various shapes

title: Area of parallelograms
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a parallelogram is base times height, just like the formula for the area of a rectangle.

title: Area of triangles
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Area of shapes on grids
description: Learn how to calculate the area of a triangle on a grid.

title: Area of trapezoids & composite figures
description: Area of a trapezoid is found with the formula, A=(a+b)/2 x h.  Learn how to use the formula to find area of trapezoids.

title: Area and circumference of circles
description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

title: Advanced area with triangles
description: Finding the formula for the area of an equilateral triangle with side s

title: Volume of rectangular prisms
description: Sal introduces volume and compares it to length and area.  He also introduces cube units.

title: Volume with fractions
description: Another way of finding the volume of a rectangular prism involves dividing it into fractional cubes, finding the volume of one, and then multiplying that volume by the number of cubes that fit into our rectangular prism.

title: Surface area
description: Admittedly, "nets of polyhedra" sounds like the title of a bad sci-fi movie about man-eating, multi-headed fish. But in reality, nets of polyhedra are just 2D objects that wrap around 3D objects, like wrapping paper around presents.

title: Volume of cones, cylinders, and spheres
description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h, and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

title: Surface and volume density
description: Sal solves a word problem about the number of passengers a blimp can carry, using his knowledge of volume and density.

title: Cross sections of 3D objects
description: What happens when you slice vertically into a rectangular pyramid? What kind of geometric shape results?

title: Koch snowflake fractal
description: A shape that has an infinite perimeter but finite area

title: Heron's formula
description: Using Heron's Formula to determine the area of a triangle while only knowing the lengths of the sides

title: Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Pythagorean theorem application
description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the width of some carpet.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Pythagorean theorem and distance between points
description: Learn how to find the distance between two points by using the distance formula, which is an application of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Pythagorean theorem proofs
description: James Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean Theorem.

title: Introduction to rigid transformations
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Translations
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation, and he draws the image of the triangle under that translation.

title: Rotations
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, and he manually draws the image of that rotation.

title: Reflections
description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane and the definition of a reflection, and he draws the image of the segments under that reflection.

title: Dilations
description: Sal shows how to perform a dilation on a hexagon using our interactive widget!

title: Properties and definitions of transformations
description: Sal is given information about a transformation in terms of a few pairs of points and their corresponding images, and he determines what kind of transformation it can be.

title: Symmetry
description: Introduction to the concept of an "axis of symmetry"

title: Old transformations videos
description: An older video where Sal uses the interactive widget to find the image of a rectangle under a translation.

title: Transformations and congruence
description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are congruent by mapping one onto the other using rigid transformations.

title: Triangle congruence
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

title: Theorems concerning triangle properties
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Working with triangles
description: We write the letters of congruent triangles so their order tells us which parts are corresponding. In this video, Sal uses this notation to solve some angles.

title: Theorems concerning quadrilateral properties
description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: Proofs of general theorems that use triangle congruence
description: Sal proves that a point is the midpoint of a segment using triangle congruence.

title: Definitions of similarity
description: Sal is given pairs of polygons, and then he determines whether they are similar by trying to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations.

title: Introduction to triangle similarity
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar, and how this follows from the definition of similarity.

title: Solving similar triangles
description: Sal solves two problems where a missing side length is found by proving that triangles are similar and using this to find the measure.

title: Angle bisector theorem
description: Sal introduces the angle-bisector theorem and proves it.

title: Solving problems with similar and congruent triangles
description: Sal uses the similarity of triangles and the congruence of others in this multi-step problem to find the area of a polygon.

title: Solving modeling problems with similar and congruent triangles
description: Triangle similarity, the Golden ratio, and art, all converge in this inspiring video!

title: Special right triangles
description: Introduction to 45-45-90 Triangles

title: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal introduces sine, cosine, and tangent, and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.

title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Modeling with right triangles
description: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.

title: Trigonometric ratios and similarity
description: Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Sine and cosine of complementary angles
description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: The reciprocal trigonometric ratios
description: Sal finds all six trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent, secant, cosecant, and cotangent) of an angle in a given right triangle.

title: The law of sines
description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

title: The law of cosines
description: Learn how to use the law of cosines to find the missing side length of a triangle when given two side lengths and the contained angle measure.

title: Solving general triangles
description: Sal solves a word problem about the distance between stars using the law of cosines.

title: Circle basics
description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs

title: Arc length (degrees)
description: Finding the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: Arc length (radians)
description: Sal finds the fraction of an arc length out of the entire circumference using the radian measure of the central angle subtended by the arc.

title: Sectors
description: A worked example of finding the area of a circle's sector using the area of the circle and the central angle of the sector.

title: Area of inscribed triangle
description: Sal proves that if a radius in a circle is drawn so it bisects a chord, then the radius is also perpendicular to that chord. The proof uses SSS congruence.

title: Standard equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Expanded equation of a circle
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.

title: Distance and midpoints
description: Learn how to find the distance between two points by using the distance formula, which is an application of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Dividing line segments
description: Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio. A graph is given to make it easier to visualize the problem.

title: Parallel and perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane
description: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Challenge: Distance between a point and a line
description: The distance from a point to a line is the shortest distance between the point and any point on the line. This can be done with a variety of tools like slope-intercept form and the Pythagorean Theorem.

title: Constructing bisectors of lines and angles
description: Sal constructs a perpendicular bisector to a given line segment using compass and straightedge.

title: Constructing regular polygons inscribed in circles
description: Sal constructs a square that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Constructing circumcircles and incircles
description: Sal constructs a circle that inscribes a given triangle using compass and straightedge.

title: Constructing a line tangent to a circle
description: Sal constructs a line tangent to a circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Worked examples
description: Three example problems involving perimeter and area.

title: Limits introduction
description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Limits from tables
description: Sal finds the limit of 3sin(5x)/sin(2x) at x=0 using a table of values.

title: Limits from graphs
description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function isn't defined at the limiting value but that doesn't mean the limit doesn't exist!

title: One-sided limits
description: A one-sided limit is the value the function approaches as the x-values approach the limit from *one side only*. For example, f(x)=|x|/x returns -1 for negative numbers, 1 for positive numbers, and isn't defined for 0. The one-sided *right* limit of f at x=0 is 1, and the one-sided *left* limit at x=0 is -1.

title: Formal definition of limits (epsilon-delta)
description: A quick reminder of what limits are, to set up for the formal definition of a limit.

title: Continuity at a point
description: Sal introduces a formal definition of continuity at a point using limits.

title: Limits of combined and composite functions
description: What is the limit of the sum of two functions?  What about the product?

title: Continuous functions
description: Sal is asked which of the following two functions is continuous on all real numbers: eˣ and/or √x. In general, the common functions are continuous on all the numbers in their domain.

title: Intermediate value theorem
description: Introduction to the Intermediate value theorem. If f is a continuous function over [a,b], then it takes on every value between f(a) and f(b) over that interval.

title: Limits from equations (factoring & rationalizing)
description: Sal finds the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) at x=2 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Squeeze theorem
description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers, and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k), then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0, by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

title: Removable discontinuities
description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(6x²+18x+12)/(x²-4) should have at x=-2 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Unbounded limits (vertical asymptotes)
description: Here we consider the limit of the function f(x)=1/x as x approaches 0, and as x approaches infinity.

title: Limits at infinity (horizontal asymptotes)
description: Here we consider the limit of the function f(x)=1/x as x approaches 0, and as x approaches infinity.

title: Introduction to differential calculus
description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Derivative as instantaneous rate of change
description: Sal finds the average rate of change of a curve over several intervals, and uses one of them to approximate the slope of a line tangent to the curve.

title: Secant lines
description: What is the slope of a line between two points on a curve?  This is called a "secant" line.

title: Derivative as a limit
description: The derivative of function f at x=c is the limit of the slope of the secant line from x=c to x=c+h as h approaches 0. Symbolically, this is the limit of [f(c)-f(c+h)]/h as h→0.

title: Formal definition of derivative
description: Sal introduces two ways of writing the limit expression for the derivative of a function at a point.

title: Using the formal definition of derivative
description: Sal finds the limit expression for the derivative of f(x)=x² at the point x=3 and evaluates it.

title: Derivative as a function
description: Given the graph of a function, Sal sketches the graph of its derivative.

title: Power rule
description: Sal introduces the power rule, which tells us how to find the derivative of xⁿ.

title: Polynomial functions differentiation
description: Once you know how to take the derivative of x^n, it turns out you can take the derivative of any polynomial.  Let's see why...

title: Sine & cosine derivatives
description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: eˣ and ln(x) derivatives
