title: Parametric & vector-valued function differentiation
description: Sal gives an example of a situation where parametric equations are very useful: driving off a cliff!

title: Mean value theorem
description: The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b] and differentiable on the open interval (a,b), then there exists a point c in the interval (a,b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a,b]. In other words, the graph has a tangent somewhere in (a,b) that is parallel to the secant line over [a,b].

title: L'Hôpital's rule
description: When you are solving a limit, and get 0/0 or ∞/∞, L'Hôpital's rule is the tool you need.

title: Justifying properties of functions using the first derivative
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Critical points & intervals of increase or decrease
description: Sal introduces the "critical points" of a function and discusses their relationship with the extremum points of the function.

title: Finding relative extrema (first derivative test)
description: Once you find a critical point, how can you tell if it is a minimum, maximum or neither?

title: Finding absolute extrema
description: Sal finds the absolute maximum value of f(x)=8ln(x)-x² over the interval [1,4].

title: Concavity & inflection points intro
description: Sal introduces the concept of concavity, what it means for a graph to be "concave up" or "concave down," and how this relates to the second derivative of a function.

title: Connecting ƒ, ƒ’, and ƒ’’
description: Given the graph of a function, Sal sketches the graph of its derivative.

title: Optional videos
description: This isn't a full proof of L'Hopital's rule, but it should give some intuition for why it works.

title: Rates of change in applied contexts
description: Let's face it, sometimes it feels like we forget much of what we learn.  In this example we model that forgetful phenomenon.

title: Related rates intro
description: What's the relationship between how fast a circle's radius changes, and how fast its area changes?

title: Related rates problems
description: As two cars approach the same intersection from different roads, how does the rate of change of the distance between them change?

title: Optimization
description: What is the minimum possible value of x^2+y^2 given that their product has to be fixed at xy = -16

title: Motion problems
description: The position of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by s(t)=t³-6t²+9t. Sal analyzes it to find the times when the particle is "speeding up."

title: Left & right Riemann sums
description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: Summation notation
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Riemann sums in summation notation
description: Generalizing the technique of approximating area under a curve with rectangles.

title: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum
description: Definite integrals represent the exact area under a given curve, and Riemann sums are used to approximate those areas. However, if we take Riemann sums with infinite rectangles of infinitely small width (using limits), we get the exact area, i.e. the definite integral!

title: Definite integrals properties
description: By subdividing the stretch of numbers where you are integrating, you can break up an integral.

title: Functions defined by integrals
description: Finding a definite integral by breaking it down to smaller intervals that are adjacent to each other.

title: Antiderivatives and indefinite integrals intro
description: What's the opposite of a derivative?  It's something called the "indefinite integral".

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how, in some sense, integration is the opposite of differentiation.

title: Indefinite integrals: reverse power rule
description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Indefinite integrals of sin(x), cos(x), eˣ, and 1/x
description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw, this is ln(x). However, if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

title: Improper integrals
description: Improper integrals are definite integrals where one or both of the ​boundaries is at infinity, or where the integrand has a vertical asymptote in the interval of integration. As crazy as it may sound, we can actually calculate some improper integrals using some clever methods that involve limits.

title: 𝘶-substitution
description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

title: Integration by parts
description: By looking at the product rule for derivatives in reverse, we get a powerful integration tool.

title: Partial fraction expansion
description: When you are integrating a function in the form of a fraction, it helps to find a way to break apart the expression.

title: Average value of a function
description: Average value of a function over a closed interval

title: Optional videos
description: The first part of the fundamental theorem of calculus tells us that if we define 𝘍(𝘹) to be the definite integral of function ƒ from some constant 𝘢 to 𝘹, then 𝘍 is an antiderivative of ƒ. In other words, 𝘍'(𝘹)=ƒ(𝘹). See why this is so.

title: Differential equations intro
description: Differential equations are equations that relate a function with one or more of its derivatives. This means their solution is a function! Learn more in this video.

title: Separable differential equations
description: "Separation of variables" allows us to rewrite differential equations so we obtain an equality between two integrals we can evaluate. Separable equations are the class of differential equations that can be solved using this method.

title: Slope fields
description: Slope fields allow us to analyze differential equations graphically. Learn how to draw them and use them to find particular solutions.

title: Euler's Method
description: Euler's method is a numerical tool for approximating values for solutions of differential equations. See how (and why) it works.

title: Exponential models
description: Assuming a quantity grows proportionally to its size results in the general equation dy/dx=ky. Solving it with separation of variables results in the general exponential function y=Ceᵏˣ.

title: Logistic models
description: Population should grow proportionally to its size, but it can't keep growing forever! Learn more about this problem, posed by Malthus, and embark on a journey towards its mathematical solution.

title: Word problems involving definite integrals
description: If you have a function representing rate, what does the area under its curve represent?

title: Area: vertical areas between curves
description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Area: polar curves
description: Develop intuition for the area enclosed by polar graph formula

title: Arc length
description: We can use definite integrals to find the length of a curve. See how it's done and get some intuition into why the formula works.

title: Volume: known cross sections
description: The volume of a solid with semi-circular cross sections and a triangular base.

title: Volume: disc method
description: Finding the solid of revolution (constructed by revolving around the x-axis) using the disc method.

title: Volume: washer method
description: Finding the volume of a solid of revolution that is defined between two functions

title: Volume: shell method (optional)
description: Introducing the shell method for rotation around a vertical line.

title: Infinite sequences
description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms"), like 2,5,8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example, 2,5,8 follows the pattern "add 3," and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example, 2,5,8,... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Finite geometric series
description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn more about it here.

title: Partial sums
description: The partial sum of an infinite series as the sum of the first few terms (and hence it's only partial). This seemingly simple concept is very useful in thinking about infinite series.

title: Basic convergence tests
description: If the terms of an infinite series don't approach zero, the series must diverge. Learn more about this test in this video.

title: Comparison tests
description: If every term in one series is less than the corresponding term in some convergent series, it must converge as well. This notion is at the basis of the direct convergence test. Learn more about it here.

title: Ratio & alternating series tests
description: The ratio test is a most useful test for series convergence. It caries over intuition from geometric series to more general series. Learn more about it here.

title: Estimating infinite series
description: Suppose we want to find the sum of a convergent series, and can't do it directly. We can take a partial sum, but how do we know how far we are from the actual sum? We can use improper integrals for that!

title: Power series intro
description: Power series is a sum of terms of the general form aₙ(x-a)ⁿ. Whether the series converges or diverges, and the value it converges to, depend on the chosen x-value, which makes power series a function.

title: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials intro
description: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials are a very clever way of approximating any function with a polynomial. Learn how these polynomials work.

title: Maclaurin series of sin(x), cos(x), and eˣ
description: Approximating cos(x) with a Maclaurin series (which is like a Taylor polynomial centered at x=0 with infinitely many terms). It turns out that this series is exactly the same as the function itself!

title: Optional videos
description: A sequence is "converging" if its terms approach a specific value at infinity. This video is a more formal definition of what it means for a sequence to converge.

title: AP Calculus BC 2011
description: Velocity and acceleration vectors for particle

title: AP Calculus BC 2008
description: Part 1a of the 2008 BC free response

title: Spirals, Fibonacci and being a plant
description: Part 2: http://youtu.be/lOIP_Z_-0Hs Part 3: http://youtu.be/14-NdQwKz9w Re: Pineapple under the Sea: http://youtu.be/gBxeju8dMho

title: Doodling in math
description: More videos/info: http://vihart.com/doodlingDoodling Snakes + Graphs: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=heKK95DAKmsDoodling Stars: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CfJzrmS9UfYDoodling Binary Trees: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e4MSN6IImpIhttp://vihart.com

title: Hexaflexagons
description: Hooraaaay flexagons! Next hexaflexagon video in one week. Happy October!More info coming soon.

title: About pi and tau
description: Happy Tau Day! This is a song about Tau! Other Tau things you should see:Pi is (still) Wrong: http://youtu.be/jG7vhMMXagQ What Tau Sounds Like: http://youtu.be/3174T-3-59QThe Tau Manifesto: http://tauday.com/

title: Singing (and noises)
description:
A visual and musical expression of mathematical symmetry groups. The transformations done to the video are equivalent to the transformations done to the notes.

These type of repeating patterns are called frieze patterns. A couple wallpaper groups are also represented.

title: Mobius strips
description:
Playing mathematically with fruits by the foot.
Mobius Story, Wind and Mr. Ug: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4mdEsouIXGM
Mobius Candy buttons: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOLIB3cjFqw
Mobius Music box: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3iMI_uOM_fY

Doodling Snakes + Graphs (Useful for drawing Borromean rings): http://youtu.be/heKK95DAKms

title: Thanksgiving math
description:
This Thanksgiving, make sure your table isn't missing the all-important green bean matherole. Pick your favorite vector field and have at it!

Mathed Potatoes: http://youtu.be/F5RyVWI4Onk
Borromean Onion Rings: http://youtu.be/4tsjCND2ZfM
Turduckenen-duckenen: http://youtu.be/pjrI91J6jOw

title: Infinity . . .
description: Point Nine Repeating Equals One! 9.999... reasons in 9.999... minutes. Bonus points if you can name all 9.999... lords a-leaping. Dear YouTube, wouldn't it be nice if I could include the full script with this video? A larger character limit would not be unreasonable.

title: Other cool stuff
description: Pythagoras had a problem with beans and irrationality. What really happened? I don't know! The square root of two is irrational, and beans are delicious.

title: Brain teasers
description: Deductive reasoning problem from Singapore.

title: 2013 AMC 10 A
description: Video by Art of Problem Solving.  Problem from the MAA American Mathematics Competitions

title: 2003 AIME
description: 2003 AIME II Problem 1

title: Expectation warmup
description: How should two people split the pot when they are interrupted midgame?

title: Random sampling warmup
description: Can Sal predict the ratio of white to black balls without looking at all of them?

title: Arithmetic warmups
description: introduction to exponents and exponential growth

title: Introduction to rational numbers
description: Learn what rational and irrational numbers are and how to tell them apart.

title: Solving linear equations with variables on both sides
description: We will use a scale to try to achieve balance and help explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation, even when the variable appears on both sides.

title: Reducing equations to simpler form
description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Some more applications
description: Sal solves the equation 7 - 10/x = 2 + 15/x.

title: Algebraic equations review
description: Learn what variables, expressions, and equations are.

title: Polygons
description: Learn how to find the sum of the interior angles of any polygon.

title: Sum of the measures of the exterior angles of a polygon
description: Sal demonstrates how the the sum of the exterior angles of a convex polygon is 360 degrees.

title: Kinds of quadrilaterals
description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid, parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, and square.

title: Quadrilateral proofs & angles
description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: Organizing data
description: Learn to organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).

title: Grouping Data
description: A histogram is a graphical display of data using bars of different heights. In a histogram, each bar groups numbers into ranges. Taller bars show that more data falls in that range. A histogram displays the shape and spread of continuous sample data.

title: Circle Graphs or Pie Charts
description: Reading Pie Graphs (Circle Graphs)
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Chance and Probability
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Square roots
description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Estimating square roots
description: Learn how to approximate the decimal value of √45 without using a calculator.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Cube roots
description: Learn the meaning of cube roots and how to find them. Also learn how to find the cube root of a negative number.

title: What are expressions?
description: Learn what variables, expressions, and equations are.

title: Multiplying a monomial by a monomial
description: Learn to express the area of a rectangle with length 4y and width 2y as a monomial.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multiplying a monomial by a polynomial
description: Sal multiplies -4x² by (3x² + 25x - 7).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Multiplying a polynomial by a polynomial
description: Sal expresses the product (3x+2)(5x-7) as 15x²-11x-14.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Standard identities
description: Sal gives numerous examples of the two special binomial product forms: perfect squares and the difference of two squares.

title: Mapping space around us
description: Understand how a scale drawing is converted into real numbers using the scale factor.

title: Area of a trapezium
description: Area of a trapezoid is found with the formula, A=(a+b)/2 x h.  Learn how to use the formula to find area of trapezoids.

title: Area of general quadrilaterals
description: Sal proves that we can find the area of a rhombus by taking half the product of the lengths of the diagonals.

title: Area of polygons
description: Learn to break up irregular shapes into smaller geometric shapes to determine area.

title: Surface area
description: Admittedly, "nets of polyhedra" sounds like the title of a bad sci-fi movie about man-eating, multi-headed fish. But in reality, nets of polyhedra are just 2D objects that wrap around 3D objects, like wrapping paper around presents.

title: Volume of cube, cuboid, and cylinder
description: Sal introduces volume and compares it to length and area.  He also introduces cube units.

title: Powers with negative exponents
description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with negative exponents as fractions with positive exponents.

title: Laws of exponents
description: Introduction to exponent rules including basic product and quotient rules.

title: Use of Exponents to Express Small Numbers in Standard Form
description: Introduction to scientific notation. An in-depth discussion about why and how scientific notation is used.

title: Direct and inverse proportions
description: Sal explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.

title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors
description: Sal shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).

title: Factoring quadratics using identities: Difference of squares
description: Sal factors 45x^2-125 as 5(3x+5)(3x-5).

title: Factoring quadratics using identities: Perfect squares
description: Sal factors 25x^2-30x+9 as (5x-3)^2 or as (-5x+3)^2.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Factoring quadratics by grouping
description: Sal introduces the method of grouping, which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.

title: Bar graphs and histograms review
description: Sal creates a bar chart using data from a survey.

title: Linear graphs
description: A line graph is way to visually represent data, especially data that changes over time.  Let's take a look at an example.

title: Intro to the coordinate plane
description: Sal graphs ordered pairs, such as (8, 10) in quadrant 1 on a coordinate plane.

title: Coordinate plane word problems
description: Sal solves a word problem involving distance between points on quadrant 1 of a coordinate plane.

title: Dependent & independent variables
description: Identifying the dependent and the independent variables in a word problem.

title: Some applications
description: Sal discusses how we would go about making sense of the direction of a linear graph that represents a relationship between two real-world quantities.

title: Numbers in general form
description: Sal writes 14,897 in expanded form.
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Tests of divisibility
description: Worked example of basic divisibility tests.

title: Physics and its laws
description: An overview of what physics is about as we delve deeper in future videos. How physics is related to math, the other sciences, and the world around us.

title: Physical quantities and their measurement
description: Attempting to comprehend the scale of the large

title: Scientific notation
description: Can you imagine if you had to do calculations with very, very small numbers? How would you handle all those zeros to the right of the decimal? Thank goodness for scientific notation!
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Significant figures
description: Significant figures refers to the number of important single digits in a value, often a measurement.  This video is an introduction to significant figures.

title: Introduction to logarithms
description: Sal explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.

title: The constant e and the natural logarithm
description: Sal introduces a very special number in the world of math (and beyond!), the constant 𝑒.

title: Slope
description: Sal shows how to find the slope of a line.

title: The unit circle definition of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine, cosine, and tangent for all real numbers.

title: The graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent
description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1, in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically, this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers, and the range is [-1,1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).
authors: Sal Khan, Monterey Institute for Technology and Education

title: Basic trigonometric identities
description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.

title: Evaluating functions
description: Functions assign a single output for each of their inputs. In this video, we see examples of various kinds of functions.

title: Inputs and outputs of a function
description: Sal finds the input value for which f(t)=13, given that f(t)=-2t+5.

title: Maximum and minimum points
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing
description: Function values can be positive or negative, and they can increase or decrease as the input increases. Here we introduce these basic properties of functions.

title: Interpreting features of graphs
description: When a function models a real-world context, we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video, we consider a graph that models temperature over time.

title: Slope
description: Sal shows how to find the slope of a line.

title: Introduction to differential calculus
description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Secant lines
description: What is the slope of a line between two points on a curve?  This is called a "secant" line.

title: Limit basics
description: An older video of Sal introducing the notion of a limit.

title: Derivative as a limit
description: The derivative of function f at x=c is the limit of the slope of the secant line from x=c to x=c+h as h approaches 0. Symbolically, this is the limit of [f(c)-f(c+h)]/h as h→0.

title: Using the formal definition of derivative
description: Sal finds the limit expression for the derivative of f(x)=x² at the point x=3 and evaluates it.

title: Derivative as a function
description: Given the graph of a function, we are asked to recognize the graph of its derivative.

title: Power rule
description: Sal introduces the power rule, which tells us how to find the derivative of xⁿ.

title: Polynomial functions differentiation
description: Once you know how to take the derivative of x^n, it turns out you can take the derivative of any polynomial.  Let's see why...

title: Sine & cosine derivatives
description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Product rule
description: Introduction to the product rule, which tells us how to take the derivative of a product of functions.

title: Chain rule
description: The chain rule states that the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). In other words, it helps us differentiate *composite functions*. For example, sin(x²) is a composite function because it can be constructed as f(g(x)) for f(x)=sin(x) and g(x)=x². Using the chain rule and the derivatives of sin(x) and x², we can then find the derivative of sin(x²).

title: Antiderivatives
description: What's the opposite of a derivative?  It's something called the "indefinite integral".

title: Indefinite integrals of common functions
description: ∫sin(x)dx=-cos(x)+C, ∫cos(x)dx=sin(x)+C, and ∫eˣdx=eˣ+C. Learn why this is so and see worked examples.

title: Definite integral as area
description: If you already know the area under a curve, you can use it to compute an integral.

title: Riemann sums
description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: Definite integral evaluation
description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: u-substitution
description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

title: Area & net change
description: An example relating rates of change with a leaky bathtub.

title: Distance, displacement, and coordinate systems
description: An introduction to the difference between distance traveled and displacement.

title: Average velocity and average speed
description: The difference between vectors and scalars. ​Introduction to distance, displacement, speed, and velocity.

title: Velocity and speed from graphs
description: Instantaneous speed and velocity looks at really small displacements over really small periods of time

title: Acceleration
description: Calculating the acceleration of a Porsche

title: Kinematic formulas
description: Calculating average velocity when acceleration is constant

title: Objects in freefall
description: Plotting projectile displacement, acceleration, and velocity as a function of time.

title: Rectilinear motion (integral calc)
description: What can you say about the velocity and position of a particle given its acceleration.

title: Relative velocity in 1D
description: Velocity depends on the point of view we take. Let's discuss this concept of relative velocity, what it is and why it's needed. Created by Mahesh Shenoy.

title: Vector basics
description: The difference between vectors and scalars. ​Introduction to distance, displacement, speed, and velocity.

title: Unit vectors
description: Unit vectors are vectors whose magnitude is exactly 1 unit. They are very useful for different reasons. Specifically, the unit vectors [0,1] and [1,0] can form together any other vector.

title: Adding vectors in magnitude and direction form
description: Watch Sal add two vectors given in magnitude and direction form by breaking them down into components first.

title: Analyzing vectors using trigonometry
description: Visualizing, adding and breaking down vectors in 2 dimensions

title: Review: Unit vectors
description: Using unit vectors to represent the components of a vector

title: Graphs of projectile motion
description: Visualizing position, velocity and acceleration in two-dimensions for projectile motion

title: Horizontally launched projectiles
description: How to solve for the horizontal displacement when the projectile starts with a horizontal initial velocity. We also explain common mistakes people make when doing horizontally launched projectile problems.

title: Projectiles launched at an angle
description: Figuring out the horizontal displacement for a projectile launched at an angle

title: Projectiles launched from/to a height
description: More complicated example involving launching and landing at different elevations

title: Relative motion in 2D
description: How fast is the sheep moving as seen by the lion? In previous videos, we have already seen how to calculate relative velocity in 1D. In this video let's extend this concept to the next level, to 2D motion. Created by Mahesh Shenoy

title: Uniform circular motion introduction
description: David explains the meaning of angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration.

title: Centripetal acceleration
description: When acceleration could involve a change in direction and not speed.

title: Introduction to forces and free body diagrams
description: Sal defines and compares tension, weight, friction and normal forces using free body diagrams.

title: Newton's first law: Mass and inertia
description: Basic primer on Newton's First Law of motion

title: Newton's second law
description: Newton's second law of motion is F = ma, or force is equal to mass times acceleration. Learn how to use the formula to calculate acceleration.

title: Newton's third law
description: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction

title: Normal force and contact force
description: The force that keeps a block of ice from falling towards the center of the earth

title: Balanced and unbalanced forces
description: Primer on identifying balanced and unbalanced forces

title: Slow sock on Lubricon VI
description: What would happen to a slowly moving frozen sock on a frictionless planet

title: Inclined planes
description: Figuring out the components of the force due to gravity that are parallel and perpendicular to the surface of an inclined plane

title: Friction
description: Block of wood kept stationary by the force of friction (Correction made in next video)

title: Tension
description: David explains what the force of tension is, how to solve for it, and some common misconceptions involving the force of tension.

title: Centripetal forces
description: Introduction to centripetal force, which accelerates an object toward the center of the circular path.

title: Centripetal force problem solving
description: In this video David gives some problem solving strategies for centripetal force problems and explains many common misconceptions people have about centripetal forces.

title: Introduction to linear momentum and impulse
description: What momentum is. A simple problem involving momentum.

title: Conservation of linear momentum and elastic collision
description: In this video, David shows how to solve for the impulse and force applied during a dodgeball collision using the impulse momentum relationship.

title: Collision in 2D
description: An example of conservation of momentum in two dimensions.

title: Introduction to work
description: David goes through some example problems on the concept of work

title: Work-energy theorem
description: David explains the link between work and kinetic energy

title: Gravitational potential energy and conservative forces
description: A conservative force exists when the work done by that force on an object is independent of the object's path. Instead, the work done by a conservative force depends only on the end points of the motion. An example of a conservative force is gravity.

title: Spring potential energy and Hooke's law
description: Introduction to Hooke's Law

title: Conservation of energy
description: Sal discusses how energy can't be created or destroyed in an isolated system, and works an example of how energy is transformed when a ball falls toward the Earth.

title: Work and energy problems involving friction
description: In this video David shows how to find the energy generated by the force of friction and solves an example conservation of energy problem involving thermal energy.

title: Power
description: IIII haaaave the powerrrr! Power is the rate at which work is done.

title: Elastic and inelastic collisions
description: David explains what it means for a collision to be elastic or inelastic.

title: Centre of mass
description: Sal gives a conceptual understanding of what center of mass means.

title: Introduction to rotational motion
description: David explains the meaning of angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration.

title: Angular kinematics
description: David explains the rotational kinematic formulas and does a couple sample problems using them.

title: Torque and equilibrium
description: An introduction to torque

title: Cross product and torque
description: Introduction to the cross product

title: Rotational inertia and angular second law
description: David explains moment of inertia and the rotational version of Newton's second law and shows how to solve an example problem.

title: Rotational kinetic energy
description: David explains what rotational kinetic energy is and how to calculate it.

title: Angular momentum and angular impulse
description: Introducing angular momentum conceptually starting from linear momentum. Also covers some real-life examples.

title: Conservation of angular momentum
description: How angular momentum is conserved within a system when there is no external torque.

title: Newton's law of gravitation
description: Basics of gravity and the Law of Universal Gravitation

title: Gravitational potential energy at large distances
description: Learn how to calculate gravitational potential energy when we can no longer assume the gravitational field is uniform.

title: Stress, strain, and modulus of elasticity
description: Is steel more elastic than rubber? We all have some intuition for elastic and non-elastic materials. But how do we define elasticity? How do we say whether something is more or less elastic? In this video, we will explore the true meaning of elasticity.

title: Shear and bulk stress
description: How do we really tear paper? This seems like a silly question, but the answer is 'we shear it'. So let's explore this concept of shearing.

title: Application of elastic properties (Bonus)
description: When constructing buildings, why do we always use beams which have a cross-sectional shape of I? Let's explore this intuitively in this video.

title: Density and pressure
description: In this video David explains what specific gravity means. He also shows how to calculate the value for specific gravity and use it to determine the percent of an object that will be submerged while floating.

title: Buoyant force and Archimedes' principle
description: Introduction to Archimedes' principle and buoyant force.

title: Fluid dynamics
description: Sal introduces the notion of moving fluids and laminar flow. Then he uses the incompressibility of a liquid to show that the volume flow rate (flux) must remain constant. Sal then derives the equation of continuity in terms of the area and speed.

title: Viscosity
description: David explains the concept of viscosity, viscous force, and Poiseuille's law.

title: Surface tension
description: David explains the concepts of surface tension, cohesion, and adhesion.

title: Temperature, kinetic theory, and the ideal gas law
description: Intuition of how gases generate pressure in a container and why pressure x volume is proportional to the combined kinetic energy of the molecules in the volume.

title: Specific heat and heat transfer
description: Defining specific heat, heat of fusion, and heat of vaporization. How to calculate the amount of heat to change the temperature of water and the energy required to change for a phase change.

title: Thermal expansion in solids
description:
What's buckling of a rail way track got to do with a thermometer? 
It's all about thermal expansion. In this video we will explore some day to day examples where we get to experience thermal expansion first hand. 
We will also peek into the atomic level and figure out the cause of this phenomenon.

Created by Mahesh Shenoy

title: Thermal expansion in fluids
description:
How do we quantify expansion coefficient in liquids? 

Unlike solids, liquids don't have a definite shape or size, so we need to be careful while thinking of expansion coefficients. 
In this video, we will see what's the best way to quantify expansion coefficients fo liquids. 

Created by Mahesh Shenoy

title: Thermal stress
description:
When a heated glass is suddenly cooled, it shatters. Why? 

 When things are not free to expand, they end up developing stress, called thermal stress. In this video, we will explore this concept of thermal stress with the help of a numerical

Created by Mahesh Shenoy

title: Zeroth and first law of thermodynamics
description: In physics, a microstate is defined as the arrangement of each molecule in the system at a single instant. A macrostate is defined by the macroscopic properties of the system, such as temperature, pressure, volume, etc. For each macrostate, there are many microstates which result in the same macrostate.

title: Work from PV graph and internal energy
description: How a system can do work by expanding

title: Thermodynamic processes and Carnot cycle
description: Isothermic and adiabatic processes. Calculating the work done by an isothermic process and seeing that it is the same as the heat added.

title: Ideal gas equation
description: Intuition behind the ideal gas equation: PV=nRT.

title: Introduction to simple harmonic motion
description: David defines what it means for something to be a simple harmonic oscillator and gives some intuition about why oscillators do what they do as well as where the speed, acceleration, and force will be largest and smallest.

title: Simple harmonic motion in spring-mass systems
description: David explains what affects the period of a mass on a spring (i.e. mass and spring constant). He also explains what does not affect the period of a mass on a spring (i.e. amplitude and gravitational acceleration).

title: Simple pendulums
description: David explains how a pendulum can be treated as a simple harmonic oscillator, and then explains what affects, as well as what does not affect, the period of a pendulum.

title: Energy in simple harmonic oscillators
description: Sal graphs elastic potential energy and kinetic energy for a mass on a spring and compares the total energy when with and without dissipative forces (friction).

title: Simple harmonic motion (with calculus)
description: Harmonic motion refers to the motion an oscillating mass experiences when the restoring force is proportional to the ​displacement, but in opposite directions. Harmonic motion is periodic and can be represented by a sine wave with constant frequency and amplitude. An example of this is a weight bouncing on a spring.

title: Introduction to waves
description: Introduction to transverse and longitudinal waves

title: Wave characteristics
description: Amplitude, period, frequency and wavelength of periodic waves. How to calculate wave velocity.

title: Wave interference
description: David explains wave interference and solves a few examples to find the value of the total wave when two wave pulses overlap.

title: Standing waves
description: David explains how and why standing waves occur, and well as how to determine the wavelengths for a standing wave on a string.

title: Sound
description: Sound is vibrating air. But how does the air start vibrating?

title: Beats and interference of sound waves
description: David explains what beat frequency means, how to find it, and solves a sample problem involving beat frequency.

title: The Doppler effect
description: Learn about the Doppler effect and how it explains the change in frequency of a wave when its source and an observer are moving.

title: Average velocity and average speed (Hindi)
description: Although speed and velocity are often words used interchangeably, in physics, they are distinct concepts. Speed is calculated by dividing the distance traveled by time. It does not have direction. Average velocity is the displacement (change in position) divided by time.

title: Velocity and speed from graphs (Hindi)
description: Instantaneous speed and velocity look at really small displacements over really small periods of time.

title: Acceleration (Hindi)
description: Visualizing, adding and breaking down vectors in 2 dimensions

title: Kinematic formulas (Hindi)
description: Calculating average velocity when acceleration is constant.

title: Objects in freefall (Hindi)
description: Plotting projectile displacement, acceleration, and velocity as a function to change in time.

title: Rectilinear motion (integral calc) (Hindi)
description: What can you say about the velocity and position of a particle given its acceleration?

title: Relative velocity in 1D (Hindi)
description: Velocity is relative and not absolute. It depends upon who is doing the measurement, i.e. what is the frame of reference.

title: Analyzing vectors using trigonometry (Hindi)
description: Visualizing, adding and breaking down vectors in 2 dimensions.

title: Graphs of projectile motion (Hindi)
description: Visualizing position, velocity, and acceleration in two-dimensions for projectile motion.

title: Horizontally launched projectiles (Hindi)
description: In this video Ram explains how to solve for the horizontal displacement when the projectile starts with a horizontal initial velocity. He also explains the common mistakes people make when doing horizontally launched projectile problems.

title: Projectiles launched at an angle (Hindi)
description: Figuring out the horizontal displacement for a projectile launched at an angle.

title: Projectiles launched from/to a height (Hindi)
description: A more complicated example involving launching and landing at different elevations.

title: Projectile on an incline (Hindi)
description: A challenging problem of a projectile on an inclined plane.

title: Relative motion in 2D (Hindi)
description: Ram discusses the idea of finding relative velocity when objects are moving in a plane and not on a straight line.

title: Uniform circular motion introduction (Hindi)
description: Ram explains the meaning of angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration.

title: Centripetal acceleration (Hindi)
description: When acceleration could involve a change in direction and not speed.

title: Newton's first law: Mass and inertia (Hindi)
description: Basic primer on Newton's First Law of Motion.

title: Newton's second law (Hindi)
description: Newton's second law of motion is F = ma, or force is equal to mass times acceleration. Learn how to use the formula to calculate acceleration.

title: Newton's third law (Hindi)
description: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.

title: Normal force and contact force (Hindi)
description: The force that keeps a block of ice from falling towards the center of the earth.

title: Balanced and unbalanced forces (Hindi)
description: A primer on identifying balanced and unbalanced forces.

title: Slow sock on Lubricon VI (Hindi)
description: What would happen to a slowly moving frozen sock on a frictionless planet?

title: Inclined planes (Hindi)
description: Figuring out the components of the force due to gravity that are parallel and perpendicular to the surface of an inclined plane.

title: Friction (Hindi)
description: Block of wood kept stationary by the force of friction (Correction made in next video).

title: Tension (Hindi)
description: Ram explains what the force of tension is, how to solve for it, and some common misconceptions involving the force of tension.

title: Treating systems (Hindi)
description: Solving pulley block problems by considering a system.

title: Centripetal forces (Hindi)
description: In this video Ram does a quick recap of Centripetal acceleration which he uses along with Newton's second law to introduce centripetal force.

title: Centripetal force problem solving (Hindi)
description: In this video, Ram gives some problem-solving strategies for centripetal force problems and explains many common misconceptions people have about centripetal forces.

title: Introduction to linear momentum and impulse (Hindi)
description: What is momentum? A simple problem involving momentum.

title: Conservation of linear momentum and elastic collision (Hindi)
description: In this video, Ram shows how to solve for the impulse and force applied during a dodgeball collision using the impulse-momentum relationship.

title: Collision in 2D (Hindi)
description: An example of conservation of momentum in two dimensions.

title: Introduction to work (Hindi)
description: Introduction to work and energy.

title: Work-energy theorem (Hindi)
description: Ram explains the link between work and kinetic energy.

title: Gravitational potential energy and conservative forces (Hindi)
description: A conservative force exists when the work done by that force on an object is independent of the object's path. Instead, the work done by a conservative force depends only on the endpoints of the motion. An example of a conservative force is gravity.

title: Spring potential energy and Hooke's law (Hindi)
description: Introduction to Hooke's Law.

title: Conservation of energy (Hindi)
description: Ram discusses how energy can't be created or destroyed in an isolated system, and works an example of how energy is transformed when a ball falls toward the Earth.

title: Work and energy problems involving friction (Hindi)
description: In this video Ram shows how to find the energy generated by the force of friction and solves an example conservation of energy problem involving thermal energy.

title: Power (Hindi)
description: IIII haaaave the powerrrr! Power is the rate at which work is done. Created by Ram Prakash.

title: Elastic and inelastic collisions (Hindi)
description: Ram explains what it means for a collision to be elastic or inelastic.

title: Centre of mass (Hindi)
description: Ram gives a conceptual understanding of what center of mass means.

title: Introduction to rotational motion (Hindi)
description: How angular velocity relates to speed.

title: Angular kinematics (Hindi)
description: In this video Ram explains the rotational kinematic formulas and does a couple sample problems using them.

title: Torque and equilibrium (Hindi)
description: An introduction to torque.

title: Cross product and torque (Hindi)
description: The cross product and the direction of torque.

title: Rotational inertia and angular second law (Hindi)
description: Ram explains moment of inertia and the rotational version of Newton's second law and shows how to solve an example problem.

title: Rotational kinetic energy (Hindi)
description: In this video Ram explains what rotational kinetic energy is and how to calculate it.

title: Angular momentum and angular impulse (Hindi)
description: Introducing angular momentum conceptually starting from linear momentum. Also covers some real-life examples.

title: Conservation of angular momentum (Hindi)
description: How angular momentum is conserved within a system when there is no external torque.

title: Newton's law of gravitation (Hindi)
description: Basics of gravity and the Law of Universal Gravitation.

title: Stress, strain, and modulus of elasticity (Hindi)
description: Steel is more elastic than rubber. It can resist a huge amount of deforming force and still return to its original shape. We understand about this definition with the help of more examples.

title: Density and pressure (Hindi)
description: In this video Ram explains what specific gravity means. He also shows how to calculate the value for specific gravity and use it to determine the percent of an object that will be submerged while floating.

title: Buoyant force and Archimedes' principle (Hindi)
description: Introduction to Archimedes' principle and buoyant force.

title: Fluid dynamics (Hindi)
description: Ram introduces the notion of moving fluids and laminar flow. Then he uses the incompressibility of a liquid to show that the volume flow rate (flux) must remain constant. Ram then derives the equation of continuity in terms of the area and speed.

title: Viscosity (Hindi)
description: Ram explains the concept of viscosity, viscous force, and Poiseuille's law.

title: Surface tension (Hindi)
description: Ram explains the concepts of surface tension, cohesion, and adhesion.

title: Thermal expansion in solids (Hindi)
description: Things expand on heating, but why?

title: Thermal expansion in fluids (Hindi)
description: Like solids, liquids too expand on heating. Let's find out more about how we can calculate the change and how liquid's thermal expansion is similar to that of solid's

title: Thermal stress (Hindi)
description: When you pour very hot water into a glass then it might shatter sometime. This thermal shock results from thermal stress generated due to rapid cooling. Let's get to know more about this.

title: Introduction to simple harmonic motion (Hindi)
description: In this video Ram defines what it means for something to be a simple harmonic oscillator and gives some intuition about why oscillators do what they do as well as where the speed, acceleration, and force will be largest and smallest.

title: Simple harmonic motion in spring-mass systems (Hindi)
description: In this video Ram explains what affects the period of a mass on a spring (i.e. mass and spring constant). He also explains what does not affect the period of a mass on a spring (i.e. amplitude and gravitational acceleration).

title: Simple pendulums (Hindi)
description: In this video Ram explains how a pendulum can be treated as a simple harmonic oscillator, and then explains what affects, as well as what does not affect, the period of a pendulum.

title: Simple harmonic motion (with calculus) (Hindi)
description: Harmonic motion refers to the motion an oscillating mass experiences when the restoring force is proportional to the ​displacement, but in opposite directions. Harmonic motion is periodic and can be represented by a sine wave with constant frequency and amplitude. An example of this is a weight bouncing on a spring.

title: Introduction to waves (Hindi)
description: Introduction to transverse and longitudinal waves.

title: Wave characteristics (Hindi)
description: Amplitude, period, frequency and wavelength of periodic waves. How to calculate wave velocity.

title: Wave interference (Hindi)
description: Waves add and subtract their amplitudes when they overlap.

title: Standing waves (Hindi)
description: Ram explains how and why standing waves occur, and well as how to determine the wavelengths for a standing wave on a string.

title: Sound (Hindi)
description: Sound is vibrating air. But how does the air start vibrating?

title: Beats and interference of sound waves (Hindi)
description: Ram explains what beat frequency means, how to find it, and solves a sample problem involving beat frequency.

title: The Doppler effect (Hindi)
description: Learn about the Doppler effect and how it explains the change in frequency of a wave when its source and an observer are moving.

title: Electric charge
description: Learn the physics behind why a balloon clings to things after you rub it on a sweater

title: Conservation of charge
description: Charge can't be created, and it can't be destroyed

title: Coulomb's law and electric force
description: Sal explains the fundamental force that causes charged particles to attract or repel each other

title: Electric field
description: In this video David explains why physicists came up with the idea of the electric field, how it's useful, and explains how the electric field is defined.

title: Electric potential energy, electric potential, and voltage
description: Introduction to electric potential energy

title: Circuits with capacitors
description: A basic overview of capacitors and capacitance. By David Santo Pietro.

title: Electric current and voltage
description: Current is the flow of charge. We measure current by counting the amount of charge passing through a boundary in one second.

title: Resistivity, and Ohm's law
description: Introduction to electricity, circuits, current, and resistance

title: Electric power and DC circuits
description: In this video David derives the formula to find the power used by a resistor.

title: Kirchhoff's junction rule
description: Definition of circuit terms: element, component, node, branch, mesh, and loop

title: Kirchhoff's loop rule
description: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law says if you travel around any loop in a circuit, the voltages across the elements add up to zero.

title: Series and parallel resistors
description: Resistors connected head-to-tail are in series. The equivalent overall resistance is the sum of the individual resistance values.

title: DC Circuit analysis
description: How to calculate the current through a resistor in parallel using equivalent resistance and Ohm's law.

title: Cross product (Prerequisite)
description: Introduction to the cross product

title: Magnets and magnetic force
description: An introduction to magnetism

title: Magnetic field created by a current
description: See how a wire carrying a current creates a magnetic field.

title: Electric motors
description: Sal shows that there will be a net torque on a loop of current in a wire. Sal shows that this net torque will cause the loop to rotate.

title: Magnetic flux and Faraday's law
description: Introduction and intuition for flux and magnetic flux.

title: Reflection and plane mirrors
description: Specular and Diffuse Reflection

title: Reflection and curved mirrors
description: Let's explore the ray tracing technique to figure out the properties of images when things are kept in front of a concave or a convex mirror.

title: Refraction at plane surfaces
description: Refraction and Snell's Law

title: Refraction in prisms
description: The index of refraction in a material isn't always the same for every wavelength. This is how prisms split white light into so many colors.

title: Refraction at curved surfaces
description: Let's derive a formula connecting object distance (u) and image distance (v) for refraction at a curved surface.

title: Refraction in thin lenses
description: Convex Lenses

title: Optic instruments: human eye and defects
description: Why do distant things get blurred when we concentrate on things close to us? Why can't we see things which are very close to us? Let's explore how our eyes work and get answers to questions like these by exploiting the power of ray diagrams

title: Optic instruments: telescopes and microscopes
description: Let's explore how a magnifying glass (simple microscope) really works.

title: Interference of electromagnetic waves
description: In this video David explains what constructive and destructive interference means as well as how path length differences and pi shifts affect the interference.

title: Photons
description: In this video, David explains what a photon is and how to determine the energy of a photon.

title: History of atomic structure
description:
How did we get here? Well, in terms of Atomic Chemistry, Hank takes us on a tour of the folks that were part of the long chain of other folks who helped us get to these deeper understandings of the world. From Leucippus to Heisenberg to you - yes, YOU - the story of Atomic Chemistry is all wibbly-wobbly... and amazing.
Writers: Edi Gonzalez
Chief Editor: Blake de Pastino
Consultant: Dr. Heiko Langner
Director/Editor: Nicholas Jenkins
Sound Designer: Michael Aranda
Graphics: Thought Cafe

title: Atoms and electrons
description: In this video, David explains how an atom can absorb and emit photons of particular values and how to determine the allowed values.

title: Nuclear physics
description: Nuclear binding energy is the energy required to split an atom’s nucleus into protons and neutrons. Mass defect is the difference between the predicted mass and the actual mass of an atom's nucleus. The binding energy of a system can appear as extra mass, which accounts for this difference.

title: Half life and decay rate
description: Carbon dating is a real-life example of a first-order reaction. This video explains half-life in the context of radioactive decay.

title: Band theory of solids
description: Why are we obsessed with semiconductors? All our computers and digital devices are made from semiconductors. But what is so special about them? Why do we use them? In this video let's explore, what it is about semiconductors, that allows us to create all these awesome computing devices.

title: Basics of semiconductors
description: Semiconductors have two things responsible for current. What are they? In this video we will explore the electrical properties of a pure silicon crystal.

title: The PN junction
description: A P-type has a lot of holes and an N-type lot of electrons. What if we put them together? In this video, let's explore the famous PN junction. We will see what happens when we have a single crystal with a P-type semiconductor on one side and an N-type on the other.

title: PN junction biasing
description: What happens if we put a voltage across a PN junction? In this video, we will attach metallic contacts at the end of the PN and provide a voltage across it. When we connect P side to Positive and N side to negative, we call it forward biasing.

title: Rectifiers
description: How do you convert AC to DC? The circuits that do that are called Rectifiers. Turns out there are different kinds of rectifiers, some simple and some more advanced. In this video, we will learn the simplest kind of rectifier, a half wave rectifier.

title: Zener diode
description: Heavily doped diodes can undergo a different kind of breakdown. In this video let's explore what happens in a very heavily doped diode. The mechanism was first discovered by a man named Zener. So this mechanism is also called, Zener breakdown and the diodes are called Zener diodes. It's a quantum mechanical effect.

title: Transistors working
description: Amplifying an electric signal. Let's explore how a transistor (more specifically a Bipolar junction transistor) works as an amplifier.

title: Transistor characteristics
description: We will explore the behaviour of input current (base current) as the input voltage (base-emitter voltage) is changed.

title: Transistor as a device
description: We will explore what it means to amplify a signal mathematically, and then see how our transistor does voltage amplification. We will also find the voltage gain.

title: Introduction to physics
description: An overview of what physics is about as we delve deeper in future videos. How physics is related to math, the other sciences, and the world around us.

title: Displacement, velocity, and time
description: The difference between vectors and scalars. ​Introduction to distance, displacement, speed, and velocity.

title: Acceleration
description: Calculating the acceleration of a Porsche

title: Kinematic formulas and projectile motion
description: Calculating average velocity when acceleration is constant

title: Old videos on projectile motion
description: Using the equations of motion to figure out things about falling objects

title: Two-dimensional projectile motion
description: How to solve for the horizontal displacement when the projectile starts with a horizontal initial velocity. We also explain common mistakes people make when doing horizontally launched projectile problems.

title: Optimal angle for a projectile
description: You want a projectile to fly as far as possible, at which angle should you launch it? We'll start with formulas for the initial velocity.

title: Newton's laws of motion
description: Basic primer on Newton's First Law of motion

description: The force that keeps a block of ice from falling towards the center of the earth

title: Balanced and unbalanced forces
description: Primer on identifying balanced and unbalanced forces

description: What would happen to a slowly moving frozen sock on a frictionless planet

description: David explains what it means for a collision to be elastic or inelastic.

description: Specular and Diffuse Reflection

description: Virtual Image

description: Convex Lenses

title: Michelson and Morley's luminiferous ether experiment
description: If waves are disruptions traveling through a medium and light is a wave, what medium does it travel through? A luminiferous ether?

title: Minkowski spacetime
description: We introduce a graph that's a lot like your good old position-vs-time graph—but with a twist!

title: Lorentz transformation
description: So we've got two coordinate systems from the perspectives of two observers. How can we convert spacetime coordinates between these? Enter the Lorentz transformation!

title: Einstein velocity addition
description: Lorentz transformation for change in coordinates

title: Photons
description: In this video, David explains what a photon is and how to determine the energy of a photon.

title: Atoms and electrons
description: In this video, David explains how Louis De Broglie got his Nobel Prize for the idea of matter having a wavelength.

title: Quantum numbers and orbitals
description: Definition of Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Calculating uncertainty in position given the uncertainty in momentum for Bohr model of hydrogen.

title: Nuclei
description: Nuclear binding energy is the energy required to split an atom’s nucleus into protons and neutrons. Mass defect is the difference between the predicted mass and the actual mass of an atom's nucleus. The binding energy of a system can appear as extra mass, which accounts for this difference.

title: Discovery of magnetism
description: Our ancestors noticed that certain rocks were attracted to each other. They also noticed that this force could be transferred onto certain metallic objects!

title: Discovery of magnetic fields
description: Exploring the effect of a permanent magnet on compass. What is going on?

title: Measuring magnetic fields
description: Will the power of two magnets stuck together increase the overall force? Why?

title: Discovery of batteries
description: Zinc Copper cell - example of reduction-oxidation reaction

title: Discovery of electromagnetism
description: Hans Christian Ørsted made this famous observation in 1819.

title: Discovery of resistors
description: Why does the deflection change when an electromagnet is attached to the circuit? Does it matter what side of the electromagnet we test?

title: Electric motor
description: By pulsing the connection to the battery we can cause a compass to spin. How is this working?

title: Electrostatics
description: Our ancestors noticed that when amber was rubbed against fur it attracted small objects...why is this?

title: Projectile launcher
description: This video highlights the projectile (ping pong ball) launcher

title: Thermo can
description: This project shows how to power a boat with a candle.

title: AP Physics 1 concept review
description: In this video David rapidly explains all the concepts in 1D motion and also quickly solves a sample problem for each concept. Keep an eye on the side scroll see how far along you've made it in the review video.

title: AP Physics 1 free response questions 2015
description: Free body diagram for two masses connected by string-pulley system.
