title: Velocity and speed from graphs
description: Instantaneous speed and velocity looks at really small displacements over really small periods of time

title: Average and instantaneous acceleration
description: Calculating the acceleration of a Porsche

title: Motion with constant acceleration
description: How to set up problems with constant acceleration and choose the best kinematic equation to solve for the target unknown.

title: Objects in freefall
description: Plotting projectile displacement, acceleration, and velocity as a function of time.

title: Analyzing vectors using trigonometry
description: Visualizing, adding and breaking down vectors in 2 dimensions

title: Graphs of projectile motion
description: Visualizing position, velocity and acceleration in two-dimensions for projectile motion

title: Horizontally launched projectiles
description: How to solve for the horizontal displacement when the projectile starts with a horizontal initial velocity. We also explain common mistakes people make when doing horizontally launched projectile problems.

title: Projectiles launched at an angle
description: Figuring out the horizontal displacement for a projectile launched at an angle

title: Introduction to forces and free body diagrams
description: Sal defines and compares tension, weight, friction and normal forces using free body diagrams.

title: Newton's first law: Mass and inertia
description: Basic primer on Newton's First Law of motion

title: Newton's second law
description: Newton's second law of motion is F = ma, or force is equal to mass times acceleration. Learn how to use the formula to calculate acceleration.

title: Newton's third law
description: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction

title: Angled forces
description: Sal explains how to draw free body diagrams when forces are applied at an angle. How to find horizontal and vertical components of an angled force using trigonometry.

title: Inclined planes
description: Figuring out the components of the force due to gravity that are parallel and perpendicular to the surface of an inclined plane

title: Friction
description: Why static friction is harder to overcome than kinetic friction

title: Uniform circular motion introduction
description: David explains the meaning of angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration.

title: Centripetal acceleration
description: When acceleration could involve a change in direction and not speed.

title: Centripetal forces
description: Introduction to centripetal force, which accelerates an object toward the center of the circular path.

title: Newton's law of gravitation
description: Basics of gravity and the Law of Universal Gravitation

title: Introduction to work
description: David goes through some example problems on the concept of work

title: Work-energy theorem
description: David explains the link between work and kinetic energy

title: Gravitational potential energy and conservative forces
description: A conservative force exists when the work done by that force on an object is independent of the object's path. Instead, the work done by a conservative force depends only on the end points of the motion. An example of a conservative force is gravity.

title: Spring potential energy and Hooke's law
description: Introduction to Hooke's Law

title: Conservation of energy
description: Sal discusses how energy can't be created or destroyed in an isolated system, and works an example of how energy is transformed when a ball falls toward the Earth.

title: Power
description: IIII haaaave the powerrrr! Power is the rate at which work is done.

title: Introduction to linear momentum and impulse
description: What momentum is. A simple problem involving momentum.

title: Elastic collisions and conservation of momentum
description: David shows how to use conservation of momentum for a situation where two objects bounce off of each other.

title: Inelastic collisions
description: David explains what it means for a collision to be elastic or inelastic.

title: Center of mass and two-dimensional collisions
description: Sal gives a conceptual understanding of what center of mass means.

title: Introduction to rotational motion
description: David explains the meaning of angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration.

title: Angular kinematics
description: David explains the rotational kinematic formulas and does a couple sample problems using them.

title: Torque and equilibrium
description: An introduction to torque

title: Rotational inertia and angular second law
description: David explains moment of inertia and the rotational version of Newton's second law and shows how to solve an example problem.

title: Rotational kinetic energy
description: David explains what rotational kinetic energy is and how to calculate it.

title: Angular momentum and angular impulse
description: Introducing angular momentum conceptually starting from linear momentum. Also covers some real-life examples.

title: Conservation of angular momentum
description: How angular momentum is conserved within a system when there is no external torque.

title: Gravitational potential energy at large distances
description: Learn how to calculate gravitational potential energy when we can no longer assume the gravitational field is uniform.

title: Introduction to simple harmonic motion
description: David defines what it means for something to be a simple harmonic oscillator and gives some intuition about why oscillators do what they do as well as where the speed, acceleration, and force will be largest and smallest.

title: Simple harmonic motion in spring-mass systems
description: David explains what affects the period of a mass on a spring (i.e. mass and spring constant). He also explains what does not affect the period of a mass on a spring (i.e. amplitude and gravitational acceleration).

title: Simple pendulums
description: David explains how a pendulum can be treated as a simple harmonic oscillator, and then explains what affects, as well as what does not affect, the period of a pendulum.

title: Energy in simple harmonic oscillators
description: Sal graphs elastic potential energy and kinetic energy for a mass on a spring and compares the total energy when with and without dissipative forces (friction).

title: Introduction to waves
description: Introduction to transverse and longitudinal waves

title: Wave characteristics
description: Amplitude, period, frequency and wavelength of periodic waves. How to calculate wave velocity.

title: Wave interference
description: David explains wave interference and solves a few examples to find the value of the total wave when two wave pulses overlap.

title: Standing waves
description: David explains how and why standing waves occur, and well as how to determine the wavelengths for a standing wave on a string.

title: Introduction to sound
description: Sound is vibrating air. But how does the air start vibrating?

title: Beats and interference of sound waves
description: David explains what beat frequency means, how to find it, and solves a sample problem involving beat frequency.

title: Doppler effect
description: Learn about the Doppler effect and how it explains the change in frequency of a wave when its source and an observer are moving.

title: Electric charge
description: Learn the physics behind why a balloon clings to things after you rub it on a sweater

title: Conservation of charge
description: Charge can't be created, and it can't be destroyed

title: Coulomb's law and electric force
description: Sal explains the fundamental force that causes charged particles to attract or repel each other

title: Electric current, resistivity, and Ohm's law
description: Introduction to electricity, circuits, current, and resistance

title: Electric power and DC circuits
description: In this video David derives the formula to find the power used by a resistor.

title: Kirchhoff's junction rule
description: Kirchhoff's Current Law says the currents flowing into a node must add up to zero.

title: Kirchhoff's loop rule
description: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law says if you travel around any loop in a circuit, the voltages across the elements add up to zero.

title: Series and parallel resistors
description: Resistors connected head-to-tail are in series. The equivalent overall resistance is the sum of the individual resistance values.

title: DC Ammeters and voltmeters
description: Learn about the instruments we use to measure voltage and current

title: DC Circuit analysis
description: How to calculate the current through a resistor in parallel using equivalent resistance and Ohm's law.

title: AP Physics 1 concept review
description: In this video David rapidly explains all the concepts in 1D motion and also quickly solves a sample problem for each concept. Keep an eye on the side scroll see how far along you've made it in the review video.

title: AP Physics 1 free response questions
description: Free body diagram for two masses connected by string-pulley system.

title: Density and Pressure
description: In this video David explains what specific gravity means. He also shows how to calculate the value for specific gravity and use it to determine the percent of an object that will be submerged while floating.

title: Buoyant Force and Archimedes' Principle
description: Introduction to Archimedes' principle and buoyant force.

title: Fluid Dynamics
description: Sal introduces the notion of moving fluids and laminar flow. Then he uses the incompressibility of a liquid to show that the volume flow rate (flux) must remain constant. Sal then derives the equation of continuity in terms of the area and speed.

title: Temperature, kinetic theory, and the ideal gas law
description: Intuition of how gases generate pressure in a container and why pressure x volume is proportional to the combined kinetic energy of the molecules in the volume.

title: Specific heat and heat transfer
description: Defining specific heat, heat of fusion, and heat of vaporization. How to calculate the amount of heat to change the temperature of water and the energy required to change for a phase change.

title: Laws of thermodynamics
description: In physics, a microstate is defined as the arrangement of each molecule in the system at a single instant. A macrostate is defined by the macroscopic properties of the system, such as temperature, pressure, volume, etc. For each macrostate, there are many microstates which result in the same macrostate.

title: Charge and electric force (Coulomb's law)
description: Learn the physics behind why a balloon clings to things after you rub it on a sweater

title: Electric field
description: In this video David explains why physicists came up with the idea of the electric field, how it's useful, and explains how the electric field is defined.

title: Electric potential energy, electric potential, and voltage
description: Introduction to electric potential energy

title: Magnets and Magnetic Force
description: An introduction to magnetism

title: Magnetic field created by a current
description: See how a wire carrying a current creates a magnetic field.

title: Electric motors
description: Sal shows that there will be a net torque on a loop of current in a wire. Sal shows that this net torque will cause the loop to rotate.

title: Magnetic flux and Faraday's law
description: Introduction and intuition for flux and magnetic flux.

title: Interference of electromagnetic waves
description: In this video David explains what constructive and destructive interference means as well as how path length differences and pi shifts affect the interference.

title: Reflection and refraction
description: Specular and Diffuse Reflection

title: Mirrors
description: Virtual Image

title: Lenses
description: Convex Lenses

title: Photons
description: In this video, David explains what a photon is and how to determine the energy of a photon.

title: Atoms and electrons
description: In this video, David explains how Louis De Broglie got his Nobel Prize for the idea of matter having a wavelength.

title: Quantum numbers and orbitals
description: Definition of Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Calculating uncertainty in position given the uncertainty in momentum for Bohr model of hydrogen.

title: Nuclear physics
description: Nuclear binding energy is the energy required to split an atom’s nucleus into protons and neutrons. Mass defect is the difference between the predicted mass and the actual mass of an atom's nucleus. The binding energy of a system can appear as extra mass, which accounts for this difference.

title: Introduction to the atom
description: A big picture view of chemistry and why it is fascinating. How chemistry relates to math and other sciences.

title: Ions and compounds
description: Difference between ions and atoms. How to calculating charge on an ion.

title: Names and formulas of ionic compounds
description: Naming cations, anions, and simple ionic compounds such as potassium chloride

title: Balancing chemical equations
description: Reactants and products in reversible and irreversible chemical reactions.

title: Stoichiometry
description: Stoichiometry expresses the quantitative relationship between reactants and products in a chemical equation. Stoichiometric coefficients in a balanced equation indicate molar ratios in that reaction. Stoichiometry allows us to predict certain values, such as the percent yield of a product or the molar mass of a gas.

title: Limiting reagent stoichiometry
description: Stoichiometry problem where we find the limiting reagent and calculate grams of product formed.

title: Molecular composition
description: Examples to demonstrate the difference between empirical, structural, and molecular formulas

title: Types of chemical reactions
description: Finding the half reactions in a combustion reaction, and identifying what is getting oxidized and reduced.

title: History of atomic structure
description:
How did we get here? Well, in terms of Atomic Chemistry, Hank takes us on a tour of the folks that were part of the long chain of other folks who helped us get to these deeper understandings of the world. From Leucippus to Heisenberg to you - yes, YOU - the story of Atomic Chemistry is all wibbly-wobbly... and amazing.
Writers: Edi Gonzalez
Chief Editor: Blake de Pastino
Consultant: Dr. Heiko Langner
Director/Editor: Nicholas Jenkins
Sound Designer: Michael Aranda
Graphics: Thought Cafe

title: Bohr's model of the hydrogen atom
description: Light and the electromagnetic radiation spectrum. Wave and particle-like behavior, and how to calculate the wavelength or frequency of a light wave.

title: Quantum numbers and orbitals
description: Definition of Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Calculating uncertainty in position given the uncertainty in momentum for Bohr model of hydrogen.

title: Electron configurations
description: Introduction to orbitals. Relates energy shell to rows and periods in the periodic table.

title: Introduction to the periodic table
description: Definitions of groups, periods, alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, halogens, and noble gases. How metals, non-metals, and metalloids can be identified by the position on the periodic table.

title: Periodic table trends
description: How atomic radius is defined, and trends across a period and down a group.

title: Types of chemical bonds
description: There are three major types of chemical bonds: ionic, covalent, and metallic. Ionic bonds form due to the transfer of an electron from one atom to another. Covalent bonds involve the sharing of electrons between two atoms. Metallic bonds are formed by the attraction between metal ions and delocalized, or "free" electrons.

title: Dot structures and molecular geometry
description: Guidelines for drawing Lewis dot structures.

title: Hybridization and hybrid orbitals
description: sp³ hybrid orbitals and properties of sigma bonds.

title: Ideal gas equation
description: Intuition behind the ideal gas equation: PV=nRT.

title: Non-ideal gas behavior
description: Ideal gas law assumptions, and when they break down. What happens to pressure and volume at low T and high P.

title: States of matter
description: Introduction to the states or phases of matter.

title: Introduction to intermolecular forces
description: Van der Waals forces: London dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces,  and hydrogen bonding.

title: Mixtures and solutions
description: A suspension is a heterogenous mixture containing large particles that will settle on standing. Sand in water is an example of a suspension. A solution is a homogenous mixture of two or more substances where one substance has dissolved the other. An example of a solution is saltwater . Colloids are homogenous mixtures where the particles are small enough that they stay suspended. An example of this is gelatin, which stays suspended in water to form a gel.

title: Equilibrium constant
description: Equilibrium reactions and constants.

title: Factors that affect chemical equilibrium
description: Le Chatlier's principle (also known as "Chatelier's principle" or "The Equilibrium Law") states that when a system experiences a disturbance (such as concentration, temperature, or pressure changes), it will respond to restore a new equilibrium state. For example, if more reactants are added to a system, Le Chatlier's principle predicts that the reaction will generate more products to offset the change and restore equilibrium.

title: Acids, bases, and pH
description: Arrhenius definition of acids and bases.

title: Acid-base equilibria
description: Introduction to conjugate acid-base pairs. Definition and examples of conjugate acid-base pairs.

title: Buffer solutions
description: Introduction to buffer systems, which regulate pH in blood.

title: Titrations
description: Introduction to acid-base titrations using example of titrating 20.0 mL of HCl of unknown concentration with 0.100 M NaOH. Covers indicators, endpoint, equivalence point, and calculating the unknown concentration.

title: Solubility equilibria
description: Defining solute, solvent, hydration, dissolution, precipitation, net ionic equation, and spectator ions. Looking at the molecular level interactions between water and ions in NaCl.

title: Internal energy
description: Energy cannot be created or destroyed. It can only be transferred or converted from one form to another.

title: Enthalpy
description:
Today's episode dives into the HOW of enthalpy. How we calculate it, and how we determine it experimentally...even if our determinations here at Crash Course Chemistry are somewhat shoddy.
Writers: Edi Gonzalez
Chief Editor: Blake de Pastino
Consultant: Dr. Heiko Langner
Director/Editor: Nicholas Jenkins
Sound Designer: Michael Aranda
Graphics: Thought Cafe

title: Entropy
description: Introduction to entropy, and how entropy relates to the number of possible states for a system.

title: Gibbs free energy
description: Intuition behind why spontaneity is driven by enthalpy, entropy and temperature. Introduction to Gibbs free energy.

title: Oxidation-reduction reactions
description: Introducing oxidation states, oxidation, and reduction. Some tips for remembering oxidation and reduction.

title: Galvanic cells
description: What happens when you add zinc to a solution of copper sulfate? Identifying the half reactions to see what got oxidized and reduced.

title: Standard cell potentials
description: How to use a table of standard reduction potentials to calculate standard cell potential. Identifying trends in oxidizing and reducing agent strength.

title: Electrochemistry, thermodynamics, and equilibrium
description: Relationship between Gibbs free energy and standard cell potential.

title: Cell potentials under nonstandard conditions
description: Relationship between Gibbs free energy, reaction quotient Q, and cell voltage.

title: Electrolytic cells and electrolysis
description: Comparing a voltaic cell to an electrolytic cell.

title: Reaction rates and rate laws
description: Kinetics is the study of reaction rates and how they are affected. Many factors, such as concentration, pressure, temperature, and enzyme activity, can impact the rate of a reaction. For example, a molecule's kinetic energy is directly proportional to its temperature, so increasing the temperature will result in an increase in reaction rate.

title: Relationship between reaction concentrations and time
description: Deriving the integrated rate law for first-order reactions using calculus. How you can graph first-order rate data to see a linear relationship.

title: Arrhenius equation and reaction mechanisms
description: An introduction to collision theory and activation energy.

title: Spectrophotometry
description: Spectrophotometry, transmittance, absorbance and the Beer-Lambert Law

title: Radioactive decay
description: Nuclear binding energy is the energy required to split an atom’s nucleus into protons and neutrons. Mass defect is the difference between the predicted mass and the actual mass of an atom's nucleus. The binding energy of a system can appear as extra mass, which accounts for this difference.

title: 2015 AP Chemistry free response questions
description: Analyzing reactions and cell potential of a metal-air cell. From 2015 AP Chemistry free response 1a.

title: Introduction to the atom
description: A big picture view of chemistry and why it is fascinating. How chemistry relates to math and other sciences.

title: Compounds and ions
description: Examples to demonstrate the difference between empirical, structural, and molecular formulas

title: Balancing chemical equations
description: Reactants and products in reversible and irreversible chemical reactions.

title: Stoichiometry
description: Stoichiometry expresses the quantitative relationship between reactants and products in a chemical equation. Stoichiometric coefficients in a balanced equation indicate molar ratios in that reaction. Stoichiometry allows us to predict certain values, such as the percent yield of a product or the molar mass of a gas.

title: Limiting reagent stoichiometry
description: Stoichiometry problem where we find the limiting reagent and calculate grams of product formed.

title: Molecular composition
description: Examples to demonstrate the difference between empirical, structural, and molecular formulas

title: Types of chemical reactions
description: Finding the half reactions in a combustion reaction, and identifying what is getting oxidized and reduced.

From Leucippus to Heisenberg to you - yes, YOU - the story of Atomic Chemistry is all wibbly-wobbly... and amazing.

description: Arrhenius definition of acids and bases.

description: Introduction to conjugate acid-base pairs. Definition and examples of conjugate acid-base pairs.

description: Relationship between Gibbs free energy and standard cell potential.

description: Relationship between Gibbs free energy, reaction quotient Q, and cell voltage.

title: Electrolytic cells and electrolysis
description: Comparing a voltaic cell to an electrolytic cell.

title: 2015 AP Chemistry free response questions
description: Analyzing reactions and cell potential of a metal-air cell. From 2015 AP Chemistry free response 1a.

title: Dot structures
description: How to draw single bonds using dots to represent valence electrons.

title: Hybridization
description: sp3 Hybridized Orbitals and Sigma Bonds

title: Bond-line structures
description: How to go from Lewis dot structures to partially condensed structures to condensed structures

title: Electronegativity
description: Electronegativity differences in bonding using the Pauling scale. Classifying bonds as covalent, polar covalent, or ionic.

title: Counting electrons
description: How formal charges and oxidation states are both ways of counting electrons

title: Resonance structures
description: Introduction to resonance structures, when they are used, and how they are drawn.

title: Organic acid-base chemistry
description: Bronsted-Lowry and Arrhenius definitions of acids and bases.

title: Naming alkanes
description: Representing structures of organic molecules using line (or line-angle) diagrams.

title: Naming alkanes, cycloalkanes, and bicyclic compounds
description: Using IUPAC rules to name linear, branched, and cyclic hydrocarbons

title: Conformations of alkanes
description: Newman Projections

title: Conformations of cycloalkanes
description: Chair and Boat Shapes for Cyclohexane

title: Functional groups
description: An overview of some common functional groups

title: Chirality
description: Introduction to chirality (handedness), and how chirality is related to the groups bonded to a central carbon.

title: Enantiomers
description: Enantiomers are stereoisomers that are non-superimposable mirror images, meaning that one enantiomer will be the mirror image of the other enantiomer. In order to draw an enantiomer, you can determine the stereocenter, then swap the two groups attached to the stereocenter.

title: Stereoisomeric relationships
description: Stereoisomers, Enantiomers, Diastereomers, Constitutional Isomers and Meso Compounds

title: Free radical reaction
description: Free radical reactions

title: Nucleophilicity and basicity
description: Nucleophilicity (Nucleophile Strength)

title: Elimination reactions
description: E2 Elimination Reactions

title: Sn1/Sn2/E1/E2
description: Comparing E2 E1 Sn2 Sn1 reactions

title: Sn1 and Sn2
description: The definition of nucleophiles and electrophiles. Identifying nucleophilic and electrophilic centers in a molecule.

title: E1 and E2 reactions
description: Mechanism of an E1 elimination reaction.

title: Sn1/Sn2/E1/E2
description: How to figure out if a reagent will act as a strong or weak base or a nucleophile in a reaction.

title: Naming alkenes
description: Naming Alkenes Examples

title: Alkene reactions
description: Introduction to Reaction Mechanisms .  Addition reaction to an alkene

title: Alkene nomenclature
description: Introduction to alkenes: geometry and rotation about the double bond and stability of differently substituted forms.

title: Alkene reactions
description: Hydrogenation of an alkene using hydrogen gas and a platinum (or palladium or nickel) catalyst. The mechanism of syn addition of the hydrogens.

title: Naming and preparing alkynes
description: Rules for naming alkynes (molecules with a carbon-carbon triple bond).

title: Alkyne reactions
description: Different methods for reducing alkynes to alkenes or alkynes.

title: Synthesis using alkynes
description: Using a flowsheet showing different reactions of alkanes, alkenes, and alkynes to solve an organic synthesis problem.

title: Alcohol nomenclature and properties
description: Naming alcohols.

title: Synthesis of alcohols
description: How to prepare a primary or secondary alcohol from a ketone or aldehyde using sodium borohydride.

title: Reactions of alcohols
description: Oxidation of primary alcohols to aldehydes (and then carboxylic acids); oxidation of secondary alcohols to ketones.

title: Nomenclature and properties of ethers
description: Ether naming and introduction.

title: Synthesis and cleavage of ethers
description: Two-step synthesis of an ether from an alcohol, A strong base is a dded to deprotonate the alcohol, which then attacks an alkyl halide.

title: Nomenclature and preparation of epoxides
description: Cyclic ethers and epoxide naming.

title: Ring-opening reactions of epoxides
description: How nucleophilic attack can open the highly strained ring of an epoxide.

title: Thiols and sulfides
description: How to prepare sulfides from thiols. Sulfides are like ethers, but with a sulfur instead of an oxygen atom.

title: Diels-Alder reaction
description: How to draw the products for a Diels-Alder reaction

title: Naming benzene derivatives
description: Naming benzene derivatives introduction.

title: Reactions of benzene
description: Electrophilic aromatic substitution.

title: Aromatic stability
description: The aromaticity of benzene.

title: Electrophilic aromatic substitution
description: The general reaction and mechanism of electrophilic aromatic substitution.

title: Directing effects
description: Regiochemistry.

title: Other reactions and synthesis
description: The mechanism of the Birch reduction.

title: Nucleophilic aromatic substitution
description: The addition-elimination mechanism.

title: Introduction to aldehydes and ketones
description: Aldehyde introduction.

title: Reactions of aldehydes and ketones
description: How ketones and aldehydes react with water to form hydrates.

title: Naming carboxylic acids
description: Carboxylic acid introduction.

title: Formation of carboxylic acid derivatives
description: Fischer esterification of carboxylic acids.

title: Nomenclature and reactions of carboxylic acids
description: Naming carboxylic acids and analyzing their physical properties.

title: Nomenclature and reactions of carboxylic acid derivatives
description: How to name acyl (acid) chlorides and acid anhydrides and how to analyze their physical properties.

title: Formation of enolate anions
description: Keto-enol tautomerization.

title: Aldol condensations
description: Introduction to the mechanism for the aldol reaction.

title: Naming amines
description: Amine naming introduction.

title: Infrared spectroscopy
description: Basic principles of spectroscopy. Light absorption and bond vibration.

title: UV/Vis Spectroscopy
description: Introduction to UV/Vis spectroscopy. How this technique is used to analyze molecules with electrons in pi orbitals and nonbonding orbitals.

title: Proton NMR
description: The basic physical principles underlying proton NMR spectroscopy.

title: Welcome to biology!
description: Overview of biology, the study of life.

title: The science of biology
description: How the scientific method is used to ask questions and test explanations.

title: Elements and atoms
description: How elements relate to atoms. The basics of how protons, electrons, and neutrons make up an atom.

title: Electron shells and orbitals
description: Introduction to orbitals. Relates energy shell to rows and periods in the periodic table.

title: Chemical bonds and reactions
description: There are three major types of chemical bonds: ionic, covalent, and metallic. Ionic bonds form due to the transfer of an electron from one atom to another. Covalent bonds involve the sharing of electrons between two atoms. Metallic bonds are formed by the attraction between metal ions and delocalized, or "free" electrons.

title: Hydrogen bonding in water
description: Hydrogen bonding in water.

title: Cohesion and adhesion
description: How capillary action and the meniscus are related to intermolecular forces in water.

title: Temperature and state changes in water
description: LeBron asks Sal why sweating helps cool the body down.

title: Acids, bases, and pH
description: Autoionization of water into hydronium and hydroxide ions.

title: Carbon
description: Carbon as a building block of life.

title: Hydrocarbon structures and functional groups
description: Hydrocarbon overview.

title: Carbohydrates
description: Molecular structure of glucose. Monosaccharide structure. Linear and ring forms.

title: Lipids
description: Understanding how a triglyceride (triacylglycerol) can be formed from a glycerol molecule and three fatty acids.

title: Nucleic acids
description: Learn about DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Overview of DNA bases, complementary base pairing, and the structure of the double helix.

title: Proteins
description: Amino acids and the central dogma of molecular biology. Amino and carboxyl groups, side chains, and zwitterions.

title: Energy in metabolism
description: Overview of metabolism, anabolism, and catabolism.

title: Laws of thermodynamics
description: Energy is defined as the ability to do work. Energy can be found in many things and can take different forms. For example, kinetic energy is the energy of motion, and potential energy is energy due to an object's position or structure. Energy is never lost, but it can be converted from one form to another.

title: Free energy
description: Gibbs free energy and spontaneous reactions.

title: ATP and reaction coupling
description: Learn more about ATP: how it stores energy, and how that energy is released when it's converted to ADP and phosphate.

title: Introduction to enzymes
description: Kinetics is the study of reaction rates and how they are affected. Many factors, such as concentration, pressure, temperature, and enzyme activity, can impact the rate of a reaction. For example, a molecule's kinetic energy is directly proportional to its temperature, so increasing the temperature will result in an increase in reaction rate.

title: Enzyme regulation
description: The cofactors and coenzymes (organic cofactors) that help enzymes catalyze reactions.

title: Introduction to cells
description: Thinking about how large a cell is compared to viruses, proteins and simple molecules.

title: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells
description: Thinking about the limiting factors of cell size. Focus on volume to surface area ratio.

title: Tour of a eukaryotic cell
description: Structure of the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi body (Golgi apparatus). Their role in protein secretion.

title: Extracellular structures and cell-cell junctions
description: Overview of how cells interact with the extracellular matrix.

title: The plasma membrane
description: The fluid mosaic model describes the cell membrane as a tapestry of several types of molecules (phospholipids, cholesterols, and proteins) that are constantly moving. This movement helps the cell membrane maintain its role as a barrier between the inside and outside of the cell environments.

title: Diffusion and osmosis
description: Learn about how particles move from an area of greater concentration to an area of lesser concentration through the process of diffusion.

title: Passive transport
description: Passive transport and selective permeability. Passive transport through diffusion.

title: Active transport
description: How the the sodium-potassium (Na+/K+) pump works. Its role in establishing resting membrane potentials.

title: Bulk transport
description: Bulk transport: endocytosis, phagocytosis, and pinocytosis.

title: Introduction to cellular respiration
description: Learn more about ATP: how it stores energy, and how that energy is released when it's converted to ADP and phosphate.

title: Steps of cellular respiration
description: Overview: glycolysis, pyruvate oxidation, the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle), and oxidative phosphorylation.

title: Glycolysis
description: Overview of the basics of glycolysis.

title: Pyruvate oxidation and the citric acid cycle
description: Overview of the Krebs or citric acid cycle, which is a series of reactions that takes in acetyl CoA and  produces carbon dioxide, NADH, FADH2, and ATP or GTP.

title: Oxidative phosphorylation
description: How oxidation of co-enzymes like NADH can lead to the production of ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.

title: Variations on cellular respiration
description: Lactic acid fermentation. How organisms like lactobacillus convert pyruvic acid to lactic acid and oxidize NADH to NAD+ in the process.

title: Intro to photosynthesis
description: Learn more about ATP: how it stores energy, and how that energy is released when it's converted to ADP and phosphate.

title: The Calvin cycle
description: The Calvin cycle, or the light-independent (dark) reactions of photosythesis.

title: Photorespiration: C3, C4, and CAM plants
description: The Calvin cycle and a competing pathway called photorespiration (also initiated by Rubisco).

title: How cells signal to each other
description: Overview of cell signaling. Autocrine, paracrine and endocrine signaling.

title: Communication in single-celled organisms
description: Yeast can reproduce sexually through a signaling pathway known as the mating factor pathway. In this process, two haploid yeast cells combine to form a diploid cell. Yeast cells secrete a signal molecule called mating factor that attracts them to their mates. Once the mating factor of one yeast binds to the receptor on another yeast, an outgrowth called a "shmoo" forms, which allows the yeast cells to fuse together.

title: Introduction to cell division
description: How haploid gametes (sperm and egg cells) combine to form a diploid zygote with two sets of chromosomes.

title: The cell cycle and mitosis
description: Interphase of the cell cycle, including G₁, S, and G₂ phases. How the cell replicates its DNA before mitosis.

title: Meiosis
description: Comparison of the processes of mitosis and meiosis.

title: Cell cycle regulation, cancer, and stem cells
description: An overview of early development of a zygote to an embryo. Embryonic and somatic stem cells.

title: Mendelian genetics
description: Heredity and Classical Genetics. Dominant and recessive traits. Heterozygous and homozygous genotypes.

title: Variations on Mendelian genetics
description: Learn how to use Punnett squares to calculate probabilities of different phenotypes. Includes worked examples of dihybrid crosses. independent assortment, incomplete dominance, codominance, and multiple alleles.

title: Chromosomal basis of genetics
description: Overview of how chromosomes were first proposed as the carriers of Mendel's "heritable factors" (what we now call "genes").

title: Sex linkage, chromosomal mutations, & non-nuclear inheritance
description: Sex-linked traits are associated with genes found on sex chromosomes. In humans, the sex chromosomes are X and Y. Because the X-chromosome is larger, X-linked traits are more common than Y-linked traits. An example of a sex-linked trait is red-green colorblindness, which is carried on the X-chromosome. Because males only have one X-chromosome, they have a higher chance of having red-green colorblindness.

title: Molecular basis of genetics
description: Learn about DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Overview of DNA bases, complementary base pairing, and the structure of the double helix.

title: Structure of DNA
description: Learn about DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Overview of DNA bases, complementary base pairing, and the structure of the double helix.

title: Discovery of DNA
description: How Griffith and later Avery, McCarty and MacLeod found strong evidence that DNA is the "transforming principle" that encodes genetic information.

title: DNA replication
description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Central dogma and the genetic code
description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Transcription
description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Translation
description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Stem cells
description: An overview of early development of a zygote to an embryo. Embryonic and somatic stem cells.

title: Development & differentiation
description: Visit us (http://www.khanacademy.org/science/healthcare-and-medicine) for health and medicine content or (http://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat) for MCAT related content. title: Apoptosis
description: How apoptosis is different from cell death by injury. Role in development and body maintenance.

title: Prokaryote structure
description: Introduction to bacteria.

title: Viruses
description: Introduction to viruses.

title: Evolution and natural selection
description: Introduction to how groups of organisms evolve and how natural selection can lead to evolution.

title: Population genetics
description: Allele frequencies in populations and how they differ from genotype frequencies.

title: Speciation and evolutionary trees
description: The science of taxonomy and where humans fit into the tree of life.

title: Formation of Earth and early life
description: Earth ​was formed approximately 4.6 billion years ago, likely as the result of a supernova (star explosion). The debris from this explosion began to collapse in on itself due to gravity, forming the sun. Gravity continued to draw the remaining particles together, clumping them into larger bodies, ultimately forming Earth and the other planets in our solar system.

title: The diversification of life
description: Ozone layer and eukaryotes show up in the Proterozoic eon. Great oxygenation event (oxygen catastrophe).

title: Radiometric dating
description: Discussion of the relatively recent changes in our ability as a species to shine light on our deep past

title: Intro to ecology
description: Ecology is the study of how living things interact with each other and their environment. This includes living things (biotic factors) and non-living things (abiotic factors).

title: Intro to population ecology
description: How do organisms use different life history strategies to maximize fitness? Learn about different ways that different species allocate energy and other resources between growth, maintenance/survival, and reproduction.

title: Population growth & regulation
description: Learn about population growth rates and how they can be modeled by exponential and logistic equations.

title: Intro to community ecology
description: Learn about the many types of interspecific interactions: competition, predation, herbivory, symbiosis, parasitism, mutualism, commensalism.

title: Community structure & diversity
description: Flow of energy and matter through ecosystems. What happens if an ecosystem is disrupted. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Intro to ecosystems
description: Introduction to ecosystems. How land ecosystems are classified into biomes.

title: Biogeochemical cycles
description: Introduction to how water, carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus are cycled through ecosystems.

title: Biogeography
description: How biodiversity is distributed globally. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Ecosystems & ecosystem services
description: Flow of energy and matter through ecosystems. What happens if an ecosystem is disrupted. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Global distribution of biodiversity
description: What a biodiversity hotspot is, and why these locations are important to preserve. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Threats to biodiversity
description: Human activities that cause a loss of biodiversity. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Protecting biodiversity
description: Different approaches to conservation and how they can protect species and habitats. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Levels of biodiversity
description: How does the gene pool contribute to biodiversity? Learn how genetic diversity within populations contributes to species survival. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Animal behavior

title: Circulatory and pulmonary systems
description: The pulmonary system including the lungs, larynx, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, alveoli and thoracic diaphragm.

title: The neuron and nervous system
description: Neurons (or nerve cells) are specialized cells that transmit and receive electrical signals in the body. Neurons are composed of three main parts: dendrites, a cell body, and an axon. Signals are received through the dendrites, travel to the cell body, and continue down the axon until they reach the synapse (the communication point between two neurons).

title: The kidney and nephron
description: Overview of how the nephrons in the kidney filter blood and reabsorb water and other molecules.

title: Muscles
description: How myosin and actin interact to produce mechanical force.

title: Immunology
description: Role of phagocytes in innate or nonspecific immunity. Neutrophils, macrophages, and dendritic cells. MHC II.

title: Plant responses to light
description: Phototropism and the role that auxin plays.

title: Free-response questions: 2015 AP Biology exam
description: Genetic and environmental influences on mouse activity cycles.

title: Crash Course: Biology
description: Hank discusses the properties of carbon and the bonding behavior of atoms.

title: Crash Course: Ecology
description: Hank discusses the history of life on Earth (including major events such as oxygenation of the atmosphere and mass extinctions).

description: Introduction to orbitals. Relates energy shell to rows and periods in the periodic table.

title: Chemical bonds and reactions
description: There are three major types of chemical bonds: ionic, covalent, and metallic. Ionic bonds form due to the transfer of an electron from one atom to another. Covalent bonds involve the sharing of electrons between two atoms. Metallic bonds are formed by the attraction between metal ions and delocalized, or "free" electrons.

description: Overview of the nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi bodies, vacuoles, mitochondria, chloroplasts and lysosomes.

description: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Bacteria and archaea.

description: Overview of animal and plant cells. Topics include cell walls, vacuoles, chloroplasts, peroxisomes, lysosomes, mitochondria, etc.

description: Overview of metabolism, anabolism, and catabolism.

description: Introduction to passive and active transport

description: Osmosis of water from an area of lower to an area of higher solute concentration across a semipermeable membrane.

title: Cellular respiration
description: Introduction to cellular respiration, including glycolysis, the Krebs Cycle, and the electron transport chain.

title: Types of reproduction
description: Binary fission, budding, mitosis, fragmentation, parthenogenesis  and sexual reproduction.

description: Overview of DNA transcription, translation, and replication during mitosis and meiosis. Learn about chromosomes, chromatids, and chromatin.

title: The cell cycle and mitosis
description: Interphase of the cell cycle, including G₁, S, and G₂ phases. How the cell replicates its DNA before mitosis.

title: Meiosis
description: How homologous chromosomes exchange fragments in prophase I. Tetrads, chiasmata, and alleles.

title: Fertilization and development
description: Overview of fertilization and early human development. From conception leading to a zygote to blastocyst, embryo and fetus.

title: Introduction to heredity
description: Heredity and Classical Genetics. Dominant and recessive traits. Heterozygous and homozygous genotypes.

title: Non-Mendelian inheritance
description:
Come learn about Co-dominance and incomplete dominance and 
how they differ from complete dominance. By Ross Firestone.

description: Sex-linked traits are associated with genes found on sex chromosomes. In humans, the sex chromosomes are X and Y. description: An introduction to reading and analyzing pedigrees.

description: Learn about DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Overview of DNA bases, complementary base pairing, and the structure of the double helix.

description: Molecular structure of RNA.

description: Introduction to genetic engineering. Human breeding. Recombinant DNA. Bioethics.

description: An overview of the different types of evidence that support evolution, including homologous and analogous features and vestigial structures.

description: The science of taxonomy and where humans fit into the tree of life.

title: Body structure and homeostasis
description: Ever wondered why your temperature stays at 98.6 degrees? Learn about homeostasis and how your body maintains a stable temperature.

title: The immune system
description: Innate vs. adaptive immunity. Humoral adaptive immunity vs. cell-mediated adaptive immunity.

title: Introduction to ecology
description: Ecology is the study of how living things interact with each other and their environment. This includes living things (biotic factors) and non-living things (abiotic factors).

title: Population ecology
description: Learn about population growth rates and how they can be modeled by exponential and logistic equations.

title: Community ecology
description: Are all coral reefs the same?  Each regional ecosystem has its own assemblage of species and each contributes uniquely to global biodiversity. Explore why ecosystem diversity is important for conservation decisions. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Ecological relationships
description: Learn about the many types of interspecific interactions: competition, predation, herbivory, symbiosis, parasitism, mutualism, commensalism.

title: Trophic levels
description: Seeing how energy and matter flows and is recycled from primary producers (autotrophs) to primary, secondary and tertiary consumers.

title: Biogeochemical cycles
description: Introduction to how water, carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus are cycled through ecosystems.

title: Human impact on ecosystems
description: Human activities that cause a loss of biodiversity. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Scale of earth, sun, galaxy and universe
description: Attempting to comprehend the scale of the large

title: Time scale of the cosmos
description: Cosmological Time Scale 1

title: Light and fundamental forces
description: Light and the electromagnetic radiation spectrum. Wave and particle-like behavior, and how to calculate the wavelength or frequency of a light wave.

title: Big bang and expansion of the universe
Life and death of stars
description: Birth of Stars

title: Quasars and galactic collisions
description: Quasars

title: Stellar parallax
description: Parallax in Observing Stars

title: Cepheid variables
description: Cepheid Variables 1

title: Plate tectonics
description: Plate Tectonics Introduction and Difference between crust and lithosphere

title: Seismic waves and how we know earth's structure
description: S-waves and P-waves

title: Earth's rotation and tilt
description: Why our closeness to the sun does not dictate the seasons

title: Moon phases and eclipses
description: An introduction to the size of the Moon, the distance to the Moon, the relation of the 28-day cycle of the Moon to a month and understanding the phases of the Moon.

title: History of life on earth
description: Earth ​was formed approximately 4.6 billion years ago, likely as the result of a supernova (star explosion). The debris from this explosion began to collapse in on itself due to gravity, forming the sun. Gravity continued to draw the remaining particles together, clumping them into larger bodies, ultimately forming Earth and the other planets in our solar system.

title: Humanity on earth
description: From the extinction of the dinosaurs to humanity

title: Measuring age on earth
description: Discussion of the relatively recent changes in our ability as a species to shine light on our deep past

title: Life in the universe
description: A framework for thinking about how many detectable civilizations are out there.

title: Getting started
description: Current is the flow of charge. We measure current by counting the amount of charge passing through a boundary in one second.

title: Circuit elements
description: Introduction to the most common circuit elements: resistor, capacitor, and inductor. Introducing the current-voltage equations for these elements, including Ohm's Law for resistors.

title: Resistor circuits
description: Resistors connected head-to-tail are in series. The equivalent overall resistance is the sum of the individual resistance values.

title: DC circuit analysis
description: Kirchhoff's Current Law says the currents flowing into a node must add up to zero.

title: Natural and forced response
description: The capacitor current-voltage equation in derivative form and integral form

title: AC circuit analysis
description: Solving circuits with differential equations is hard. If we limit ourselves to sinusoidal input signals, a whole new method of AC analysis emerges.

title: Operational amplifier
description: The "operational amplifier" has two differential inputs and very high gain. Willy describes the symbol and properties of an op-amp. Op-amps are the backbone of analog circuit design.

title: Diode
description: Introducing the diode as a circuit element. A diode conducts current in one direction but not the other.

title: Electric force and electric field
description: Sal explains the fundamental force that causes charged particles to attract or repel each other

title: Fields, potential, and voltage
description: Advanced proof of the formula for the electric field generated by a uniformly charged, infinite plate

title: Fourier series
description: The Fourier Series allows us to model any arbitrary periodic signal with a combination of sines and cosines. In this video sequence Sal works out the Fourier Series of a square wave.

title: All about Spout
description:
Mrs. Rowhani's third graders learn about matter and energy by building a Spout bot with Khan Academy. 

Special thanks to: Santa Rita's volunteer parents, Kami Thordarson, Karen Wilson and of course Laleh Rowhani the class teacher.

title: Spout Bot without Solder
description: Make Spout a low cost beetle bot that can avoid obstacles. Spout is low cost and can be made without solder.

title: Spider Bot
description:
Vicki Lombardi's 6th grade students at Santa Rita Elementary in Los Altos School district learn how to build a Spider robot.

Read more at: http://lasdilearn.blogspot.com/2013/02/third-graders-building-robots-mission.html

title: Bit-zee Bot
description: Bit-zee is a project designed to inspire students to explore math and science. It was created from everyday items (a hair dryer, tap light, alarm clock, digital camera, and a universal remote). See the following link for help with the code https://sites.google.com/site/khanacademyprojects/home

title: Introduction
description: Anything robots can do, lego robots can do!

title: Light guitar
description: Light guitar in action!

title: Coin detector
description: demonstration of a simple coin detector

title: Ant bot
description: demonstration of a basic ant bot

title: Programming basics
description: Ready, set... start your engines!

title: Household items
description: In this video we explore what is inside an alarm clock, how it is made, and how it works.

title: Hair dryer
description: In this video we explore ground fault interrupt circuits and how they keep us safe.

title: DVD player
description: In this video we explore the housing and functions of a DVD player.

title: Digital camera
description: In this video we go inside the digital camera to discover what is inside and how it works.

title: Respiratory system introduction
description: Every time you take a breath, oxygen makes it way into your lungs. Follow along on that journey! Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Hematologic system introduction
description: Spin down your blood and find out what it's made up of.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Immunologic system introduction
description: Role of phagocytes in innate or nonspecific immunity. Neutrophils, macrophages, and dendritic cells. MHC II.

title: Nervous system introduction
description: This video provides an introduction to the cell types of the nervous system. By Matt Jensen.

title: Muscular system introduction
description: How myosin and actin interact to produce mechanical force.

title: Endocrine system introduction
description: Welcome to the Endocrine System. Get ready to learn about one of the most important ways that our body parts communicate! By Ryan Patton.

title: Lymphatic system introduction
description: Welcome to the lymphatic system! Find out why we need it, and how it interacts with our blood vessels. By Patrick van Nieuwenhuizen.

title: Pregnancy and pregnancy complications
description:

title: Blood pressure
description: Find out what a systolic and diastolic blood pressure mean.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Blood pressure control
description: Learn about how the arteries use nerve impulses to help regulate blood pressure.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Fetal circulation
description: Learn how the needs of the fetus are met by the placenta, which is a special organ that belongs to both the mother and the fetus! Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Blood vessels
description: Remember the 3 key layers of a blood vessel (Tunica intima, Tunica media, and Tunica externa) and how arteries, veins, and capillaries are all different from one another. Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Arterial stiffness
description: Learn about compliance (and elastance) of arteries, veins, and lead pipes!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Heart muscle contraction
description: Understanding the structure of a muscle cell.

title: Heart depolarization
description: Find out how a cell that is permeable to one ion can become charged (either positive or negative) if there is permeability and a concentration gradient. Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Nerve regulation of the heart
description: Find out exactly how your autonomic nervous system has a chronotropic effect (i.e. timing) that changes the delay between the contraction of the atria and the ventricles!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Preload and afterload
description: Understand LaPlace's law to see the effect that pressure, radius, and wall thickness each have on the "wall stress" in the left ventricle. Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Pressure volume loops
description: Watch the pressure in the left heart go up and down with every heart beat!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Changing the PV loop
description: Some say Preload = End-Diastolic Pressure, others say Preload = End-Diastolic Volume, so which one is it? Watch and find out! Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Atherosclerosis, arteriosclerosis, and arteriolosclerosis
description: Learn some important differences between arteries (high pressure/low volume) and veins (low pressure/high volume).

title: Stroke

title: Acyanotic heart diseases
description: Acyanotic heart disease is a group of heart conditions where blood with oxygen mixes with blood with little oxygen in the heart. This mixing is not enough to cause cyanosis, a symptom of not enough oxygen being delivered to tissues of the body, hence the name acyanotic heart disease.

title: Vasculitis
description: Vasculitis is a group of medical conditions which cause damage to the blood vessels through inflammation. Depending on which blood vessels are affected, vasculitis can be classified as large vessel, medium vessel, or small vessel vasculitis. Learn about the signs and symptoms of vasculitis such as purpura, bloody stool and urine, and bruits.

title: Respiratory system introduction
description: Every time you take a breath, oxygen makes it way into your lungs. Follow along on that journey! Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Gas exchange
description:
Find out how to calculate exactly how much oxygen is deep down inside your lungs!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

These videos do not provide medical advice and are for informational purposes only. The videos are not intended to be a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis or treatment. Always seek the advice of a qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding a medical condition. Never disregard professional medical advice or delay in seeking it because of something you have read or seen in any Khan Academy video.

title: Breathing control
description: Peripheral chemoreceptors are extensions of the peripheral nervous system that respond to changes in blood molecule concentrations (such as oxygen or carbon dioxide) and help maintain cardiorespiratory homeostasis. They are generally located in the carotid and aortic bodies.

title: Introduction to pulmonary diseases
description: Learn what the main classifications of lung diseases are: obstructive, restrictive, ventilation, and perfusion. Discover the classification of common diseases like asthma, emphysema, and pneumonia.

title: Emphysema (COPD)
description: Emphysema is a chronic medical condition (most often caused by smoking and air pollution) where lung tissue is damaged and traps air inside the lung. Learn how shortness of breath, persistent cough, and wheezing are common symptoms of this condition and why they occur in emphysema.

title: Pneumonia
description: Pneumonia is a medical condition where lung tissue becomes inflamed, usually caused by a virus or bacteria. Learn how shortness of breath, cough, and fever are common symptoms of this condition and why they occur in pneumonia.

title: Pleural Effusion
description: Pleural effusions are when excess fluid get caught between two layers of tissue (the visceral and parietal pleurae) surrounding the lungs. This fluid can build up over time, taking up space in the lung and impairing a person’s ability to breath. Learn about the signs and symptoms of pleural effusions such as chest pain, shortness of breath, and dry coughing.

title: Lung cancer
description: Lung cancer is a disease where cells in the lungs multiply uncontrollably. The extra cells take up space in the lungs and impair gas exchange and the lung’s ability to expel dirt. Learn how smoking, radon gas, and air pollution increase the risk of lung cancer.

title: Nose, sinus, and upper respiratory conditions
Hematologic system introduction
description: Spin down your blood and find out what it's made up of.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Bleeding and impaired hemostasis
description: Hemostasis is the process which stops bleeding after an injury. Blood vessels are repaired by the creation of a platelet plug during primary hemostasis, and the platelet plug is further reinforced by the conversion of fibrin to fibrinogen during secondary hemostasis.

title: Leukemia
description: Hematopoiesis is the process of creating new blood cells in the body. All blood cells start off as hematopoietic stem cells, and then specialize (differentiate) into myeloid cells (erythrocytes, megakaryocytes, monocytes, neutrophils, basophils, or eosinophils) or lymphoid cells (T-lymphocytes and B-lymphocytes).

title: Iron deficiency anemia and anemia of chronic disease
Myeloproliferative disorders
description:
Learn about 4 different cancers that involve the bone marrow and produce a large number of cells in the blood stream. By Raja Narayan.

title: Emotion
description: The limbic system is a set of structures in the brain that deal with emotions and memory. It regulates autonomic or endocrine function in response to emotional stimuli and also is involved in reinforcing behavior . The limbic system is composed of four main parts: the hypothalamus, the amygdala, the thalamus, and the hippocampus. There are several other structures that may be involved in the limbic system as well, but scientists have not reached a unanimous consensus on them.

AP(R) Macroeconomics on Khan Academy: Macroeconomics is all about how an entire nation’s performance is determined and improved over time. We hit the traditional topics from an AP Macroeconomics course, including basic economic concepts, economic indicators and the business cycle, national income and price determination, the financial sector, the long-run consequences of stabilization policies, and international trade and finance.

title: Real vs. nominal GDP

title: Business cycles
description: The business cycle and how it may be driven by emotion

title: Aggregate demand

title: Multipliers

title: Long-run aggregate supply

title: Equilibrium in the AD-AS Model
description:
The interaction of SRAS and AD determine national income. We can compare that national income to the full employment national income to determine the current phase of the business cycle. An economy is said to be in long-run equilibrium if the short-run equilibrium output is equal to the full employment output.

title: Changes in the AD-AS model in the short run
description: Factors that might shift aggregate demand

title: Long run self-adjustment
description:
A demand shock has a short-run effect on an output and unemployment, but in the long run only the price level will be impacted. If there is an increase in aggregate demand, the price level will go up. Once wages have adjusted to that inflation in the long run, SRAS decreases and returns the economy to full employment output. Shocks do not cause economic growth, only changes in full employment output cause economic growth.

title: Fiscal policy
description:
Fiscal policy can be used to close output gaps. Fiscal policy means using either taxes or government spending to stabilize the economy. Expansionary fiscal policy can close recessionary gaps (using either decreased taxes or increased spending) and contractionary fiscal policy can close inflationary gaps (using either increased taxes or decreased spending).
